a: a dark murky silky brownish black mix. dark as night. 1 finger tan/cherry/mahogany head that fades relatively quickly to some that just hangs around the edge of the glass. no surprise given the abc  s: dark caramel malts, cherry, so much wood, baking chocolate powder, figs, and some alcohol  t: its intense. right away your punched in the tongue with a little jolt of alcohol. this fades to an intense woody flavor with some rich syrupy caramel malts. that fades further to a pretty noticeable cherry flavor that i don't think is actually cherry. its like a nice exotic mix of ginger & cherry - slightly sweet. finishes with some cocoa powder and a smooth vanilla. quite a bit of alcohol in here  m: medium. i was thinking it would be a little heavier, but its surprisingly easy drinking (mouthfeel wise)  o: well. definitely the most intense brown ale i've ever had. the woody flavor is incredible in here. minus the alcohol in the flavor (which id expect for something at 12%) everything in here is blended really well. a mix of malts, wood, and that cherry-like flavor really come together to create a beer that is something you'd end your night with. but be careful - this is a sipper for sure

A. This is what I like to see in a beer. Nice frothy head and rich clear color. Good head retention and great lacing. I would give it a five except that it says its a brown and its more like a stout being so black.  S. I love the aroma, nice and strong, malts, chocolate, coffee.  T. This is the 2nd time I've had it and as I continue with this one it just gets better. It is not real complex but I like it. For a 12%, you would not know it. The flavor same as nose. Very balanced nothing unpleasant that lingers.  M. Nice, except for me,a little to sticky in the lingering feel but nothing gets tired in the feel even as it warms.  O. There is an appeal to this beer that makes me want to try it again. It is not too heavy for such a strong brew. I am not sure why but I really like it. Its easy to drink and not overbearing in any way. Simply good.

Pours a thick, syrupy brown with a mocha head that sees some impressive retention and lacing.  Not a huge nose on this one -- smells sweet like caramel, with some roasted grains and fennel in the background.  Rich toffee, caramel and anise up front, cherry and syrupy sweetness in the middle, with some chalky chocolate and coffee on the finish. A little pepper and wood linger on the aftertaste. There's an exotic elixir flavor that I can't quite put my finger on, like ginseng or something. It all blends together very well for a unique, indulgent experience.  Mouthfeel is nice and round, equal parts slick and syrupy, with some boozy dryness around the edges.  A big beer that goes down oh so smooth and will have your body feeling tingly in no time. This tasty treat defies characterization.

Poured with a one inch medium, brown head, with a light red hue near the bottom portion of the head. The body of the beer appears black. This brew definitely has some dark purple, and/or ruby colors lurking around in there. The head dies down into a light cover over the top and spreads out to ring the sides of the glass. The lacing is slippery and easily slides down the sides of the glass. This beer is definitely appealing to look at.  There is a faint boozy and roasted malt smell. There is also an aroma of earth and sweetness.  This beer almost has a bourbon type of taste, but doesn't go all the way through with it. The bourbon end is missing, no booziness. The taste is familiar but exotic. Similar to a stout, but of course different.  The mouthfeel of this brown ale is chewy, plus smooth and silky, with mild, dense carbonation.  Overall, this is a unique, complex beer. The wood used in aging plays a big part in this beers outstanding, overall quality. I will drink this beer again and will keep my eyes out for more of it in the future.

Bottle date 12/19/12. Very dark reddish brown with a small khaki head. Smell is very woody with some sweetness and roastiness. Taste is quite sweet, almost cola-like. After the sweetness comes the wood flavor. Then a little booze, and more wood. Some roast comes thru in the finish. Mouthfeel medium, a little syrupy. It's a pretty nice, sweet beer. Not super-complex but enjoyable.  PS: Bottlecap seal looks normal but exhibits a strange artificial odor.

On tap: Pours more black than brown, more like a porter. Head is foamy red-tan and decently thick, lasting, and provides lacing. The nose isn't as roasted in nature as I expected from the color. Perhaps the wood mellows it a tad, and it comes through with a bit as a wine-cherry-ish tartness. There are also some dark sugar notes in as well.  The initial tastes are on the sweet side, the dark sugar from the nose. The beer has a bit of quad-like sweetness (without the Belgian yeast notes), date, plum, fig. The feel is silky smooth, and the wood that subtly comes through adds a light drying feel in the end. As the beer warms, the alcohol does add a little burn to the end.  I've had this numerous times before, and each time it seems to grow on me more. From being not much of a fan, this pour is a wonderful treat, one I feel I might even rate higher in the future.

The beer comes in a black/dark brown color with tinges of reddish brown on the edges.  The aroma is big deep raisin and plum, woody oak and cedar quality, alcohol, a chewy toffee/dark caramel sweetness, some roasted malt and coffee.  The beer in the front hits roasted malt. A bittersweet chocolate and espresso. Then onto again those sweet raisins, fig, and dried plum notes. A caramel and toffee sweetness and hint of nuttiness. Then onto a big slap of alcohol and then the beer lingers off of chocolate bitterness roasted malt and heavy wood note. Lots of tobacco character and drying instead of sweetness.  This beer probably does wonders with age as the alcohol is very prevalent. It is an interesting combination of stout, old ale, brown ale, quad, and barrel.  Still, this beer has beautiful complexity and should really be sought after like some of the other barrel aged brews.

Pours brownish black. Good amount of dark tan head. Molasses and oak aromas. Roasted malt. Earthy cloves. The flavors are similar: oak, molasses, vanillas, malt, earthy hops at the very end. A tad of alcohol heat in the back but not as much as 12% would have you believe. Fair amount of carbonation helps take away some of the sweetness.  Overall a good brew. The price doesn't reflect the quality though. I'm glad I tried it and would love to have it again sometime but it's too costly to be a regular.

First thing I noticed was the cloudy, deep/dark brown appearance and the fantastic carbonation. Smelled the vanilla and earthy characteristics from the oak barrels. Taste was great...a bit boozy on the aftertaste but that's to be expected from such a big beer (12% abv). Easy beer to drink if you don't mind a little alcohol in the aftertaste.

Poured into an Ale Syndicate Pint glass.  A) Dark brown almost black, thick two finger head surprising for a 12% abv beer. It leaves lots of lacing.  S) Burnt sugar, cookie, brown sugar, toffee, sweet malt, toast, and a honey.  T) Vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, sweet bread, wood, earthy, fusel alcohol after taste.  M) Thick medium amount of carbonation almost batter like.  O) This is delicious, a sweet malt bomb with woody finish. At 12% this one is good to share with a friend or spouse!

Had this at the Dogfish Head brew pub in Rehoboth Beach Delaware.  A: A nice dark brown, pretty much black, a nice tan head at the top that stuck around for a while, left a little lacing around the glass.  S: A nice nose on this beer, some caramel, bit of chocolate and brown sugar, nice notes.  T: Little vanilla and caramel up front, slight hints of the sweetness from the sugar but pretty complex, and great tasting.  M: Nice mouthfeel, very smooth and thick all at the same time, slight carbonation.  O: This beer was fantastic, lots of character and slight hints of the wood from the barrels its held in, I enjoyed this brew very much.

Appearance: Pours jet black with a creamy cappuccino colored one inch head. Poured on a teku glass, put against the light and couldn't pick up anything through the thick pour. Not much lacing after the head dissipates. Residual alcohol legs remain after every sip.  Smell: Vanilla and the alcohol is predominant, wrapped on the sweet aromas from the barrel aging - wood (palo santo, I guess :) ). I also pick up spices (trace amounts of cinnamon) and coffee, this last one mostly coming out after the beer warmed up a little after being in a fridge at 55 degrees.  Taste: Faint coffee comes out increasingly sip after sip, but never overpowering like some RIS. Vanilla and wine/spirit type alcohol are always present. This makes a very well balanced beer. The after taste is lasting and opens up with the sip's subsequent breath exposing more of the properties of this complex beer - vanilla ice cream, pinot noir, and cinnamon.  Mouthfeel: Creamy. Delicious. Almost no carbonation allowing for the tongue and palate to easily absorb the full spectrum of flavors, without distraction.  Overall: Excellent beer. At this price point ($14/4pk in WA) its a very compelling offering from DFH that can compete with both strong ales, brown ales as well as lower ABV RIS. I would love to pour one of these at a RIS blind taste.

A: Pours very dark and not what i expected for a 'brown' visible lacing and very little carbonation. S: Amazing smell and very inviting. I get the oak right off the bat with some caramel, raisin sweetness. You can smell the ABV on the nose which is always a good thing in my mind. T: The taste mimics the nose and just as solid. oak, chocolate, caramel, and an earthly alcohol sugar finish. M: Medium-heavy mouth, medium carbonation. very drinkable for the style and just heavy enough to know you are drinking 12%. O: Personally not been too impressed/excited for dogfish head in a few years but this one was a solid offering. not like the norm of this style and really pushed the outer bounds. I will look for this one in the future as it was an awesome surprise.

A: Pours a very dark, nearly black color with two fingers of dense, tan foam that retains beautifully and nearly cloaks the insides of the glass with a thick, tight lacing. Tiny bubbles continue to rise and build in layers below the surface. Looks nearly like a freshly brewed espresso with foam atop.  S: Strong, aromatic wood, dark malts, and raisin lead the nose with a hint of chocolate to follow. Aroma continues to build with more woody/earthy notes and some alcohol as it warms.  T: Smoke, wood, and roasted malts rush in, followed by a hint of sweet, dark fruit, and perhaps a bit of raisin and vanilla. Beautifully hidden alcohol, with very little noticeable heat. Roasted malts linger on the palate, with ever so slight bitterness at the finish.  M: Extremely creamy head with excellent carbonation, almost chewy full and silky mouthfeel, and incredibly smooth (actually, it's terrifyingly smooth for its ABV). Not nearly as thick as it looks, following the Brown Ale profile even though it looks more like a Stout. Finishes with a perfect touch of dryness.  O: Exceptional! This brew left me craving the next sip! It was almost as enjoyable to look at as it was to drink. If anything, I wish they had bolstered the aroma a bit, as it seems the rest of its attributes tend to overshadow the aromatic profile. Would highly recommend.

This was thoroughly enjoyable. A touch boozy, but so well balanced, as it warmed the booze did not heighten. Thick and chewy, this beer had hints of vanilla and dark fruit twisted amongst the caramel bittersweetness. I didn't get any wood from this, but the mouthfeel and carbo just danced up and down my palate. Will absolutely have again. Might be my new DFH fav. If your a RIS fan looking for a touch of variety, try this, you will thank me...

A) Dark brown color like a stout, Very small head  S) Sweet, roasted, dark fruit, woody, coffee  T) Sweet, roasted/smoky, hardwoods, coffee, not too much alcohol for 12%, delicious finish  M) Full body, low carbonation, smooth  O) Extremely delicious, great body, pleasant finish. This is a winner.

A- Super dark brown with hints of light coming through giving it an intense mahogany glimmer. Light 1 finger caramel head doesn't stick around long.  S- Lots of rich wood character, caramelized sugars, and touch of vanilla  T- Sweet malt up front mellows into the dark fruit and damp wood. Significant booze flavor in the finish.  M- I genuinely enjoyed the feel as it was full and somewhat silky, but the booze was slightly hot and distracting.  O- Very solid imperial brown here. I haven't had many beers of the style to compare it to, but the one that comes to mind is Prairie Okie. A bit more contained and less complex to that one in comparison. A unique and well done effort

A - Deep, black, with slight mahogany highlights, slight tan-brown head, with substantial lacing.  S - Big hits of alcohol and wood, but strangely flattened.  T - Malty sweetness of burnt caramel, wood, a spike of acidity and alcohol booziness, with a closing to vanilla and roasted malt notes.  M - Coats the tongue, but the body is not particularly heavy, but there is significant alcohol burn.  O - Not your standard brown. This is a beer that comes in big, with huge sweetness, alien wood elements, and underlying booze notes. It is a beer that is greater than the sum of its parts, managing to meld disparate elements into a pleasurable drink. Sip and ponder the wild ride.

Appearance: Brown as a turd but tasty. A nice half inch head.  Smell: It smells like beer, nice, nice  Taste: Like beer of course, thick and wonderful.  Mouthfeel: Its thick and creamy, its dark and incredibe.  Overall: Its a great beer, a dark brown ale, nice head and dark as night. I love it.

A. Dark brown to black appearance with a three finger tan head that has great retention. Laces extraordinarily well.  S. Malt, oak, caramel, cherry and vanilla nose. Lacks assertiveness which dings its score.  T. Raisin, sweet cherry, oak, vanilla and caramel that finishes with a slight hop prickliness. This is a big beer that carries its alcohol very well. As others have stated, it reveals layers of flavor as it warms.  M. Creamy with low carbonation.  O. This is my second favorite DFH beer after 90 Minute. It's is nice change of pace beer to have from time-to-time.

A- Mostly black, but with subtle ruby hues. Dark tan, 1 finger head. Good lacing. Thick alcohol legs.  S- Cherries, raisins, chocolate, booze (but the good kind), caramel, something that reminds me of oats, light smoke, hoppy spice, and vanilla.  T- This is one of those that goes from good to glorious as it warms. Sweet mix of dark fruits in the very beginning. Beautiful combination of coffee, chocolate, and caramel comes next, morphing into wonderful dark roast coffee. Spice, dark chocolate, and coffee aftertaste. A nice raisin flavor shows up in your mouth a couple of minutes after swallowing.  M- Medium body. Silky with nice medium carbonation. Drying.  O- This was an awesome, awesome beer. Please drink it slow and let it warm. You won't regret it. Subtle changes with each sip, and flavors fade in out of nowhere. Beautifully crafted, balanced, and complex.

Pours virtually black except for a faint red translucence at the edges. You can't get a head on this if you try, its just too viscous.  Aroma is rich with plum, raisin, caramel....smells awesome  Tastes as expected from the aroma. Rich and viscous. Alcohol is hidden with the heavy body and dried fruit. Very slight metallic taste...maybe I got an old 4-pack. Edited after some additional aging - the metallic taste increased over time to the point that the taste is not all that pleasant.  Mouth is rich, full. You won't want to quench your thirst with this on a hot day. This is dessert after a big hearty meal.  Awesome big heavy sweet brown ale. But the metallic taste detracts.

awesome chocolate milk head, medium consistency and creamy! on top of a very dark brown liquid which smells very sweet and malty. very high alcohol aroma.... taste is definitely like a stout or a porter.... brown ale? how? sweet and malty, as the others before me noted. some vanilla. some coffee(?). very high abv but not totally obvious in the taste. overall, I've had this before but not reviewed it. I remember liking it. I actually think it's a decent brew and easy to drink considering the abv.

Don't know what to make of this beer to tell you the truth,it's different that's for sure.they call it a brown ale but it pours black like a porter or stout,smells more of the same.in order to get any head you gotta pour this thing like a fountain,it laces nice but it's not a brown ale and that's what the label says it is.in the beginning it taste pretty good some vanilla and coco,a little sweet and very rich,once again it taste like a porter and not a brown ale.to be honest this beer begins to fringe on wine and not beer IMO.  All in all this one was like other dogfish brews not very good.wtf is up with these guys do they think their shit is like nectar of the gods or what,I mean all there beer is way overpriced and not that great.i have yet to have a world class beer from them yet.i won't be buying this again and maybe not any dogfish head period.

Consumed: 2/18/14 12oz bottle Appearance: Aggro pour into a pint snifter gives a 2.5 finger head of café latte head that lasts due to my pour. Thick lacing contrasts a very dark, but slightly red colored beer. Amazing legs.  Aroma: alcohol, cherries (dried), vanilla, coffee, smokey hardwood- almost like a beach cookout smelled from waaayyy down the beach.  Flavor: light smoke, alcohol, coffee, roasted malts. Slight hoppy-ness, vanilla, toffee?, hint of chocolate, dark dried fruits. Sweetness at first then bittering, then super complex, followed by alcohol warming.  Mouthfeel: Full- bodied, alcohol warming as it goes down (too easily). Feels even on the tongue.  Opinion: I really don’t know how to rate beer very well yet, but this beer is extraordinary. I’ll definitely give it another go when the time is right. Very easy to drink considering the ABV and thickness.

Dogfish Head Palo Santo Marron  Enjoyed on tap at Champps Americana Brookfield, WI. This was served in a 12 oz stemmed tulip. Served chilled...  A) This is dark... A dark brown... Damn near stout territory. A nice tan head, about a fingers worth. Nice retention and some lacing too.  S) Sweet and malty... A bit of roast with a fair amount of dark fruit. Milky, like a hint of milk chocolate, and smokey, with vanilla, and a little spice.  T) Very flavorful... Unlike any brown ale I've had the opportunity to try. It's near the nose. Sweet, smokey, a fair amount of wood. The alcohol is so well hidden.  M) Full bodied with mild carbonation. This is fairly thick... Goes down smooth. Nice aftertaste too.  O) Glad to give this beer a try. Remarkably flavorful with a nice full body. The ABV is well hidden. Very tasty.... Glad to recommend this beer,

This is my second tasting of Palo Santo Marron. My first was last August. It's pretty expensive here, so I waited patiently and tried again. I was NOT disappointed.  Each sip caused me to lean back in my chair and smack my lips and enjoy the fruity aftertaste. There isn't a hint of bitterness anywhere in the tasting and there is such a pleasant fruit smell and clean, smooth taste that I don't feel the need to chase it with chips, but it sure does go well with Pringles.  I probably poured it wrong, but I barely got any head... just 1/8" but it surely didn't dampen the taste.  I'll re-review it if I get a different pour another time. This is my favorite beer.

Bottle Poured into a Stone Snifter. Bottled date - 2/4/14  Very nice dark brown almost black appearence. Has look and body of a stout almost. Smell is awesome. Notes of caramel, vanilla, molasses, some nuts. Taste is quite sweet and delicious. Tons of caramel, vanilla and sweet malt with some chocolate. Just plain awesome.  I will be aging a few more of these. Can't wait to see what some time does for them.

To begin, for me alone, this was a true spectacle of perfection. The beer poured a very dark-brown color almost pitch-black, opaque; into a Smuttynose snifter glass.  No light getting through this dark, thick beer. One finger thick light-brown/ mocha colored head formed then dissipated with streaks of lacing along the edges of the glass.  The body of this brew is almost like that of a stout. Smells of some chocolate, molasses, some sweet dark fruits, roasted malts, nuts, possibly caramel, and of course of vanilla.  Truly divine flavor and taste of coffee, chocolate, caramel, molasses, toffee, wood, dried fruits and vanilla.  Slick, smooth, mouth feel may be quite possibly amazing amongst the subtle carbonation. Warming heat on the back end of the palate when finishing from the 12% ABV that is mostly hidden until the glass is empty.  Overall, this was an awesome concoction that I cannot wait to savor again! Stored a couple away for next time. Highly recommended!!!  6/21/2014 Edit: Just cracked opened this beer again with a brewed on date of 6/19/13. One year later and it's still a wonderful looking dark brew with a nice foamy head. Smells as wonderful as I remember with the vanilla seeming to be more pronounced. The flavor is still so unique with an emphasis on the molasses and the aged wood tones. Very smooth and oh so fantastic. If you can age one, do it!  4/24/15 Savoring a bottle from 12/25/14 and it is probably what I would call my go to everyday beer; if I could drink it everyday. The aroma is quite enticing; more than what I can remember and that flavor is oh so awesome!

Pours like a stout, dark brown with a 0.25" head that fades quickly. Aroma is complex, sweet and fruity with a molasses like note, but not as sweet. Can definitely detect the wood notes and the alcohol. Taste also reveals the 12% alcohol, but it blends with the fruity complexity. Mouthfeel is rich with a nice finish. One of my favorites.

12oz bottle, bottled 1/2014. Poured into a Surly goblet today, 3/4/2014. Also drank a 9/2012.. which was subsequently drainpoured. Comments to come in the Overall section of the review.  App- Dark brown body, one finger mocha head with good retention. Not much lacing. Looks thick and viscous.  Smell- Overpowering alcohol, but still get sweet caramel, toffee, very nutty, lots of oak. Alcohol is very strong here and in my opinion, a big detractor.  Flavour- Very, very sweet. Caramel, nuttiness, lots of oak. And a lot of alcohol. Not very complex, and I find this to be borderline undrinkable due to the sweetness and the solvent-nature of the alcohol.  Mouthfeel- Thick bodied, syrupy, viscous. Pretty much on point for what I'd expect from an Imperial Brown Ale.  Overall- I did not like this beer that much. It's drinkable, but not by much. The sweetness and the high solvent alcohol character on this beer is too overwhelming for me. The 9/2012 bottle was even more disgusting as it was just even more overwhelmingly sweet without any alcohol presence to cut the sweetness. The price point is also not helping this beer any.

This beer is a constant in my fridge. It's so good that I enjoy introducing it to as many friends as possible. This is perfect with dessert or while relaxing on the couch at the end of the night. Rich flavor with pleasant mouthfeel for such a high alcohol ale.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle. Pours thick, and very dark with minimal caramel colored head. Smell is very nice, very roasty, a lot of bourbon notes (with no bourbon in the beer) some cloves. Taste is really nice as well. Right in line with the aromas. Alcohol is hidden well despite the very high ABV. Mouthfeel is slippery and slightly viscous. Nice. Overall, very much enjoyed this Brown Ale.

I think that this is one of the best beers made year round. The color is a super dark brown with a nice coffee colored head that lingers after you pour. The smell of the wood and the alcohol are easy to find and then come forward at the first sip. In the middle and end you get all the little nuances. The earthy tones, mostly nuttiness, from the brown ale compliments the overwhelming wood flavor. It's a filling beer that coats your mouth from the first sip. I absolutely love this beer and would recommend it to anyone within earshot.

Dogfish Head Palo Santo Marron is nearly black, with a dense, dark-brown head, with substantial lacing. It has a mild malty smell that belies its overwhelmingly chocolatey (in a good way - deep, tasty dark chocolate not cloyingly sweet or artificial) flavor. The intense flavour nearly covers the substantial 12% abv despite minimal hoppiness, but it's still easy to tell that this isn't a beer to slam, or even an every-day sipping beer. There is no pretending that this is something light. The density is slightly offset by a pleasant carbonation.  Calls itself a brown ale but it's far heavier than anything else I've had in the genre, probably closer to an imperial stout.  A unique and delicious beer, I strongly recommend Palo Santo Marron.

A - Dark dark brown...meaning black. Basically like a stout. Dark head as well.  S - Sweet caramel.  T - Bitter roasted caramel with darkly sweet vanilla. Can't really believe this is a "brown ale" but when a brown ale is aged this is what happens. Very similar to an Imperial Stout.  M - Can definitely taste the alcohol but it's a pleasant sensation. The flavors and rich smoothness of the body mask it in an enticing manner. Complex to say the least.  O - Really good and hits the spot for the complex stout and aged stout area even though this is a "brown ale". Price point is a bit steep but that's Dogfish head.

This beer pours like an imperial stout, it's so dark even the head is tinged brown.  The smell is fantstic. There's alot going on there, it's earthy and fruity, smells sweet like molasses. Some spice in there too like cinnamon or clove, maybe some anise and chocolate.  The taste is much like the nose, very complex, you get some of that molasses sweetness off the bat followed by a touch of bitterness and spice. I get almost none of the 12% abv, it's very well masked, just a slight warming sensation as it goes down. Would not have guessed blind that this beer was as strong as it is.  Very nice complex beer from Dogfish. I'm very rarely disappointed by them and often surprised by the variety of flavors packed into their beer. Nice job.

I've never had a beer in which i was so confident giving a 5 in any category, but the smell of this beer is out of this world. It pours like a black daemon with very little lacing. As mentioned before the smell is perfect. You can smell the rich oaked flavor that makes you feel like your out in a majestic wild forest. It tastes almost as good as it smells.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Surly Darkness chalice.  Appearance: Pours an oily black with a moderate amount of bubbles. About one finger of deep tan head that slowly fades into a thin creamy layer. Leaves a decent amount of lacing.  Smell: A rich and sweet malt forward aroma with big hints of dark fruit and wood. Big barrel presence with hints of wood, vanilla, and oak. Roasted malts with hints of sweet caramel, toffee, chocolate, biscuit, coffee, grains, smoke, and yeast. Big presence of dark fruit with hints of raisin, fig, prune, cherry, and plum. Sweet scent of brown sugar and syrup. Also some anise and cinnamon like spice. Hops are very light. A very good aroma.  Taste: Like it smells, a rich, sweet, and woody malt driven taste with big notes of dark fruit and caramel. Woody taste from the barrel along with some notes of vanilla and oak. Roasted malts with notes of sweet caramel, biscuit, grains, coffee, toffee, toasted bread, yeast, and slight smoke. Big taste of dark fruits with notes of fig, raisin, cherry, prune, and plum. Spice notes of anise and slight cinnamon. Sweet taste of brown sugar and some syrupy molasses. Not much hop presence. A really interesting and good taste.  Mouthfeel: Full bodied with a moderate amount of carbonation. Rich, chewy, creamy, and somewhat syrupy. Alcohol heat is pretty smooth considering the 12% ABV.  Overall: A really good and unique twist on an imperial Brown Ale. Rich and strong but still nicely creamy and smooth. Lots of good dark fruit flavor.

A - This brew pours a deep brown, very close to black with about a finger of dark tan head  S - Dark fruits and sweet malts. A slight wood nose which balances the malt aroma. Slight hop bitterness lingers on the nose.  T - Exactly like the smell, you get a lot of dark fruits. Not as much as a Quad, but a good presence. The taste is balanced well with a smooth dryness coming from what I assume is the "holy wood" in which it is fermented in.  M - Nice and creamy with a bit of carbonation at the tip of the tongue. The taste lingers nicely and changes in complexity as it sits on the tongue.  O - All I can say is WOW! This beer is a must try. DFH really nailed it here with Palo Santo Marron. I really like the complexity, it takes you on a journey of flavor and creates a true drinking experience.

A - Surprised how thick this pours considering it is a brown ale and aged. A very dark coffee like brown with a thin tan foam head that quickly dissipated leaving a thin cap and lacing around the edges.  S - Aroma is very nice with sweet malt, wood, caramel, toffee, vanilla and syrup.  T - This beer really tastes great, but not like a brown ale would. Heavy malts and syrup with caramel, vanilla and wood mixed in. I don't notice much bitterness, but it isn't overly sweet. The booze is very well hidden.  M - Low carbonation as expected from the aging. Thick and chewy mouth feel from this unlike most brow ales which are much more thin.  O - Great beer than I really enjoyed. I'll have to get a hold of more some day. Do yourself a favor and pick some of this up because it is very tasty. Thanks to deadonhisfeet for sending to me.

Hell yeah! Had on draft first time. Review is the bottles it forced me to purchase. Had a year old bottle. The brown ale label is debatable. I get a little of that style, but it is it's own beast. Honestly it tastes similar in many ways to a Barleywine, but kind of comes across as a strong, dark Belgian and stout too. Very unique. Has a booziness to it, but it is 12%. Smell is awesome. I get molasses, fruit/fig, brandy/wine, some other shit I can't even begin to describe so I'll go with "complex mo fo". Taste follows all that jive. Some chocolate and nutty flavor for sure a touch of coffee, and a cherry wood like note. Don't even know what the hell kind of wood Palo Santo is but I may have to build a bourbon cabinet out of it. A very unique and fantastic beer. May not be for everyone, but owe it to yourself to try it. I think it is better with some age on it. Drinks much hotter fresh.

Vintage:2013 Appearance: Black; Minimal head; Zero Lace Smell: Black Cherry cough syrup; Dark Chocolate; Vanilla; Coffee Taste: Blac Cherry; vanilla; Roasty malts; big alch Mouth-feel: Lightish body; oily; Overall: Unique, complex, really good. LIke sitting under a tree somewhere you can see the stars.

WOWOWOW!! This was AWESOME!! smelled a little roast on this one, chocolate, and some wood. It tasted very similar to bourbon county. It just takes a little bit on the tongue to enjoy the complexity of this beer. You get some awesome dark fruits, a ton of milk chocolate, some bourbon, vanilla, and toffee. You can see how the wood they used adds a great amount of soft sweetness. The flavors goes deep down into your taste buds. I am confused as to why this isn't rated a 100 on here, but it is definitely an easy 10 beers for me. WORLD CLASS BEER. I will cellar this and see how much better it gets a few years down the road.

Appearance Very dark brown with a tan mocha head, poured from tap into a snifter glass. Smell Smells sweet, caramel, mocha and vanilla notes come through. Smells wonderful and complex Taste Mmmhh Smokey, malt, alcohol forward but it’s a good thing. Its medium-thick bodied and each sip is a blast of flavor that I really enjoyed Overall This beer was fantastic, intriguing and I couldn’t get enough. They hit a home run with this one in my opinion. I would definitely like to try it again, perhaps from a bottle and see if my thoughts differ.  -BeerandWhiskeyHQ.com

Very dark brown pour with tan foam and specks. Smell has that wonderfully expressive wood with raisin, vanilla, bread pudding, and booze. Taste has those same great flavors, with some char, toffee and slight molasses, but the wood dominates to the point of slightly muting some of the other flavors. Feel is woody, thick, and is sneaky dry.

From earlier tasting/ notes: Dug it out of the fridge, been there at least a year and a half maybe 2+ years. Cant even find a bottle date. Now is a good time. Looks rich and oily deep brown/ virtually black. Low head, nice lacing. Has a rummy sweet smell, raisin abounds. Other dark fruit seems to lurk, even cinnamon. Barely a hint of the 12% alc. otherwise. Mysterious. Tastes like an oaky burn, with a creamy mouthfeel and a cognac after-effect. The dark fruit is in the upfront taste. A big type of brown ale, a fine after-dinner drink to sip. Not my favorite DFH beer, as "oak-age" isn't my favorite beer attribute. But this is still unique as far as the taste and style. Some very nice dark wood-like and boozy smoke flavors come through as this warms. Intriguing. Won't seek regularly, but will definitely revisit.

A- Dark as midnight. Sweet molasses. Light does not penetrate. A creamy dark tan head leaves considerable lacing.  S- Sweet dark woody malts. Black licorice. Charcoal.  T- Dark sweet and smoke. Vanilla. A complex sweet fruity malt and bitter hop middle roll on strong and long, finally giving in to a warm and sweet finish with plenty of alcohol.  M- A little chewy. Medium-heavy bodied with a zing in the finish.  O- This is an interesting take on a brown ale. There is an incredible amount of complexity going on here. A brown ale on steroids and PED's. It takes a minute to process the flavor blast and come to grip with what you are tasting. This is truly what I have come to expect from Dogfish Head. Not ordinary by any means.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint snifter glass. Pours a very, very dark brown, almost black, but not quite. Interesting and beautiful. A perfectly smooth and mildly frothy tan head which quickly goes away, looks just like an espresso topper.  Sweet smelling with plenty of coffeelike caramel notes. Slightly fruity with some raisins and figs thrown in. Alcohol and fusels join the party as well.  Wow. Sweet and alcoholic. Some smoke and hoppiness but the alcohol is a bit overwhelming. A sweet, alcoholic mess. Creamy on the tongue saves this beer a little bit.  I was impressed with the first two categories but the rest was downhill. I keep trying these beers from DFH and am continually let down. Perhaps, I have learned my lesson. At $16 for a 4-pack, I will not be buying this one again.

12 oz from 4 pack at F McD's.  A - Dark, black as night, with some brown and ruby overtones. No head, pours to a thin lace.  S - Vanilla, smoke, burnt wood, roasted nuts  T - Vanilla, coffee, hints of dark fruit. Tinge of alcohol, which you would think would be most present at 12%. Malt forward, with a small semblance of english? style hops on the finish. Picking up some caramel and chocolate as it warms  M - Low carbonation, on the syrupy sticky side  O - A porter in a brown ale's clothing. And it's aged in huge handmade wooden vessels. With it's price (and not often availability), it's not an every day drinker, more of a once or twice a year treat. Recommended.

A: Dark brown with a mocha head.  S: Malty with a slight hint of nuttiness and a touch of light and dark fruits in the nose.  T: Big malty flavor. No evidence of the very high alcohol, A touch of caramel and vanilla.  M: Full bodied and smooth.  O: Definitely the best brown ale I've ever had, if you can call it that, but even then, that's not saying much. The brown ale isn't very compelling to me. This is. Definitely worth a try.

I actually bought this beer not really reading the label thinking it was the 90min IPA. I have to say I am so glad that I made this mistake. This beer hit you right in the mouth as soon as you open it. It has a hint of vanilla and almost a coffee stout aroma. The first sip is almost like a porter with a blast of hops. Its mild carbonation makes it very drinkable for a 12% beer. It has a unique aftertaste that is hard to describe other than that of a oatmeal porter with a hop mix. Overall a great beer that needs to be tried.

As much as I did not want to like this beer at first blush for it's resemble to "winey" products, this is truly a masterpiece. It has dark strong notes, bold up front maltiness, yet with a strong hoppy ipa sort of feel too. This beer is unique and exceptional. Truly a connoisseur beer.

Poured into a tulip glass from a 12 oz bottle.  Pours pitch black and almost syrupy. Almost no head and no lacing on the glass.  Great smoky and sweet malty aroma. Caramel and vanilla notes.  For being 12%, this is very smooth and probably a little too drinkable.  Slight alcohol finish but overall this is a very well-rounded beer.

bought a 4 pack for 16 bucks from the local store and thought it would be phenominal just based on the price... great thinking that was, lol I don't know where that logic came from. cool concept, and history behind the beer I found after I googled it. not bad overall, but DEFINITELY NOT WORTH MORE THAN 10 BUCKS FOR A 4 PACK.

A: Incredibly dark, almost black, beer. With a small, long-lasting tan head.  S: Darkly roasted malts, very sweet, with a smell that is both oaky and boozy. No surprise there, given the 12% ABV. Rich, deep and complex, and I would almost swear that it was smoked.  T: Wow. This beer sure packs a wallop of flavor. chocolate malts, black coffee and caramel give way to a rich, smoked wood flavor. The flavor the the alcohol suffuses the entire tasting experience, from beginning to end.  M; Lighter than the looks might indicate, with a decent amount of carbonation to lighten it further.  O: Really a unique tasting beer. Almost (but not quite) a smoked porter. The wood adds a element of complexity that is really enjoyable. I wouldn't drink it every day, but am glad that I tried it.

12oz. bottle, Teku glass. Bottled on 9/16/2012 (I think, not 100% clear)  A: Beautiful dark walnut-going-on-ebony beer. ¾” dense, deep tan dead. Stream shows some auburn highlights, but once in the glass, it’s all pretty deep and mysterious.  S: Molasses, Cuban coffee. Faint spices, dried figs, woodsy aromas – something resembling cedar.  T: Sticky roasted, caramelized pecan. Hints of nutmeg, ginger snap. Very modest leathery tannin. Nice, pretty complex, different.  M: Sticky, heavy. Perhaps not 12% heavy, but a slow sipper for sure.  O: A very interesting and impressive beer. The wood comes through, but the base beer seems very well crafted and unique. A pleasant big, cold weather beer that is a really cool change of pace from stout/porter/barrel aged what-not. Really good.

This beer starts sweet, but ends bitter. It does make me think of semi-dry wine. It has a bit of an alcohol bite...similar to bourbon barrel beers. It has a beautiful, rich, dark color. The mouthfeel is great. Would probably drink it again, but won't buy it myself.

Poured into snifter  A-Jet black, 1/2 inch mocha head, some retention, lacing slowly slides down the inside of glass  S-roasty chocolate, mild wood, slight vanilla, some caramel  T-lots of chocolate upfront, slight alcohol burn on the back end, mild caramel and vanilla, evidence of wood is slight, mild anise  M-thick body, creamy and slick, feels and drinks like an imperial stout  O-nice oil thick big bodied beer with lots of flavor. Slight alcohol burn but not overpowering especially for the ABV

12 oz bottle at fridge temp poured into a snifter. Bottled on 11/4/13 (2 months old)  Pours out very imperial stout like, opaque black, the slightest bit of ruby brown color on the very bottom of the glass. Light mocha colored head with decent retention. Spotty lacing and just a bit of alcohol legs.  Slight bit of booze in the aroma, sweet brown sugary, caramel slight earthy woodiness, a bit of anise and dark fruits, some fruity esters.  The front is sweet sugary caramel, brown sugar. The backend is bitter roasted malt with just a hint of a lingering spice. Throughout there is anise like dark fruits, raisin, milk chocolate.  Really nice creamy, almost milky, velvety big body. Carbonation feels just about right.  A really nice and unique beer. I'm not sure if what I'm tasting is from the wood or malt, but really tasty nonetheless.

Appearance: Pours smoothly. Very dark with garnet where the light manages to get through. Enticing mocha colored head.  Smell: Very nice, beautiful roasted malt and a bit of wood.  Taste: Chocolate into caramel with coffee undertone throughout. The wood aroma lingers pleasantly. Malty as all get out!  Mouthfeel: Big and beautiful. Velvety with just enough carbonation.  Overall: I really enjoyed this beer. It's got a lot of character, and it really stands out as one of my favorites.

Pours black with a coffee colored head of small stature. Hardly any lacing, just some specks of foam. Aroma features some varied notes, including vanilla, cocoa, brown sugar, and a little bit of alcohol.  Flavor is much more stout-like as opposed to a brown ale. Roasted malt astringency balances out some prodigious malty sweetness. A little bit of herbal hoppiness on the finish. Smooth, woody notes of vanilla. There's no doubt that this has been woo-aged. Only a relatively small amount of booziness on the finish, less than you'd expect in a 12% beer. Very smooth in texture with a soft carbonation, a great match for the flavors at play.  More of an "American strong ale," as the Brown Ale classification is quite deceiving. This is a strong, flavorful, well-crafted beer with immense flavor. One of DFH's top offerings.

Pours a hugely rich, deep brown, bordering on solid black. Beautiful color -- easily the best part of the beer. Couldn't get much of a scent, though maybe it's the lingering overload of Christmas smells.  Taste is a tough one to pin down. It's complex. Strong high gravity alcohol definitely hits in the mid and aftertaste. It feels syrupy sticky, though I'm not sure I would call this beer sweet? Almost a hit of that Liquid Smoke you use to fake barbecue. I don't like it.  I had trouble finishing a bottle.

Picked up a four pack of this for my birthday. Poured black with a slim mocha head into a Chimay goblet, and looks completely frigging awesome. Nose is dark fruit, super-malt, and boozy. The bottle indicates there should be some vanilla and caramel notes. I get the caramel, not picking up on the vanilla, but definitely some dank wood. Flavor is like liquefied raisin, and boy is this thick. So good, and the vanilla really comes through in the flavor (maybe as it's warming), as does the wood, giving it real winelike character. The mouthfeel as I said is thick, alcohol level is up there with a wine and gives a similarly tongue-numbing sensation, and low carbonation. Overall, completely badass. Now going to chase this with something a bit lighter. I honestly can't see drinking more than one of these at a sitting, two tops. Awesome, awesome beer.

p-half a finger head that dissipates quickly  a-black with a mocha head. looks more like a stout  s-not as much as expected. main aroma is sweet caramel and brown sugar. Faint hint of booziness.  t-same as the nose at least first. so sweet caramel at the front, but on the back that palo santo wood comes through to provide some bitter balance to the sweetness. However, the sweetness overpowers the bitterness making this a bit unbalanced.  m-thick and smooth  o-A bit too sweet for me and it seems to be more a stout than a brown ale. This beer could benefit from a more roasty malt or some kind of bitterness to balance the sweetness. A plus for this beer is that at 12% abv there is a low alcohol presence, which makes for an easy drinking sipper. (76/100)

Bottled 11/22/11  Pours deep dark brown, almost black but not quite. Thin reddish brown head.  Smell is coffee, vanilla, burnt wood, and alcohol  Taste is coffee and some vanilla as well. maybe a little bit of semi sweet chocolate but barely. Also picking up some butterscotch notes as well. First sip or two the alcohol presence hits but the other flavors overtake and mellow it out some further into the glass and some caramel taste makes itself known.  Feel is sticky sweet and pretty well carbonated surprisingly.  This is a really complex beer. Drinks like a stout for sure and a lot is going on in these 12oz. The 12% abv is there but as the multiple flavors within decide to take turns upstaging each other, the burn quickly subdues. I had one of these 2 yrs ago when I got the 4 ok and thought it was overly boozy. The age really did this one good and glad I have another left to enjoy again. DFH hit the mark with this one.

Poured from bottle into glass. Bottled on 12/5/12.  A - Incredible deep dark brown to black color: almost looks like oil coming out of the bottle and I mean that in the best way possible. A rich, full head takes its time to settle, pleasantly thick at first.  S - The smell is deceptive - it only hints at its dark complexity, but the smell is attractive and a good invitation to the taste.  T - The taste is complex: it starts out with a front of dark caramel sweetness that dissolves against a faintly more bitter front into the aftertaste. There are notes of vanilla in there, but they are subtle.  M - When tasting, the first thing I noticed was its mouthfeel - velvety smooth. Perhaps the nature of the Palo Santo wood lends some of its natural oil to the feel. I'm not sure, but it's amazing.  O - For as heavy of a beer as this is, the finish is smooth and it is enjoyable to continue sipping. I could see having two or three bottles of this back to back, no problem, providing I wasn't leaving the house for a while!

From my tasting notes: It pours black as used motor oil and looks and tastes like an Imperial Stout. The wood aging gives it a bitter but complex taste that hides the alcohol well. It had a thick and heavy mouthfeel that lets you know you are drinking something substantial while many of the flavors and aromas introduced themselves as it warmed. Not something I could drink all the time, but a dynamic and powerful beer that I thoroughly enjoyed.

Bottle 4-?-2013 about seven-eight months on it.  Appearance - Looks like a stout more than American brown. I guess it's going to be a malty beast.  Aroma - Caramel, brown sugar, subtle vanilla. Hint of grape NyQuil...  Taste - Similar to aroma. Luckily no NyQuil taste. Instead there is a bit of wood shining through.  Mouthfeel - Syrupy, medium to full bodied, low carbonation. More like a stout than brown.  Overall - Somewhat similar to Bitches Brew with no raisin or chocolate. Very tasty.
Wonderful complex heavy sweet sticky winter beer

Had this beer a few times and decided to do full review. Beautiful looking beer that has a great smell, the smell has me salivating, malty and rich. The beer is not quite as tasty as it smells, which is perfect, but is outstanding, also thick and smooth. Bonus points for the ABV which is 12% but not at all boozy. Outstanding beer that will be a regular in my fridge.

Had this on tap a year ago at Mason Lounge (Madison), and liked it much more back then.  A viscous, syrupy black pour into a tulip glass. A finger and a half of tan head forms and dissipates. An oil-on-water pattern of tiny bubbles swirls up the black surface.  I'm not getting much aroma. Very quiet. Coffee, sweet vanilla, molasses, wood. A bit of brown-ale tartness, or is that citrus hops? Ah, coming on now with the warming you get raisin and brown sugar, plus a charred umami. Still, though, this aroma is awfully tame.  Weird that it's clearly a malt bomb, but the red wine flavor is pretty confusing. Bitter-sweet burnt coffee and dark chocolate make me think initially I'm sipping an imperial stout. But then dark fruit tanginess escorts more bitterness (hops?) to the back of the mouth. Creamy mouthfeel smooths the way for a metal barrel and alcohol-fume prickle on the back of the tongue. I'm surprised not to get the wood until well into my fourth sip, but there it is.  The low-ish carbonation and slick oily viscosity make this a real sipper, especially as the abv is plainly apparent. Smooth, though. It's going down faster than expected.  Easily one of the most "interesting" experiences on the palate, but I just don't like it.

I've had this beer on several occasions and decided to review it. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a decent head that recedes to a ring with some bubbles - 4  Smells of Roast, sweetness, and wood, with a big wallop of a malt kick, like a big beer, I just know its gonna be uber flavorful.  Taste is a malt bomb with chocolate, caramel, wood, bitter cocoa, dark fruits, bittering hops somewhere in there. very tasty. Some coffee notes in there as well, but its mostly roasted barley, and a sweet tang from the yeast. Some alc burn but its well covered up.  Feel is just right, middle of the road carb and a nice thick feel to it, making it a warming and pleasing beer to sip..  Fantastic!!! One of my favorite DFH beers. Pick this up asap and try it.

A- if it's brown, it's hard to tell, this sucker looks black. Short lived dark brown head has almost no retention but still manages to leave some lacing  S-very reminiscent of their Indian brown, with hints of wood, vanilla, and caramel  T-unique. The brown ale gets subsumed by the palo santo wood. It's not bad, but it doesn't jive with the aroma. It also mellows out as the beer warms and oxidizes  M-a slight slickness adds to the fullness  O- this is a very unique beer. There is nothing really to compare it to.

A: Thick motor oil black with no head.  S: Chocolate, malt, dark fruits  T: Lots of chocolate, some booziness with a faint taste of fruity wine. Definitely getting some smoke taste as it warms up as well.  M: Thick, moderately carbonated.  O: A great beer. I don't know why it's not listed as a stout, but it most definitely is.

Pours dark brown nearly black with a fluffy tan/khaki head.  Nose is compromised of cherries, dark chocolate, figs, dates, and raisins, with some slight earthy hop aroma and wood. Took a long time to really enjoy the complexity of the aroma which by itself makes this beer something quite unique.  First sip comes across strong the 12% alcohol level rears its ugly head quite early. Its by no means uncomfortable or overpowering but it makes its presence known. From there woody, earthy hop bitterness followed by welches grape juice, fig, and dates round out the beer.  The carbonation is nice by no means dry but helps mellow out some of the sweeter flavors this beer offers. Its a medium bodied brew and is easily enjoyable after dinner or in front of a warm fire with a good book. Definitely a brew to enjoy over the course of an hour or two as it warms up the fruity notes come to fruition.  Overall a nice change of pace beer Dogfish head stays true to there out of the box brewing and created another wonderful offering for anyone looking to try something unique go grab one soon its a great beer for a cold snow day. Cheers!

Bottled in 05/2012 consumed 11/26/13. This beer fresh is very good but wouldn't say great so I layed a few down to age and must say that it's a completely different beer with some time on it. Fresh it's a little boozy and hard to get through but after a year and a half it's a smooth killer. Initial smell is straight bourbon, vanilla and cherry. Don't really get any of the alcohol that dominates when younger.  Head is a light khaki color and about 2 fingers (though may have poured too aggressive expecting a minimal head with it being a 12% abv).  First sip is glorious. Definitely taste like it was aged in bourbon barrels though I know it hasn't. You also get hints of vanilla as well. Mouthful is silky smooth. It strikes a perfect balance of sweetness and and roasty bitterness. No alcohol burn can be detected as this beer has turned almost into a fine liquor with age. Again completely different beer with a good amount of age on it. Almost reminds me of a kbs sans the coffee overtone. shocked the hell out of me that this beer got THIS good. With the age on it, this has turned into a top 10 beer all time for me. Just wow!

I couldn't stand this beer. Normally I love a strong Dogfish IPA, but this is just too much alcohol which is overbearing. Some how I need to make my way through the last two bottles, bought some blue cheese/crackers to have something equally as sharp to be able to off-set the taste a bit. Tasted to me more like a a whiskey or something.

I will say that it's big but I can't remember having a imperial porter or stout with the depth that it has. The opal color and rich, brown lacy head make an excellent presentation. On the front end you experience strong wood flavors with notes of licorice and prunes, then you go through a warm alcohol mouth feel, finishing with a carmel-like, chocolate/coffee surge from what seems to be a good amount the darker crystal, chocolate and roasted malts. Hoppiness is moderate but some drinkers could confuse the complex malt profile for hop bitterness. Its an extremely well crafted sipper. If there is a down side, it would only be the burn from a 12% ABV and waiting for that to clear to experience the depth and complexity? Worth the wait. Thanks for a unique experience Sam!

A: Deep and dark, almost purple. Nice lacing.  S: Sweet, woody, malty, and hoppy.  T: Vanilla, caramel, oak, toffee, and chocolaty.  M: Strong but smooth. Overall a rich brew.  O: A complex brown. An elegant blend of oak aged sweetness and caramel hops. Delicious. Classic.

Strong wood aroma accompanied by oak chips, alcohol and molasses. Blackish purple appearance with a fine tan foam rim. Intense flavors of balanced burnt caramel, molasses, sweet burnt sugar, oak, maple, cinnamon, dates, figs and cherries. Overall, this is incredible. Simply amazing stuff.

Heard great things about Palo Santo Marron and I am a fan of Brown Ale's so had to pick this up. I will be buying more of this beer, will be my winter staple I suspect.  Poured into Dogfish IPA glass - Wrong glass but only affected tasted at bottom of glass which made it more interesting.  A - Color of beer and light head made it look like the smoothest of browns which was confirmed after first sip.  S - Nice chocolate maple smell almost like hazlenut. Very interesting.  T - Easiest drinking brown I had have in a while, I also am a big fan of Rogues Hazelnut Brown.  F - Very smooth.

Poured from the 12 oz. bottle into an Innis & Gunn flute.  a: Black with the barest ruby clarity showing at the bottom through bright light. Finger thick tan head dissipated to even surface foam and lacing.  s: Dark malt.  t: Very smoky initial taste, then a tangy dark malt/dark fruit combo. Extremely sippable with well hidden alcohol. Very high ABV, highest I have had so far in any beer, registers on swallowing and lingers in the back of the throat. Smoky dark fruit finish and aftertaste.  m: Medium to heavy and silky smooth.  o: Everything I could have expected. Really a unique brew, looks so much like a good stout but then ends up being more.

Saying a beer is perfect is saying there is no better beer anywhere, but this is the best I've ever had. It's thick and chocolaty, with a bite after the swallow. The bite is almost spicy at first, but ultimately confounded my taste buds. The 12% ABV wastes no time and puts me into a nice state of mind. That, after all, is what beer is supposed to do.

Before opening this rich beauty called the Palo Santo Marron, I spoiled myself by reading most of the comments and reviews offered by some of you fish heads. I purchased a four pack in the neatly labeled Dogfish Head cardboard packaging. I grabbed the first one at about 42F and poured into a tall tumbler glass with my local sports insignia. I let this sit for about 5 minutes before I dove in. I had this paired with a marinara pasta and a small left over strip cut steak. The appearance is very dark and the bottom of the head is almost like a rare ebony marble that one can only conjure up within ones head. It smelled of alcohol and a tid bit of anise that was taken over almost mid-breath with caramel and vanilla extracts that would have been left overnight in a florists shop. Taste is slightly bitter and forces you to bite your tongue, but after the third or fourth sip you respect it fully. Overall I give a 4.25. A- 4.25 S- 4.0 T- 4.50 M- 3.75 OR- 4.25

I poured this beer out of a 12 ounce bottle into a tasting glass served cool  This beer is extremely dark sunlight does not come through it. The head is Thin and mocha colored  The beer smells like chocolate vanilla and somewhat of an herbal cough drop  Boozy and wine like in the front something vanilla and dark chocolate in the middle with a Fusel alcohol finish  Light carbonation and very very thick  I don't know if I would call this an American Brown ale it definitely has a more double like quality to it. Nice beer drink it slowly

Bottle on December 18th, 2012.  Poured into a pint glass, and as I poured, I got more and more aggressive with it to develop a head, but alas... no head to be seen. Perhaps the age of the brew that's doing this? No matter, not a big deal to me. Lacing is prevalent. The brew itself is a dark void of a liquid that says "no" to light.  Smell: A few things are going on. I'm getting "camp fire smoke" which is pretty awesome, as it reminds me of all those wonderful campfires throughout my life. A bit of vanilla, and maybe caramel?  Taste: That camp fire smell is still there! It taste like burnt wood, if burnt wood tasted good. (Makes sense to me!) Getting a lot of the vanilla and the malts. Bitterness is low, with quite a bit of sweetness taking over.  Feel: Although it pours like black syrup, it's very light in the mouth. Carbonation is medium, and it's amazing how well the alcohol is hidden. I feel warmth as it goes down, but nothing at all in my mouth. Interesting.  Overall: I pulled the last two of the shelf, checked the dates out of curiosity and said "why not?" Glad I did. I'll have to try it fresh some day to see if it's the same, but almost a year later, this beer held up quite nicely and offered a fairly unique experience when it comes to brown ales. A lot of things that are aged in wood barrels have just a hint of wood, this thing was covered in it. It was a great beer!

A - Pours a very deep rich dark brown, near black. Nice finger of light chocolate colored head, retention is phenomenal, lacing is great as well.  S - Tons of sweet vanilla and caramel, and sweet woody aromas. Minimal espresso notes.  T - Big flavor, tons of caramel, vanilla and oakyness. Quite a bit of alcohol burn and a little bit of a dark fruit type flavor - possibly prunes. Alcohol is quite strong with hints of espresso at the finish. Aftertaste is mostly alcohol and dark fruit type flavors.  M - Full bodied, thick thick. Almost not carbonation to speak if, incredibly thick and smooth. As much of a sipper as almost anything I've had.  O - I've always found this to be a VERY BIG beer. More so than a lot of other 10-15%ers than I've had. The alcohol is more than present but still not off-putting. Very much a sipper though.

A: Black as night. 1/4 finger tan and khaki head. The head is nice and creamy and lingers on the surface.  S: Black licorice, bakers chocolate, vanilla bean, brown sugar, rich toffee. There are undertones of coffee and lightly toasted wood.  T: Dark chocolate and toffee on the front of the tongue. It fades to a light woody taste along with licorice, coffee, and anise on the rear. Brown sugar and caramel throughout  M: Thick and viscous, this is a delicious beer for dessert or paired with a plain cheesecake or vanilla ice cream  O: Great beer, not really a normal representative of the style but representative of the Dogfish Head creativity.

Drunk from Double Bastard glass.  Got this a while back. Best guess is it would be a year or so old.  Pours pretty much black with a healthy head which retains very well. Caramel tinge at the edge.  Smell at first is indistinguishable from an imperial stout or at least a boozy regular stout. Very roasty.  As time passes, get more of those distinctive brown ale notes. Lots of fruitcake with requisite brandy, spices and glacé fruit. Very Christmas cake-esque.  Taste also reflects the Christmas-cake theme. Fortified character, Christmas-cake, roast. Perhaps a spirituous suggestion, more neutral like Brandy than a more characterful spirit.  The wood largely seems to contribute an astringency to the palate, although I wouldn't be surprised if it was responsible for the meta Brandy-flavour, and by extension the Christmas-cake quality.  Getting through the 12 oz bottle was a small challenge, but I expected nothing less from a 12% brown ale, those being neither my favourite style nor ABV level for solo consumption.  Can't say I adored it, but it is a very solid (and dry- good thing) offering on its own merit. DFH's reputation for sweetness was substantially contradicted.

Bottled 12/19/12  This big brown ale pours nearly black with a finger of dark brown head. Head quickly recedes leaving bubbles along the rim of the glass with some alcohol legs.  Lots of woody vanilla immediately, burnt marshmallow, toasted maltiness, somewhat earthy and leathery with a touch of booze in the nostrils.  Taste offers a similar abundance of vanilla and toasted sweet flavors. Flavors are remarkably smooth at this ABV and although I haven't had this beer fresh, I'll credit the age for some characteristics. Quick hit of bitterness comes in and fades into a slightly alcoholic aftertaste. Hops are restrained but provide just enough resiny presence in this malt bomb.  Nice and chewy and smooth. Very enjoyable.  Been wanting to try this and glad I finally did. Certainly a Brown to be reckoned with.

I had this beer fresh from the source at the DFH brewery with AleBorland83. We first saw the wood tanks made of imported Paraguayan wood, and then sampled the beer in DFH’s tasting room.  It poured a jet black, completely opaque. At 12% ABV, I smelt the alcohol right away followed by a burst of maple syrup. The alcohol was not overpowering, rather was there to let you know this beer is to be respected.  However upon the first sip, all I tasted was alcohol. Once used to that, I found notes of caramel and vanilla presumably from the wood tanks. Maybe even raisins somewhere in there. Roasted malts finish the flavor profile. The beer really lingered in my mouth letting me taste the earthy complexity the beer offers.  This is a big brew that DFH tackled rather uniquely. An imperial brown for beer lovers that like high gravity. Well done.

I've been drinking this beer for 4 years off and on, and while I won't call it a favorite, it's always been enjoyable.  It's worth pointing out that in all respects this beer is not a typical brown ale. At 12% and with lots of intense flavor, you won't be knocking pints back all night.  Appearance is dark, dark brown with medium lacing. Aroma is of alcohol and maybe caramelized plums. Taste is of bitter, dark chocolate and figs. The mouthfeel is not what I would call smooth but it does not detract.  I plan on aging a bottle of this year's batch.

I purchased a four pack of this beer and was initially underwhelmed by it, especially at $15. Instead of simply grinning and bearing it, I decided to sit on it and let it age a spell. Tonight, after nearly a year, I opened my second bottle, dated 9/19/12, and decanted into—appropriately—a Dogfish Head Signature Glass.  A: Inky, opaque, brown with almost no head and no lacing to speak of. This is a brown ale of brown ales.  S: Woodsy and sweet. Reminds me very much of oak but with a wonderful sweet cherry addition.  T: Vanilla and raisins at the forefront with the notes of the palo santo wood coming through more pronounced as the beer warms. The alcohol is much more hidden now that the beer has aged a good while.  M: Syrupy and warm with a nice and heavy mouthfeel.  O: Do yourself a favor, pick up a four-pack, and let it sit for a year. Wow. This beer really shines with age. Just let this one sit. Don't even bother with it fresh.

I am a HOLY CITY guy but they do not bottle. This beer is my second favorite which is saying a lot considering all of the beers I have tasted over all this time.  This beer is a must TRY.  The cons about this beer is that it's around 12 to 14 dollars for a 4 pack. But it is worth it by being so GOOD.

A solid offering, but not a beer I could enjoy more than two of in a single evening. The viscosity is immense, and flavors are bold and over powering. Bitter chocolate, anise, bacon fat and soy glaze dominate this beer. The wood is extremely prevalent, and the flavors are almost too intense. This would be a tough beer to pair with food, although a steak au poivre or charred spiced rib eye come to mind. I would recommend this beer to stout drinkers, barbeque lovers and cold nights in front of the fireplace.

A: Pours black with little-to-no head.  S: Faint hints of plum and raisins.  T: Slightly bitter at first. Then, settles into subtle, almost cola-like sweetness. Alcohol content is almost completely undetectable.  M: Very smooth and drinkable. No carbonation.  O: A solid, if not spectacular brown.

The only non-Colorado brew I brought home from a recent trip to CO. Saw it in the cooler at Wilbur's Total Beverage in Ft. Collins and couldn't resist because I'm a lover of brown beers.  Poured into an Anchor pint glass, this looks like a big ole stout - black with a brown ring of fine bubbles leaving little lace behind.  Aromas of brown sugar, birch syrup, plums, raisins, all simmering in rum sauce.  Flavors of coffee bean, rum raisin, dark chocolate, and a vanilla finish. Heavy on the booze.  Feel is slightly syrup-like but very dry due to 12% abv. Carbonation is a bit understated for my taste.  Very good overall. Could have been a big hit, but the alcohol is simply too hot. I think it would be better with the alcohol covered up a bit more. Definitely let this beer warm up for the best experience.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter  A: jet black, very thin head that dissipated quickly, some lacing remained though  S: mild coffee and malt tones. also some vanilla but not really overwhelming  T: very smooth with vanilla upfront but a very sharp aftertaste afterwards with a lot of burnt coffee tones. alcohol is very well hidden, especially for a 12% beer  M: Thick and gummy with very little carbonation  O: Excellent beer for sure. Very drinkable, would be easy to put away a few of these (which at 12% might be self-critiquing later). Well worth having

Hate to say it but I was a little disappointed with this beer. Dogfish head has brought so many fantastic offerings to the table maybe my hopes were a little too high. Here it goes. It pours nice, jet black motor oil color with a creamy caramel head thin, but stays. Taste is upfront malty, notes of vanilla, wood, and maybe chocolate? Little aftertaste. One major positive is the alcohol is masked really well, I mean I can barely taste it and most beers over 10% its pretty pronounced. Here is the issue. The beer really does need more carbonation to be a home run. I found it a tad on the flat side. Still overall though a good beer. They really could have a gem though with a few tweaks. Also it was 15 bucks for a 4 pack!!! Next time I want to share a brew with Bill Gate's Ill bring him this.

Pours an opaque deep brown black with a frothy chocolate head that lingers, eventually leaving a thick foam layer around the rim.  Vanilla, booze, oak, caramel, dark berries, chocolate, and roast malt form the initial aroma. Very complex. Toasted, nutty notes add support for the high booze content. Tar emerges as it warms.  Flavor is initially fruit forward, with vinous notes colliding with perfume and floral notes, finishing fairly dry, oaky, and a touch bitter. Dark cherry character tends to dominate, supported by chocolate, vanilla, and roast malt. Plums, prunes, and figs add complexity. Nutty, toasted malt provides a solid foundation.  Body is thick and viscous, smooth, and syrupy, with a surprisingly moderate amount of carbonation, and significant alcohol warmth.  Interesting brew. Very complex, but would prefer a little less of the perfumey and floral notes. Good dark fruit character, and not an overpowering roast character. Fairly balanced, considering...

Third beer at the Bottleworks Cellar Tasting for Seattle Beer Week. Batch 1.  Pours black with no head.  Smell is toffee, coffee, licorice, tobacco.  Taste is wood, nutty, coffee, roast.  Amazing to get two different beers in smell and taste, completely masks the 12 percent. Great beer, aged or not.

Bottle date of 10/15/12. Poured into an imperial pint glass.  A - Inky brown, much like a RIS. Moderate amount of lacing after an aggressive pour.  S - More subdued than I was expecting at 12% ABV. Probably has mellowed a bit after 10 months on the shelf. Faint smell of vanilla and wood.  T - Again, more subdued than I thought, but very tasty. A warming taste of dark fruits, peat, and most of the alcohol on the back end. Makes me forget this is "just" a brown ale.  M - Good balance of carbonation and creaminess, coming from a fan of thick imperial stouts.  O - Took a chance after spotting this in the back of the shelf, but figured this type of brew might be well served by sitting and mellowing for a while. I'm a fan of DFH in general and this did not disappoint. One of the most drinkable 12% beers I've ever had.

A - Black - quite dark for a brown ale. Thin tan head that disappeared quickly.  S - Wood, vanilla, and a slight alcohol smell.  T - A lot going on. Vanilla sweetness comes though first fading into a woodsy bourbon flavor. Slight warming from the alcohol at the very end.  M - Light carbonation with a heavy mouthfeel.  O - Very unique complex beer. If you want a different take on a brown ale this is highly recommended.

recieved as an extra in a trade last year, but this one has been sitting in the cellar since then. bottle date reads 1/5/2012. poured from a bottle into a central waters snifter  a- brown ale huh...looks like an impy stout to me. pours deep black/brown with no light sneaking through anywhere. dark khaki head rises up almost an inch then fades, surprisingly leaving not much lacing. beautiful looking beer, but at a glance looks like a big stout  s- nose is less pronounced than I would have anticipated. roasted malt, very sweet dark fruit..maybe plum or raisin, brown sugar and some faint woodiness, which i think would be fair to assume is the palo santo wood.  t- the brown ale is there initially with the malt and brown sugar and quickly fades away to more complex flavors, mostly from the wood aging. cedar type wood flavor, a bit of bittersweet chocolate, slight bittering hops - very stout-like. then after that it melds back into a heavy brown ale with some heavy malt, sugary sweetness and a bit of raisin. a very complex and flavorful beer.  m- sticky sweet but not overly thick. booze is present but not overpowering, just a nice warming character. carbonation isnt high, but just enough to keep it from being too thick and cloying. really nice.  I cant say what this beer tastes like fresh, but I imagine its a bit hot. This, which a year and a half of age on in, is really, really good. There really isnt much to compare it so style-wise, but this drinks more like an imperial stout than a brown ale. Hopefully i can get my hands on some more of this though, because its really good.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter. Bottled on 12/19/12.  Looking more like a stout, Palo Santo Marron pours a very dark brown, nearly black, with no light shining through except for some blood red highlights on the age. It's topped by a khaki head that dwindles to light bubbles on the edge. Tons of alcohol legs on the glass. This is majestic.  The nose is complex and deep: Immediately, I pick up molasses and caramel, and beneath that, roasted grain, coffee, and chocolate. Lying underneath all of this is a thick, woody, oaky smell and a slight earthy aroma like pipe tobacco. There is also a hint of sweet booze. Incredible.  PSM is incredibly layered and hard to pin down, and I say that in the best way possible. Starting with a massive, dripping sweetness of caramel, nuts, chocolate, coffee, and roasted grain, the sweetness slowly melds into the earthy flavors of the wood aging that carries into the finish where more earthy sweetness finishes strong with no noticeable alcohol flavor but a rather strong burn. What a beauty of a drink.  Predictably, the mouthfeel is heavy with low carbonation, but not flat or lifeless. Heavy alcohol burn on the finish so you know who's boss. Lingering flavors of oak, earth, and espresso.  Dang. That's all I know to say. Definitely not a “regular” drinker, but I would say this is one of the cornerstone beers for both Dogfish Head and the American craft scene.

Bottled on 4/20/10 poured into a 3F Teku  A: Beautiful deep black and completely opaque S: Dark fruits and some roasty qualities. Some coffee notes and no alcohol T: Lots of dark fruits and coffee. Much more than a fresh bottle. There is a slight alcohol warming sensation, but this would be expected. After 3 years, the alcohol taste is completely gone. M: Silky smooth and full bodied, but not as thick as a stout O: This is an amazing beer that has improved tremendously with age. I have enjoyed this beer fresh, but will have to keep cellaring them away to achieve this wonderful level of taste! Great job DFH!

I was so excited to move to my new location to find a place that had 4 different variations of Dogfish Head beer. In my book, this is one of the most coveted brewery's in the United States. This beer is no exception, the hype is spot on.  A - Dark brown/blackish - a stout type feel for a brown, but then again it is unfiltered. About 2mm of tan head lacing.  S - Wood and oak, coffee notes, hazelnut, slightly grassy. Yet, it is not picking out the specifics in the nose of this beer, it is how robust each note sits on it's own. It's like you can smell the superb balance even without tasting it.  T & M - Like I said above, balance. Its rich and a bit frothy. Slightly heavier than most browns, but not quite a stout. It has a bitterness that is quickly absorbed with the sweeter notes in the beer. Chocolate and coffee with a roasted malt character to die for. It is made so well that you cannot tell that there is 12% alcohol in it at all.  O - If you can find this beer, buy it. Don't worry about the cost because you would be missing something truly great.

Tasted at the Tap House over 15 minutes. This brew looks and tastes like a cold cafe mocha reduction. The heavy head lingered long for me, despite the short disappointments noted in other reviews. Smells of vanilla, cinammon, dark berries, and mocha. In addition to coffee tastes, there is early pepper and other spice...a bit too heavy plant-heat in the middle and end, though. And the booze puts things out of balance, especially as it warms. The aftertaste, for me, is of higher alcohols and not very enjoyable. Warm in the mouth, but thinner than expected. A fair balance of cream and buzz, but not remarkable. Overall, the appearance of this creature is the best part. It's out of balance from that point forward, even though there are some interesting elements. The expectation for more is what lowers my overall rating despite some nice components.

Pitch black color. Mocha head that leaves a film of soap bubbles around the rim of the glass. Small traces of lacing.  Oak, rich caramel, chocolate and dark fruit. Sweet but not cloying. Very flavorful and smooth. Recommended.

Smooth, oh so very smooth  A-Dark chocolate brown, almost black, had a thick creamy head that disappeared on me! S-Sweet, spicy, cinnamon T-Malty, roasted, bourbon, some fruit notes and definite coffee and cocoa flavors M-Silky smooth, thick and rich, it almost coats the tongue, wonderful! O-Great beer, it was very satisfying and rich, I highly recommend. Share with a friend, because the alcohol will hit pretty hard.

Pours black. No head but a thin ring and some loose bubbles floating on top. Wisps and waves of light film. The head comes up upon a tilt of the glass and leaves beautiful legs and quickly disappearing faint lace. Pretty. Nose is roasted coffee, and bitter chocolate with a coldness right out of the fridge. A little grass on top. The roasted coffee is strong and deep. Then a woody aroma that is pure wood. Smells soft and bends around the nose, very supple. Roasted malt, caramel but brown sugar. Not sugary, sugar. So authentic. There's some nutty accents and a tiny bit of vanilla that smells very fresh. A bit of alcohol on the nose and a light grass. The nose continues to deepen and evolve. The coffee and the chocolate marry one another and become entwined in sweet harmony. The one is never without the other in the drink. The chocolate sweetens and the malt deepens. A bit of cherry develops and it compliments the wood and earthiness. The taste is unexpected. Your first taste after smelling the coldness right from the fridge is a warming sweet brown bread. There's sugar, and sweet creamy chocolate. The roasted coffee glides over the palate as easily as your morning cup. The vanilla excites the richness of both the coffee and the chocolate and the malt is smooth and mellow. The wood notes translate into the drink and lend to the overall freshness. The hops stay grass like. The tiny bit of alcohol is simply warming in the drink and pokes it's head out only on the finish where you meet those cherry notes one more time. Finishes dry.  This a beer that continues to develop in the glass and in the drink. It's smooth and yet it enlivens the palate and the senses. It grows on you and you like it more and more as you drink. The flavors are deep and perfected. The malt in this is superlative. It flows smoothly as the flavors become unbounded and always near at hand.

poured into a frozen tumbler and achieved a nice creamy head with lacings on the side as I drank it down Color was a dark chocolate. Smelled like a light stout and tasted very sweet as you would expect from the high ABV.  Carbonation was sufficient without being too filling.  Worth keeping in inventory for your next cigar

12oz bottle into a snifter Bottled on: 12/18/12  A: Pours a very very dark brown, essentially black except when held to light, with 1 fingers width of dark mocha colored head. Head dissipates down fairly quickly, and leaves only a few spots of lacing.  S: Dark fruits, caramel, fusel alcohol, vanilla, cinnamon, wood barrel, cherry, chocolate. This is absurdly complex for the style, and smells delicious.  T: Roasted malts, dark fruits, semi-sweet cocoa, and black coffee. There are some bourbon notes, I guess from the Palo Santo wood, with vanilla, wood, and bourbony-alcohol. This drinks like a barrel aged stout, no doubt about it. Very good though.
