Poured into a small snifter. Not sure of the vintage. Dark black color with dark brown highlights. Small one finger head that is light cocoa colored and thin in appearance. Head dissipates rather quickly and leaves no lace.  Smell is light cocoa, some virgin wood, tobacco, and some dark fruit and a bit of alcohol. Kind of smells like a Cabernet. Interesting but I think I like it.  Taste is dark roasted malts, chocolate, fig, wood, and some rather strong alcohol. Quite nice.  Mouth is medium with carbonation on the light side. Body is medium as well and the finish is average long and on the wet side.  I must say this is a very interesting tasting beer. It has a lot of the same tastes that other barrel aged beers have but this one has it's own little twist. It is so much like a wine in taste and smell but it does still keep it's beer profile. Just a very interesting twist on a beer and something I think you should seek out and try for yourself.

Poured from am12 oz. bottle into a tulip glass. Poured like motor oil, thick and black with a generous tan head.  Smell is all there. Caramel, molasses, vanilla, wood, alcohol.  Taste is well rounded across the pallet. Bubblegum, molasses, wood, delicious. Alcohol burn at the end, but well disguised for a 12% beer.  Mouthfeel is very thick and substantial with perfect carbonation.  Overall a great offering from Dogfish. Filling, well rounded, delicious.

Big pour. Huge, large bubble head.  Big nose. Sweet, malt-balls, dark-roasted coffee, dark fruits, honeyed and roasted. Beautiful.  Big ass, like an RIS. Heard that before, I'm sure. Brown still prevails. Brown sugar and root beer candy. Big-ass malts. Black malts. Licorice. Chalky malt, whoppers. Dark fruits. Big wood. Slightly tart and a hint of metal. Creamy. Hearty. Oatmealy. Booze is hidden well. Good thing it's a tad filling, because this thing, at 12%, could get out of hand.

A - Dark for a brown ale, almost porter-like. Midnight black with a light khaki head. Low retention and moderate lace.  S - Woody cranberry booze, peach, and dark caramel malt.  T - Loaded for a brown ale; drinks like a boozy porter. Complex profile of burnt coffee, bright tangy woody, vanilla, caramel, cranberries, and hot booze.  M - Nice medium body. Low carbonation.  O - The alcohol lets you know it's there, but you still might not think it's 12% abv.

Palo Santo Marron pours dark with a deep red tint. This beer smells of red wine, cedar, and a hint of cherry. Subsequent whiffs revealed a strongish alcohol presence as well. I looked away, smelled it, and thought I was drinking whiskey. It tastes wonderful: full-bodied and complex. So many flavors it was hard to pinpoint them, but not in an annoying way. Sugar, cedar, oak, red wine, vanilla, caramel, and of course, alcohol. Yum.  Overall: a very very nice beer. I liked it more than I anticipated; Dogfish really is one of the most consistent breweries in the US.

Started by pouring a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass. Mmm, what a beautiful shade of dark, deep black-brown this beer is. A half finger of thick, tan head lingers for quite a while.  The smell is of bitter, but smooth high-cocoa dark chocolate. A nice vanilla presence -- and wood, dense yet subtle.  The taste has a nice, dark malt backdrop, over which dangles a harmonious blend of alcohol heat, vanilla, and palo santo wood. The heat and the wood work together, enhancing and sharpening the beer, while not becoming too overpowering. The mouthfeel is creamy, smooth, and neither too thick, nor too thin. The aftertaste leaves the dry, crisp taste of wood on your tongue.  Definitely the best I have tasted from DFH so far (in my opinion).

Poured into a pint.  A - Rich, almost ruby-infused, black hue with a finger and a half mocha head. This is the deepest colored brown I have ever seen, granted it is also the biggest ABV. Poor retention.  S - Sweet chocolate, light espresso, nice vanilla notes,earthy malts and a minimal alcohol scent. Impressive.  T - The pinnacle of the brew. Chewy malts begin the intense experience with all the flavors of the nose to follow. Easily can detect the wood this brew was aged upon. Warm throughout but very subtle for a beer as gigantic as this one.  M - Full-medium body, medium carbonation and a fine progression. I cannot identify any part of this beer that could use improvement.  O - Another impressive beer that I hope to age in the future to see how the complexity deals with time. All factors accounted for... this beer is brilliant.

poured a deep brown almost black, motor oil sludgyness, a finger of tan head which quickly dissipated. nice retention. smells of cocoa, nuts, dates, raisins. the taste is surprisingly subtle - i was expecting a heavy on the booze beer, but i'm getting mainly sweet notes of molasses, chocolate, pecans. medium - full body (weird for a brown ale!), nicely carbonated, nice warmth from the abv.  this is a very heavy beer and within a few sips you start feeling it. a wonderful sweet treat, but you have pace yourself not to drink it too fast since it's so sweet and delicious!

Poured a 12oz bottle into the DFH signature glass.  Appearance: Opaque blackness with a very small light brown head.  Aroma: For a big beer the smell is very clean. I get the vanilla and some faint dried fruits. Also a smoke-like hint of the palo santo wood. Earthy. Real nice.  Taste: For a dark beer this is nicely hopped. The bright character of the hops sits at the top of your palate as the malty undertones and alcohol ride below it. The aftertaste remains bright with a nice woody quality and a warmth from the alcohol. I'd say the 12% abv isn't completely hidden but it adds a nice flavor almost like a liqueur. The more you drink the more roasted malt profiles come out. Dark chocolate and caramel. A zingy coffee-like bitterness lingers for a while. Definite Imperial Stout qualities.  Mouthfeel: Super smooth and above average drinkability, especially given the style. Great level of carbonation. There's no question that this is a full bodied beer, it just drinks like something smaller.  Final Thoughts: I was really lucky to get my hands on this one as we don't get DFH in MN. The signature glass was also well worth the purchase for enjoying this brew. Highly recommend this one.

Appearance - very dark mahogany, a thin layer of mocha ends up a thin collar before long, but does have a good field of dotted lace on the glass.  Aroma - Hershey's syrup with hints of espresso. Hints of caramel; and vanilla as it warms.  Taste - roasty grain, some raisiny, chocolatey sweetness. Nice coffee notes in support. Bittersweet, warm aftertaste and finish.  Mouthfeel - smooth with moderate carbonation. Slightly heavy, feels great.  Drinkability - a super sipper! Great fresh or aged, this is a DFH winner.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip. Upon pour, there is hardly any head whatsoever, except for some brown fizz. This is, by far, the darkest brown ale I have ever experienced. Thick and viscous, nearly black, with great retention and lacing.  The smell gives off a bit of fruit and cedar, and some tobacco. A little bit of caramel as well - just a bit.  The taste is certainly rich - raisin, sugar, date, and a light sourness that I cannot put my finger on to finish. A very complex beer nonetheless. This is one hell of a full-bodied beer, and the twelve percent alcohol content is well-concealed.  Overall, this is the best brown I have ever tasted - it just seems to have more... well, brown-ness to it than any other brown I've had, although I haven't tasted too many aged browns. Certainly one of my new favorite beers.

Appearance: Extremely dark brown, bordering on black. Pours syrupy and heavy. Moderate carbonation. Some deeper reds. Head is tan and drops to a tiny wispy cap and ring. Very still.  Smell: Vanilla, toffee, deep woody notes. Almost sweet from the wood. Caramel. Roasted malts. Raw sugar. Sharp hit of alcohol. Dark cherries and plums. Some fig. Jam and slight fudge.  Taste: Alcohol soaked raisins. Some cherry, leather and tobacco leaf. Vanilla, oak, big toffee, caramel, and even molasses. Slight spicy edge to the wood. Big strong woody presence. Earthy. Almost bourbon-like characteristics. Roasted, slightly burnt. Incredibly bready. Hard edge of alcohol. Hot on the finish. Dark fruit. Raisins, dark cherries, and plums.  Mouthfeel: Moderate carbonation. Body runs close to full, but the carbonation holds it off. Dry from the alcohol. Creamy.  Overall: Fresh, it's harsh, but tasty. A year might really help this beer. In typical Dogfish Head fashion, it's aggressive, a little bit messy, and hot. It works.

Notes from 08/11/12 *12oz bottle to taster flute  A: Holds the appearance of an RIS. Super dark. More black than brown actually with a thin turbinado sugar head that slips out to a crown rather quickly. Some nice oily glass coat.  S: The aroma is forward with wood. A sort of 60/40 mix of cedar and oak. Very earthy in roast. Nutty grains, toffee, spice, and some alcohol bring up the remainder of the nose. Pretty nice and unique.  T: Taste delivers the wood as well. Again bit of a of a mix between a spicy cedar and more earthy oak. I get roasted almond and hazelnut, molasses, dark pit fruit, some umami, and brown sugar. Grain roast is deep and caramelized mixing well with some underlying vanilla and tannins. The bitterness level seems rather high bringing in an herbal hop component. There is a sharp alcohol bite with some heat on it that is a little distracting. Flavors deteriorate quite a bit after mid-palate. This definitely drinks more like a RIS or Old Ale.  M: Moderate viscosity and a somewhat heavier body this brown ale maintains a smooth creamy texture with a touch of froth. Even carb and a high intense bitter bite bring a slight crispy snap. Finish is more wet and oily.  D: Had a hard time really liking this one. A lot going on here and the flavors seemed to get a bit muddled rather than develop on the palate. Not personally the beer I would have selected to showcase the wood either. Drinks more like an aged Old Ale or even some RIS’s. I will credit DFH for creating some unique brews and this was fun to try. Just glad I only purchased a single and didn't pony up the dough for the full 4-pack.

A: pours like a stout - pitch black with a dark head that slims into a faint collar - if this were a stout or black ale, I'd have rated it higher because it looks like that  S: coffee, molasses, vanilla, a little dry wood  T: tastes like somebody poured some red wine into an imperial stout - you've got the dark malt, chocolate, and espresso characters of a stout, but there's also a dark wine sweetness and dryness; some resinousness  M: syrupy, slightly sticky, coating, and medium bodied  O: well, not at all what I anticipated. I'm trying to review it as a brown ale, not just a beer, and I've never had a brown ale this dark and dense; I'd say it's a good beer, but a little bit heavier than I'd expected. I might have scored it differently (higher?) if it were a double stout or even a black ale.

Poured into a snifter. Aged approximately 1 year.  Appearance Black with 2 fingers of brown head. The head retention is impressive for a 12% monster. Thick coating of lacing.  Nose Cedar, caramelized brown sugar, saw dust, hints of vanilla and some citrus notes going on.  Taste Upfront – Molasses, saw dust, maple syrup and perhaps a hint of cherry. Mid-palate – Syrup, caramelized brown sugar, cedar and fig. Finish – Bittersweet chocolate, earth and oak.  Mouthfeel Medium-full bodied, velvety, smooth, semi-chewy, warming and sticky.  Overall Hides the 12% abv pretty damn well. This is a huge, malty monster of a Brown Ale. The Palo Santo wood is apparent and tastes like cedar covered in fresh saw dust.

Review from 1/2010 notes. Poured into a flute glass. Pours a deep, deep red brown with a thin off white head. Aroma of caramel malt, dark fruit and wood. Flavor of caramel, roasted malt, cherries, dates, unidentifiable dark and light fruit. Woody, similar to oak, from the Palo Santo. Rich mouth feel. Surprisingly subdued aftertaste; a bit boozy. A complex and very interesting brown ale.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter.  A: Pours an almost pitch black color with very little light coming through. Very little head to speak of, aside from a very thin tan-colored collar. A brown ale that thinks it's an imperial stout? This now has my attention.  S: Caramel, chocolate, vanilla, dark fruits, booze, and oak comprise the aromatic qualities. Faint, but forgivable given its lack of head.  T: The flavor sees an uptick in the nuttiness befitting a brown ale, especially on that first sip. Caramel, roasted coffee, licorice, toffee, and vanilla make an appearance on the midtaste and finish, but it could stand to be a touch more complex. The aftertaste has a good amount of darker fruits and anise, but otherwise, the general flavor profile gives off a vibe of spiked hazelnut coffee. Pretty damn boozy and tannic. Honestly, this could pass for a fruitier imperial stout along the lines of Stone IRS, rather than a rinky dink, run of the mill brown ale. I'd call it out on not having enough in the way of roastiness, but you know, brown ale, and stuff...  M: I'd call it medium bodied, perhaps ever so slightly erring on the side of light. Weakly carbonated, like I expected. The finish and aftertaste tries to strike a balance between tannic dryness and sticky wetness, and just about pulls it off, right before the tannins fade a little on the palate. Booze isn't particularly stealthy, so sip this one, preferably at a higher temperature. EDIT: It actually becomes quite hot at a higher temperature, so I'm lowering the score here. Yeesh, this is practically burning.  O: I've heard of porters that think they're stouts, but a brown ale that thinks it's an imperial stout? In its current state, it's pretty enjoyable, but still too young and hot. This could become great with a year of age, and it's readily available/cheap-ish enough (for what it is, $15/4 pack isn't chump change) to make picking up a 4 pack to age a worthy endeavor.

A- Looks like a stout to me, dark opaque brown with a one finger coffee foam head that quicly dissipated leaving a thin cap and lacing around the edges. The appearance is great but brown ale?  S- Caramel, coffee, licorice and chocolate, even some cinnamon.. Alcohol in the backgroud.  T- Looks like a stout, tastes like... an out of control brown ale. Huge malty sweetness that gets balanced by something without going into the stout bitterness I was expecting. Hard to tell this weighs in at 50 IBU's but there has to be something to offset the massive malt. A nice bit of alchemy. Everything in the nose is here too.  M- Full bodied without being syrupy. Carbonation is on the low side which lets the maltiness shine.  O- So what if the SRM is off the scale for a brown ale. DFH consistenly pushes the envelope and this is a great example. So many ways this could go wrong but it doesn't. A good one to offer to non-beer lovers as an example of what great beer can taste like.

DFH recommends paring this with chorizo- it works well.  Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a nonic tumbler- pours an incredibly dark brown (pretty much black), with one finger of mocha head, decent retention, a few streaks and dots of lacing.  Smells of dark and roasted malts- a little sweet, a little semi-sweet chocolate, a slight twinge of booze.  Taste is full and rich- lots of roasted malt (almost like an imperial stout), some brown sugar, nice round wood notes, a little booze, and some hops towards the end. Does not taste like 50 IBU but the hops somewhat balance out the extreme malt flavors.  Mouthfeel is all right- full body, mild soft carbonation. Long semi-sweet finish. This is a good beer- it is very expensive and I may not get it again, but it is worth trying.

Appearance is a deep rich brown with almost a finger of beige head that did not linger long, but left some nice lacing in its wake. The nose is distinctly malty and has accompanying notes of vanilla and caramel.  This offering has a very hardy body for a brown ale. The flavor is rich and malty with clear notes of the wood barrel present. There is a hint of alcohol on the finish, but it is mild considering the amped up ABV of this beer.  This is not your father's brown ale, this is something else altogether (in a very, very good way).  March 2016 Update: Had a two-year old bottle is celebration of Easter/Ostara. Surprisingly, aging did not seem to do this gem of a beer justice. The beer seemed past its prime and the alcohol was as potent as a fresh version. In the future, I will stick to enjoying this beer when it is fresh and bold.

A: Completely black, even when held to the light. Starts off with about a finger of mocha-colored soapy head (I used a tulip glass). Dissipates pretty quickly, leaving some, but not much, lacing on the way down.  S: First thing I noticed was coffee, followed by dark fruits and berries. Has a dark chocolate smell to it. Y'all, this beer smells incredible. After a second smell, I'm realllly noticing the dark chocolate.  T: WOW. Really, really good. I got dark fruits up front (and a little booze, but hey it's a 12% ABV beer) followed by toffee, malts, and a coffee/dark chocolate after taste. This is one of the most complex beers I've had.  M: Full-bodied and smooth. You get a little burning booze on the tongue but not much. Very drinkable. Dangerously drinkable.  O: This beer lives up to the hype. Awesome.  Update: I tried a second bottle the day after and this time noted some additional nuttiness. it's possibly that I missed it because of the lower temperature I had it at the first time. This is just an awesome, complex beer. I think I'm going to age the other two and see how they taste several months from now.

Bottled 11/22/11, poured into a Founders snifter.  A. Pours a very very dark brown color with a fluffy mocha head, which dicipates after a few minutes. Head thins to almost nothing. Very syrupy but smooth looking.  S. Surprisingly, I smell meat, buts it's subtle. More prominent is the vanilla, soy and woody aromas. Some molasses. This smells like bitter but sweet desert. Caramel is in there, as well.  T. Chocolately brown sugar, and molasses. Vanilla, something burnt but enjoyable, it's delicious. I definitley taste wood, but it's not as overwhelming as may have thought.  M. Smooth and rich. Very agreeable, perhaps a slight bite at the end.  O. Love this beer. For me, this resembles a stout more than a porter. I suppose it shares elements of both. Looking forward to obtaining more for aging.

12oz bottled poured into a snifter.  A: Brown ale? Looks like a porter to me. Very, very dark brown with a huge mocha colored head. Medium lacing.  S: Sweet woodiness and caramel.  T: Spicy vanilla and woody, caramel malts and coffee, slight heat from the alcohol.  M: Very thick for a brown ale, it's way more like a stout/porter to me. Leaves a lingering woody aftertaste.  O: I'm not huge on DFH, but this is great. My only problem with it is the price. I can't see myself buying this again soon for that reason alone. If it were cheaper, it would be a staple for me. Very nice woody brown ale.

Pours a thick, obviously opaque, brown with very little head. The smell is that of Home Depot or a cedar tree. VERY woody. I like that, but I'll admit it's a bit excessive. But that's just the smell. The taste is fantastic. The wood is present in appropriate amounts to add some serious complexity to what is otherwise normal, boring unfiltered brown ale. The unfiltered brown backbone of this is not something I'm generally a fan of. I feel like the thick oiliness of the lack of filtering can actually hurt the flavour of a brown ale sometimes by making it too thick and masking flavours that can present themselves in a thinner concoction. However, this particular ale is fantastic. It takes that thick brown, malty ale with all the stuff a beer can have crammed into it and it adds a nice woody texture to make it a VERY interesting beer. Sadly, the unfiltered yeast covers up A LOT of the alcoholic bite that should be present in a 12% beer, but most people reading this will probably like that. It's still got enough bite to keep me interested, but it is VERY disguised. So, be prepared to be hit hard. The complexity here is not as amazing as a good quad or a Samichlaus, but it's not far off. I will continue to be enticed by anything aged in wood. Such beers have yet to disappoint me.

This is pretty much a stout, with dark brown almost black pour and a light brown half finger head. Aroma of roasted grain, dirt and some light chocolate notes. Taste is bitter chocolate with serious booze on the back end, warming going down, and nicely integrated. A strong sipper, but very nice, with roast, light wood, and chocolate. Full bodied, medium carbonation, and crazy strong for a brown ale. A pretty awesome brew.

Tried on tap already, now via the bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a thumbs width mocha head. Could easily be mistaken for a stout. Very noticeable alcohol in the aroma, roasted malt, chocolate, wood, and some burnt sugar. Quite a bit of heat to this one that flows into some nice sweetness of vanilla, there's some woodiness, and some sugared breadiness. Not much activity, a nice fuller body. Overall, there was clearly no effort made at hiding the alcohol making this a definite sipper to slowly enjoy throughout the night. Lots of great flavors alongside the alcohol though, making this beer a definite winner.

02/02/12, 12 oz bottle into a DFH signature glass.  A - Pitch black body, a two finger high mocha head forms. Moderate lacing and retention, has some alcoholic legs to it.  S - Wood. But not any lumber yard special, no, no. This is some fancy wood. I'm not exactly a wood connoisseur so I'll just leave it at "pallo santo wood". This "wood" has a certain sweetness and spice to it that works really well on top of some traditional brown ale notes. Brown sugar and caramelized bananas is what really stands out though. In the background there is coffee, vanilla and cocoa powder against lightly roasted malts with a slight mineral thing going on. The aroma is so complex and unique, but its coming off like a barrel aged bananas foster themed beer.  T - It starts off very stout like with roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, oak, and chocolate. But then comes this mildly bitter yet sweet wood favor that is fruity yet smokey and dense. Again, bananas foster. Just as complex and unique as the nose, but less satisfying. It does leave an aftertaste in the mouth that is woody. The mouth feel is medium bodied and syrupy with a high level of carbonation. There is a touch of complimentary warming alcohol, but it doesn't interfere at all.  O - Dogfish Head is just so damn unique. I've had this beer a few times, including a bottle that was about 3 years old. I think I prefer it fresh. So much is happening, and the aroma is just perfect and so enticing. World class example of breaking the mold in the beer world.

Bartender poured this sucka in a pint glass. 16oz later will coincide with the end of my night. Looks dooming. Dark as night with a nice-looking finger of light brown head. Laces like a motherfucker. Not used to looking at this beer in a pint. Head rush overflowed down the sides after the pour, and believe me when I tell you, this glass is sticky.  Bright palo santo wood character upfront that's rathery cedary. Rich coffee, Madagascar Vanilla, and molasses notes in the sweetness. Heavy roasty notes and evident booze.  Woody and bright despite caramelly-rich and boat-sinking maltiness. Maple sweet with coffee, char, booze, toffee, vanilla, bitter roast, and unique barrel wood. The palo santo staves catapult this ale from 'great-tasting' to 'epic'.  Thick and a bit syrupy. Alcohol is pleasantly disguised for a clean-up hitter like this at 12%. Well-carbonated, too. Feels big and sticky, but beery.  One awesome brew! Probably my favorite from DFH!

On-tap, served in a DFH signature glass  I had this on randall with coffee and vanilla beans.  The color was a deep brown, near black, with a one finger off white cap. Some mild lacing as the cap retreated. Sip marks emerge as I move my way through.  The vanilla beans pop a little more than the coffee, but both are very noticeable on top of the wood, caramel, toffee, cocoa powder, and rum soaked fruits.  I find Palo to be a vanilla forward beer to begin with, so the addition of the fresh vanilla beans really made this pop. The coffee beans help bring down the sweetness a notch, blending with the oak and rum soaked fruits on the other end of the spectrum.  Medium to full body, smooth, easy drinker. A touch of booze leaves its mark.  This is like an amped up version of Palo with more robust vanilla notes and the addition of roast coffee to the mix. Highly enjoyable fusion of new flavors.

A: Really thick out of the bottle, pours almost jet black. If I didn't know better, I would've taken it for a stout. Light brown, creamy head dissipates really quickly. Alcohol legs there.  S: A lot going on in the nose. Cocoa powdery/sweet chocolate comes off initially, followed by the alcohol bite. Some roasted characters to finish it off.  T: Deep, dark flavors in this brew. Getting initial sweetness, molasses. Roasted caramel followed by a woody, smoky flavor. At the end you get the welcoming alcohol warmth.  M: Very smooth and deceptively drinkable at 12% abv.  Serving Type: Bottle (bottled on 1/6/11)  Overall: Really good brew. This is the first imperial brown I've tried, so I was hesitant to give this a 5, but with every sip I was reassured. A sipper for sure. Pretty cool to read about what Sam did in order to get this out to us, efforts alone make this worth while.

A: Pours big thick and black.... yeah baby. Light on the carbonation which isn't bad. Little head even after a hard pour.  S. Really fruity. Alcohol dominates. Oak comes through.  T: Grape. Sweet and alcohol. Not a lot of flavors otherwise really...  M: Sits a little sour. But with a full body and pretty good flavor development.  Pretty good but the taste really brings it down... The alcohol really dominates and I feel the more subtle flavors. Certainly not a bad beer but not spectacular.

A - Almost pitch black with a nice, tan head. Head dissipates quickly.  N - Lots of dried fruitiness. Dates, vanilla, and a luxurious malt. (I'm a sucker for good malt.)  T - Like eating a fresh biscuit with prune and date preserves washed down with a cup of vanilla coffee. Imagine that, and you've nailed this beer. Spectacular sweet malt.  M - VERY smooth. That's the overwhelming observation. A nice warmth of alcohol kindles after swallowing.  I had this in the summer. I have to get more. This beer makes me want to curl up in front of a fire on Christmas.

A: Pours an opaque jet black in color. The beer has a finger tall tan head that reduces to a large patch of thin film covering the majority of the surface of the beer and a thin ring at the edges of the glass. Light to moderate lacing is observed.  S: There are light aromas of roasted malts but the dominant aroma for this beer is from the wood it was aged in. Light vanilla notes as well. Alcohol can be detected.  T: There is a nice complexity to the flavors of this beer with some light amounts caramel sweetness, vanilla, bittersweet chocolate, raisin, coffee, and possibly rum. But the dominant flavor is from the wood that it was aged in.  M: Medium to full bodied with moderate amounts of carbonation. Smooth with alcohol warming in the finish and some light amounts of dryness.  O: This beer is pretty easy to drink but you would be better off sipping it - you can more greatly appreciate the subtly of the flavors and the high ABV will really sneak up on you otherwise. There is some light alcohol hints but not nearly as much as you might expect from this strong a beer. Not sessionable.

Amazing brew. First time I tried it, I immediately disliked it, as the flavors are so strong, and I have to admit I'm not a fan of over-the-top dark beers...Thought I'd never enjoy this beer, and planned to give or trade them away.  Reel ahead 6 months later. I finally got up the nerve to pull another one of these out of my storage closet...shazam! What a wonderful smell, mouthfeel and aftertaste. Molasses scent, black licorice flavor and the aftertaste is difficult to describe, perhaps because I constantly want to try another sip! Chewy comes to mind, but not quite accurate, because it's not thick. Incredible flavors and I love the mouthfeel, foamy, rich and chocolatey.

A: two finger milk chocolate head on a jet black body which poured out like oil.  S: vanilla, caramel, toffee, butter, earthy hops and wood all prevail with a boozy undertone.  T: I was expecting the worst but this one was as boozy as I was expecting from the 12% ABV. Starts with vanilla and caramel moving to wood then a chocolate and roasted malt finish with dryness provided by mildly bitter coffee.  M: thick and oily with moderate carbonation.  Overall: the booze are well hidden. This one is actually well balanced. I think the wood cleans this one up and smooths it up.

Was introduced to craft beer via the 2008 New Yorker piece on Dogfish, so, naturally, I was excited to try this beer. Palo Santo, you are:  Well-crafted Dark brown and thick-headed Sans frills Visually pleasing Aged and stunningly textured Fragrant of dark cherries, spices unidentifiable to a Western palate, rich soil and new roots  PS, I love you.

Probably my new favorite from Dogfish Head.  Poured out a black with hints of brown and an off-white head.  Smelled strongly of smoke, wood, vanilla and a hint of toffee.  The taste had a strong amount of the Palo Santo wood, followed by dark chocolate notes, hints of caramel and roasted malts. The mouthfeel was very creamy and rich almost like a Milk Stout. Despite the 12% I couldn't taste, smell or feel it which makes this brew kinda dangerous.  Overall, I'm very impressed with this and this is definitely the best Brown Ale I have ever tried.

12 oz into dixie cup A- black with dense brown head, looks delicous. S- Coffee, malt, sweet T- Sweet but not cloying, roasty but not stouty, amazingly little boozyness, absolutely delicious. M- Medium consistency, good tingly carbonation that fits the beer well. O- Really nice, beer, would drink again in a heartbeat.

12 Oz poured into a Duvel tulip  A- Pours motor oil pitch black. A half finger of a brown head. Lots of alcohol legs and nice lacing. A beautiful beast.  S- This beer is super earthy smelling. A lot of wood and nutty tones. A bit of a light fruity bitterness. A little bit of alcohol as well. This is an awesome and unique smelling beer.  T- One sip is all it took for me to form an opinion of this beer, excellency. A bit of chocolate malt, a tiny bit of coffee and a lot of roasted characters as well. A very nutty and earthy beer. The wooded character comes through very well in this one too. The bitterness comes with some overly ripened fruits which will probably be the first thing to go with age. Very little alcohol taste. Awesome stuff.  M- Goes down incredibly smooth and is very silky. Not too hard to drink. A lot of alcohol warming, no surprise. A dry and slightly bitter aftertaste of wood and earthy tones.  O- I was expecting a good beer and it still surprised me how good this one is. Its got a lot of nice flavors that will probably improve with age. An impressive beer and my new favorite dogfish.

A. Pure black. Nice tan foamy head with some lacing.  S. Not that much of a scent. Some malt.  T. Very strong malt taste. Some chocolate. Some roasted burnt wood taste. Smooth. Strong alcohol taste. Some vegetable taste. Celery.  M. Kinda sour taste.  O. It's an OK blend. Kind of port wine-ish. Interesting and solid, but not my style.

Pours black, black, black. Very small brown head that quickly disappears.  Aroma of alcohol, woody, dark fruits.  Taste of dark malts, wine, vanilla, cocoa.  Mouthfeel is heavy, not cleansing, dry.  Overall, rather interesting. Certainly worth a try.

Poured into a 10 oz. snifter glass. Pours s deep dark brown, with a huge, tan head. The smell is mellow roasted malts, with notes of the wood barrels and vanilla. Taste is strong roasted malts, mild wood notes and a nicely balanced hop spice. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Overall a decent beer, but far from DFH's best.

12 oz bottle poured into an English pint glass at cellar temperature.  L - Deep brown-to-black color with a 3-finger bubbly brown head. Good retention, not much lacing, though. Looks intimidating for a brown ale.  S - Roasted and caramel malt aromas with a woody mustiness and vanilla sweetness from the barrel. Definitely some alcohol present. Smells more like a barrel-aged imperial stout than a brown ale, but let’s see how it tastes.  T - Very interesting taste. The base of this beer is definitely a brown ale with the usual toasted and bread-like malt flavors, but there is a definite vanilla sweetness from the wood. Definitely some alcohol here, as well.  F - Medium-to-full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation for the style, velvety and creamy mouthfeel, with a dry and bitter finish. Bitter taste hangs around for a while, but the sweetness lingers for longer. Definitely a throat-warming sensation from the alcohol.  O - This beer pushes the limits of a brown ale (I should know better with Dogfish Head) but is definitely tasty. Kudos to Dogfish Head for barrel-aging a beer other than a stout or a sour. You know it’s different as soon as you pour it. This is definitely a sipper due to the presence of alcohol throughout. I bought another bottle for my friend who loves brown ales and I have a feeling I’ll have to give him a heads-up before he cracks this one open. This seems like a nice introduction to barrel-aged beers for him.

Appearance – This is very dark brown; almost black. Also very opaque. A nice head that thins out but stays with the beer a long time. Has a light, wet lacing.  Smell – Bitter burnt malts, smoke, caramel, and spice.  Taste – Malt (not as bitter as it smelled), Molasis, and chocolate.  Mouthfeel – Thick and creamy. Very smooth. Hides the 12% abv nicely.  Drinkability – Very easy drinking for a 12% abv beer. Although it smelled a little bitter, it tasted great with no bitter aftertaste. A big surprise!

A - Pours a dark brown-black color with a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lace.  S - Aroma is a mix of molasses, vanilla, smoke, roasted chocolate and caramel malts, black licorice, wood, a touch of dark fruit, and a bit of booze.  T - Starts off with some molasses, vanilla, roasted chocolate malts, and a touch of sweet dark fruits. Through the middle, some smoke and licorice come through with some wood and some more roasted chocolate malts. The finish is a mix of smoke, licorice, vanilla, wood, cocoa, coffee, dark fruit, and a touch of booze.  M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feel smooth with a slightly thick sweet, smoky, and warming finish.  D - Very drinkable. Different and excellent take on a big brown ale. I like the smoke and wood flavors in the beer with the complexity of the rest of the flavors.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip  Appearance: This is a brown ale? It's dark as hell! Used engine oil black, no light getting thru whatsoever. Fluffy tan had has decent retention but leaves virtually no lacing.  Smell: Sweet, sugary malts are outshined a bit by the heavy alcohol.  Taste: Malt bomb. Heavy on the vanilla and caramel, the wood aging leaves quite a mark. Slight mocha, light coffee and milk chocolate as well. At 12% abv, the alcohol is quite prevalent and is very warming. As in the aroma, it suppresses the malt flavor a little bit.  Mouthfeel: Medium body, delicately smooth and a bit creamy from the carbonation. Alcohol sticks to the palate.  Overall: An interesting and enjoyable brew, quite the sipper. It's good, but its a bit too boozy and quite expensive. Definately worth a shot, but I'll stick to DFH's Indian Brown Ale

355 ML poured into a tulip  A-- Poured a deep, dark brown. Bordering on black. Just hints of light at the top of the head. Half finger of dark brown head, quickly fading to a film and a thin but nice ringed collar.  S-- Wood, sweet carmel, sweet vanilla, dark cherry, dark roasted plumb. Sweet nose that borders on a port.  T-- Follows nose but is quite sweet and syrupy. Brown ale on crack really.  M-- Heavy body and low carbonation. Gets heavier as drink as alcohol gets going. Dry wood finish.  O-- Slow drinker. Some nice things about it but too sweet and not balanced enough. Worth having here and there but not all that often.

Ba Review #164 Served On: 05/10/2012 Glassware: Duvel Glass Labeled ABV: 12% Date/ Code: 11/7/2011  This was from a 4-pack of 12oz. bottles I picked up at Ye Old Spirits - Frederick, MD.  Look: Color was a deep dark brown - almost black with zero transparency. The head was a thin coating of brown foam with some head-lacing already noticeable.  Smell: Aroma was a very earthy caramel with an alcohol booziness. Also notes of coffee and roasted malts.  Taste: First was a sweet note of molasses. Then a slight warming sensation hit. A very nice roasted note took over. The finish was of a burnt brown sugar that lead into a roasted aftertaste.  I actually had this beer a couple years ago but didn't have the same appreciation for these types of offerings at the time. I can definitely say this will now be another addition to my beer cellar.

12oz bottle in a tulip.  pours a deep mahogany, sits a borderline black tone while yielding a smallish, maybe 1/2" tan head. moderate retention and lacing.  bold, aromatic nose smacks of malty, woody, smoky delciousness: there's chocolate, roasted malt, some vanilla; almost more reminiscent of an imperial stout than a brown. great aroma.  taste confirms the delicious: smoky and woody notes flank roasted malt, hints of coffee, milk chocolate, molasses, and vanilla; and at 12% abv, there's definitely a wallop of warming alcohol. this a big, unique, and very tasty brew, full of flavor and complexity. smooth, medium-full bodied mouthfeel with adequate carbonation. drinkability is good for a beer this potent, you have to remind yourself to sip. really enjoying this one.  original reviewed on: 07-19-2010

Two and a half year old bottle dated 12/28/09. Had this several times. Finally time for a review.  A - Pours nearly pitch black with one finger head after aggressive pour. Nice lacing.  S - Molasses, brown sugar, alcohol, burnt vanilla, black licorice.  T - Warming alcohol up front followed by a sweet wave of burnt sugars, molasses, some vanilla.  M - Medium bodied with plenty of carbonation. Alcohol warmth present.  O - This beer still has quite a bit of heat after being laid down over two years. Burnt sugars are really pronounced. The palo santo wood may have faded some. Very interesting beer from DFH.

Poured from bottle into pint glass.  Appearance: Pours a dark brown body with a small off white head and no retention, good color.  Smell: A nice strong blend of cocoa, smoked wood, brown sugar, and a red wine. I also get a little vanilla.  Taste: It starts and progresses through a smokey wood and chocolate flavor and then hints of vanilla and red wine. Some residua hops bitterness (not surprised). Finishes with a smooth spiced touch.  Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel.  Drinkability: Quite nice, an I wasn't really feeling or expecting the 12% which they balance quite well. Kudos Dogfish Head.

Bottle into a small snifter.  Dark brown, mostly black. Nice head and lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, char, sweet coconut and smokiness.  Flavor is notes of chocolate, coffee and dark caramel with heavy wood notes--oak, vanilla, and a really unique character for the Palo Santo wood. Barrels contribute sweet flavors of coconut and smoke. Unique. Alcohol is definitely noticeable, but I wouldn't peg it as 12 percent ABV.  Medium mouthfeel, mildly carbonated.  This is a good beer, and probably my favorite from Dogfish Head. I don't always like their experiments, but this Palo Santo wood was a good move. It tastes more like a porter or stout than a brown ale, and it's like your typical barrel-aged offerings--but only kind of.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Looks dark brown with a nice brown head.  Smells a little medicinal, but nice whiffs of wood, carmel, and malt.  I get a little of the nail polish remover taste, but it's not a killer. It still has a nice sweet dark fruit, smokey, earthy, carmel, complex flavor that is worthy of a strong brown ale.  Mouthfeel is good, but could grow tired of the high abv.  Pretty solid beer that is expensive, but fun to drink.

Rich, deep, mocha head with elegant lacing. Dark cocoa appearance. A bit weak in the nose, but very pleasant hints of caramel and wood. Satin-like mouthfeel with a mild, coffee finish. An ever so subtle booziness that is common with DH. Overall, another outstanding beer from Dogfish Head

12oz bottle poured into a standard pint glass, bottle was chilled to around 40 degrees.  I am a big dfh fan and beers like this help reinforce that fact.  Smell is definitely porter-like, but with more espresso and an unfamiliar spice I can only attribute to the palo santo wood.  It poured like a lot of homebrews Ive seen, but the 1 finger head changing from copper orange to brown quickly then disappearing was very interesting.  Taste is awesome, which is why I bought it. Honestly the alcohol is hidden VERY well. The earthy coffee thick bold flavor is worth every penny. Will finish updating later.

12oz bottle split into two pint glasses  Pours stoutlike in color, but the head looks like a dark version of a brown ale's. Opaque. Slow fizzy. Smell is rich and woody.  Taste is extremely complex, but it starts with an alcohol slap in the face. Rich and sweet, lots of smoke flavor, maybe dates and toffee, maybe some coffee, definitely some cherry.  Mouthfeel is rich and a little gritty, somewhere between stout and brown ale. Overall, this is a surprising and good beer.

This self described "EXTREME" beer, is shy of its claim, but a step above the norm for Dogfish.  It pours like a light syrup with a deep brown color and amber accents. The head failed to appear, but excited copper bubbles danced on the top in its place.  The mouthfeel of the beer is surprisingly pleasant despite the high alcohol content. It is very present on your breath at first, but fades as the malty carmel flavor dominates. The vanilla never really broke through until the very end.  Design:  Dogfish focuses on a cross section of Lignum vitae wood (Palo Santo) with a wood grain background.  They go to the extent to explain that they are very excited about this beer and it's woody housing, and that that are bearers of such wood. "It's all very exciting. We have wood. Now you do too." Always a classy presentation.

Let me start by saying I had almost given up on DFH. I have had a couple of their more recent beers that just didn't do it for me. This beer won me back from the first sip.  It pours black with a nice 2-3 finger tan head. Nice sweet, roasted malt aroma.  Tastes of vanilla, caramel, chocolate with a hint of licorice.  The surprise for me was the drinkability and mouthfeel for 12% abv. While the alcohol is present it is not overbearing, nor is the mouthfeel to thick.  All in all a very delicious beer. Definitely one to look out for.

Poured from a 12-ounce bottle into a tulip-shaped Duvel glass.  A: Pitch black with a frothy, three-finger head of tan foam that settles to a thin, creamy head of lace. Dark and inviting with an espresso-like head.  S: Spicy, bold, earthy wood aromas rise from the brew and combine with a bittersweet, chocolate-espresso smell. Bits of bourbon, vanilla and oak are woven into the dark, complex nose.  T: Warm, sweet and oakey up front, the roasted malts grip the tongue first and splash on the bourbon, bittersweet, herbal coffee and dark chocolate flavors. The sweetness gives way quickly to hot, boozy and herbal bitterness that pulls in more velvety malt notes. The finish is very warming with a slick, bittersweet and oily vanilla and woody flavor. Complex and luscious.  M: Full-bodied, slick and rich mouthfeel with a lingering, oily and hot bourbon-aged, smooth finish.  O: A robust, imperial American brown clocking in at 12% ABV; leave it to DFH to corral the chaos. A deep sipper, this would go really well with a blackened Angus burger topped with Stilton, a flourless chocolate torte or a smoky selection from the humidor. This versatile, oak-aged beauty is bets suited to be sipped and analyzed on its own, though.

A: Deep rich and dark color. Not transparent at all. Deep rich chocolate colored head slightly less then 1 finger thing. Lacing stuck around the edge all the way through.  S: Very nice amount of things working out here. Hints of coffee and dark chocolate/caramel working thru. Allowed the beer to warm a bit after first smell and it seemed to become more intense with a few other earthy aromas coming thru. Slight hint of alchol poking thru as well.  T: Very nice. So much going on in my mouth, very nice deep and rich flavors. Def coffee/dark chocolate and alot of earthy wood/oak flavors make it very complex and enjoyable on my palette. Sweet flavor, maybe a hint of vanilla, not sure mostly tasting the bold flavors and then the alcohol at the end.  M: Light carbonation thru out, mouthfull brings out some sweeter flavor and then gets to the deeper darker bolder flavors but still ends with a sweetness that i'm really enjoying. Impressed with this one.  O: Def a very enjoyable beer. Bit on the heavy side so its more of a beer i'd drink after a meal or with a good dessert while relaxing. Would def drink again, and def like to try it on tap. DFH boys impress me yet again.

Poured from a bottle @ cellar temperature (bottled on date: 7/19/11) into a 22.5oz Libbey Citation snifter (M/N 8409).  A- Pours a near-black (light does cut through the very top edge of the liquid when the glass is tilted) with coffee ice cream colored head growing to nothing more than 1-finger.  S- A lot going on here...syrupy sweet notes of caramel, chocolate covered espresso beans, vanilla and wood all mingle endlessly. As the brew warms, wood and booze become more apparent, but never so much that it is overwhelming.  T- No detectable vanilla but the syrupy sweetness, espresso, chocolate and caramel are all there. Alcohol warmth is definitely apparent...but at 12%, I would expect as much.  M- Slick and smooth up front followed by a dry and woody finish. Moderate carbonation does the job nicely.  O- Reminds me more of an Imperial Stout, but who cares about names? This is an amazingly robust and complex ale...worth every penny, especially at 12%abv. If you like a complex sipper of a beer, do yourself a favor and check this one out.

12 ounce bottle poured into my signature Dogfish glass. Received in a trade with Rizali - thanks Bryin!  A - Jet black. Reminiscent of an imperial stout. Thin 1 finger head that dissipates rather quickly. Had a little bit of lacing.  S - Earthy, nutty, molasses, coffee, oak and booze. Smells reminds me of a bourbon barrel aged porter, not a brown.  T - Same as nose. Mellows as it sits. Booze is very present. Interesting wood / earthy smell which is obviously the Palo Santo wood.  M - Pretty highly carbonated for the style. Dry finish because of the high alcohol. Pretty smooth and well balanced.  Overall - Not my favorite Dogfish brew, but not bad. You have to understand what they try to do and go with it 'Off Centered Ales for Off Centered People'. Worth a try, but I probably wouldn't buy it again.

A - deep charcoal, nearly black. Nice tan head that dissipates quickly.  S - wood, caramel and a touch of booze.  T - burnt sugar and campfire roasted marshmallow. A woodiness that I can't quite describe emerges. The alcohol becomes evident as the beer warms and toward the end of the sip. There is a molasses sweetness but it disappears in the thin finish.  M - moderate carbonation and perhaps a touch too much for a beer this big.  O - nothing too special. Had this beer a few times but the taste and alcohol presence doesn't excite my palate. I probably won't try this again unless it's aged at least a few years.

A- Pours like it's a stout. Deep, deep brown, pretty much black. Small, one finger head of tiny bubbles that is gone quickly. Good lacing.  S- Smells like an intense brown or porter to almost a stout. Lots of sweeter notes and caramel with hints of the woody scent. Slight hint of the high ABV. Very complex and delicious smelling.  T- Starts off like the typical brown ale. Good caramel notes and some brown sugar sweetness. After the initial flavors, a slight alcohol kick comes in, but then the wood flavors kick in. Slightly like oak aged beers, the flavor is complex and sweet. Ends with a slight bite from the wood flavor profile and maybe a few, barely detectable hops.  M- Very light and carbonated for it's ABV and flavor weight, but holds both well. Easy to drink, with only a little alcohol burn. This one could sneak up on you.  Overall, I am very pleased with this DFH offering. Looking forward to the second one I have aging in a few months to a year.

Poured on-tap and served in a tumbler pint, the beer is almost jet black, with a tall, light, fluffy brown head. Aromas are subtle, with caramel and vanilla highlights and some woody characteristics. Flavors are booze forward, with a hard, roasted backbone to balance, and a blast of vanilla and oak throughout the palate. Heavy hitter for a brown, but this is a damn good beer! The aftertaste is surprisingly smooth and light, with a touch of booze and some nutty sweetness. Clean, slick finish that has a touch of drying from the increased ABV. Easy enough to drink that you could get into some trouble.

Palo Santo on tap at Pony during a mighty Dogfish tap takeover.  Appearance: Looks like a mighty Imperial Stout, oily shiny black. One finger of coffee head that dies soon, leaving abundant lacing.  Smell: Wood, fancy chocolate, braising liquid, stew. Nourishing! Molasses and sugar.  Taste: Follows nose, with added smoke, country ham and bacon. Booze and a pinch of bourbon at the end. Nice-but-odd barrel feel all around. Cafe con leche, milk foam.  Mouthfeel: Alright good, not great. Medium flavor, carbonation, body. Nice smoky finish.  Overall: A damn good beer, rich and delicious, but I like the bottled version so much better!

12 oz. bottle poured into a pint glass  Pours a very dark brown with a dark beige two and half finger head. The smell of wood, light roasted malt, and subtle dark fruitiness are present. Fig and plum with a bit of wood on the nose transitioning to toasty malt and boozy slightly sweet syrup with a hint of vanilla. The finish is dry with malt and warm booze. Exceptional mouthfeel, gentle but abundant carbonation which blankets the inside of the mouth, very full-bodied. Really an extremely original and very enjoyable brew.

Received a 12 fl oz bottle of this from my girlfriend, buying from Total Wine, Beer, & Spirits in Sarasota, FL & added it to a mix-a-six pack. Poured from the Dark Pink Labeled bottle into my 12oz Surly Darkness Tulip Glass. Has BOTTLED ON: 01/05/2012 on the neck of the bottle.  Aroma- Tons of wood, light toastiness, and chocolate attributes hit the nose first. Very dark background with dark malts, fruits, and other ingredient.  Appearance- Pours a 2 finger, darkest brown head that has average retention. Has a deep brown colored body and leaves VERY thick lacing that coats every inch of the glass.  Flavor- Tons of strong malts and wood are the two biggest noted characters. Has a light caramel flavor and medium-high bitterness at the finish.  Mouthfeel- Full Bodied, Light-Medium Carbonation, Dry, and woody/malt finish on the palate.  Overall Impression- While the drinkability of this one is poor, able to enjoy over a long period of time and really get all the characteristics within. Wish there was more of a burnt flavor and more hops included... Very strong and tough to finish! Would definitely like to age a bottle of this.

Bought a 4-pack from Total Wine in DE. Bottled on date said 2/2/12. Nice & fresh.  A: Pours a murky black with great tan head at first which then shrinks down to a thin lacing.  S: Big dark malts. Lots of roast at first, but they give away to some sweet caramel notes. Dark fruit of cherry & fig. The wood takes awhile to appear but makes itself know well enough. This one does not smell like a 12% ABV beer at all.  T: Sweet caramel that gives way to a boozy syrupy-sweet dark roasted malt character. Some molasses, vanilla, and some bourbon-like notes. Wood is nice and subtle. The alcohol makes itself known in the taste.  M: This one is well balanced considering the high ABV. A decent kick of bitterness sets in but also lets the sweetness of malts shine through. Feels medium full.  O: One of my favs from DFH. A great nightcap beer or one to sip & enjoy for quite awhile. The wood character is a great behind-the-scenes character.  Update on 3/21/13: had another bottle from the same 4-pack. Bottled on date of 2/2/12. Drinking over 1-year later. Smells more cherry-like, a tad sour, with notes of wood oil, brown sugar & molasses, and pine tar. Has some solventy alcohol. Roast & char seems evident. Tastes like a full, vinous, dark mother of a brew. Competes with any RIS. Still tastes good. Developing interesting complexities, but I wish I had aged this one for at least 2 more years.  Update on 2/11/16: cracked open a bottle from 9/26/13 production date. Tastes great as ever. Excellent beer on a very cold winter night. Some oxidized notes but still very dark, rich, and complex as ever. The palo santo wood notes have melded with the dark malts into a rich dark chocolate like flavor with some wood, vanilla and maybe some spices like nutmeg. Smells non-solventy at room temp. Glad to have aged this one as well as a few more from different years.

Dogfish Head's Palo Santo Marron is a bit of a mystery to me. I'll have it one time and really enjoy it but another time I won't be so impressed. That's why I'm re-reviewing it, so that I can have a better understanding of this insane brown ale.  Let's be clear. This doesn't look like a normal brown ale at all. It's almost jet black and totally opaque. Anything about it brown? Nope! It looks like you're pouring out oil. The head doesn't form fast or get very high but I made sure my pour was extra disruptive, so my head grew thick, creamy, and brown. By look alone, you'd think you poured out a porter or stout. This is also where you think, "This is different." Well, you'd be right about that.  Let's repeat. This doesn't smell like a normal brown ale at all. Sweet molasses, vanilla, strong booze that burns the nostrils, dark fruits, and a spicy uniqueness from the Palo Santo wood give the beer an olfactory complexity. It's very boozy, which is not surprising given its 12% ABV.  If you haven't guess it yet, this doesn't taste like a normal brown ale at all. Up front the booze hits very hard, a little too hard in my opinion. In fact, that's always been my one complaint about the Palo Santo Marron. It has some damn good flavors but the alcohol presence is too strong. The Palo Santo spiciness hits at the front as well, with the rest of the complex beer coming after. Dark fruit (figs) melds with molasses, vanilla, and coffee. Very tasty. Sweetness and roastiness lingers on the tongue.  The mouthfeel is simply luxurious. It's like velvet flowing over the tongue, it's so creamy. Carbonation is medium-low but not flat at all. Sweetness makes the mouth slick. The booze may be like a punch, but the creaminess makes the beer pretty drinkable.  My opinion hasn't changed much with the Palo Santo Marron, but there's no doubt this is a very unique beer, especially since it's classified as a brown ale. The only complaint I have is that I think the booze intrudes on it a bit too much. Still, it's delicious and a beer I'd recommend everyone try at least once.

Served in a tulip. The beer poured a very dark midnight brown color with a light smell of chocolate. The mouth feel was very tart and tingled the back of the tongue. The finish was a spicy, fruity chocolate, and overpoweringly alcoholic with slight bitterness.  This is a very alcoholic beer-12% ABV- even more than the Boulevard Chocolate Ale. After the beer warms up, there is a smell of fruited chocolate and alcohol in the smell, and the finish also accentuates the alcohol as the chocolate mellows.  Overall, this is a great beer, perhaps my favorite from Dogfish. It's strikingly alcoholic but well balanced with fruit, chocolate and light bitterness.  update: over a year later, 4/18/13, I find more deep cherry and vanilla( aroma)- very pronounced cherry fruit in the taste, and less chocolate. A wonderful beer. Quite intense and a slow sipper. My favorite from Dogfish.

12oz bottle, pours dark chestnut with an oily but creamy tan head that holds good retention given the massive ABV and leaves some chunky lacing on the glass. Aromas are oaky with vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, and a nose full of booze. Tastes are boozy up front and tremendously sweet with complex notes of burnt brown sugar, caramel, oak (Palo Santo wood, but it resembles oak), vanilla, and roasted malts. Mouth-feel is creamy, smooth, and boozy enough to leave a peppery prickle on the tongue. Overall, this has always been a favorite of mine. Always love going back to it every once in awhile. It is a sipper and can be cloyingly sweet at times, but still very enjoyable.
I aged this beer for 2.5 years, and it was AWESOME!so my rating for the 2.5 year aged brew is 4.5. This truly was good with a ton of aging. Otherwise it's a decent brew.

12 oz. bottle poured into goblet. Bottled in Setember 2011, so this one is about 6 months old.  A - Pours a nearly black, dark brown color with a small beige head that dies quickly. Darker than any brown ale I have seen. Some lacing but nothing too impressive.  S - Very complex combination of cherry, vanilla, and coffee beans. Also some oak and toasted malt. Very inviting aroma.  T - Blend of brown sugar, plum, vanilla, espresso, and a little oak (well, probably palo santo wood). There is a mild bitterness and tartness in the middle. Vanilla is especially prominent on the finish. Extremely smooth. The alcohol is well hidden and only becomes the slightest bit apparent as it warms. Very well balanced and complex.  M - Medium bodied with good micro-carbonation. Compliments the flavors nicely and contributes to the equable nature of this beer.  O - I was very impressed by this offering from DFH. The aromas and flavors are a top notch combo of sweet, woody, fruity, and chocolatey. I can't think of another beer with this ABV that goes down quite as smooth as this. It is a bit pricey, but I suppose that is the cost for such a unique, barrel aged brew. Bonus points for the groundbreaking vessels they made to age this brew. I don't give DFH as much credit as they deserve, but they continue to impress me with great beers. When I am looking for a delicious, smooth, sipping beer, it doesn't get much better than Palo Santo Marron. I highly recommend it.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Spiegelau tulip.  A: Extremely dark brown (almost black) body with a modest chocolate colored head. Head recedes down a little, but not entirely, with some lacing.  S: Prominent notes of chocolate, lactose sugar, vanilla bean, some spiciness mingling with subtle wood. Not a hint of alcohol.  T: Impressive. Assertive chocolate, vanilla bean, and a definite nice woodiness underneath. Cinnamon and salt. Milky sweetness and a bit of fruitiness from the alcohol throughout. Fantastic finish of roasty bitterness, semisweet chocolate, rum-like alcohol, and smooth wood from the barrel.  M: Thick and creamy.  O: I was extremely impressed by this brew. Straddles the line between an imperial stout and a strong brown, with the wood and alcohol integrated very well. Alcohol is extremely well-hidden for 12%, and when it comes out, it's for the better. Best DFH beer I've had.

A - Dark brown almost black with thin light brown head. Not much lacing.  S - Really complex aromas going on in this beer. Some big hints of chocolate and roast up front. Behind that is some darker fruits and some cherry notes as well. Faint vanilla notes behind the fruits. Impressive that a 12% beer has no alcohol fuselage in the nose.  T - The taste is also incredibly complex. Dark fruit is the first big taste I get in this beer. Some milk and bittersweet chocolates help compliment the sweetness. The slight boozy taste helps cut through all that sweetness and actually balances it out nicely. Finishes just a tad too boozy for my tastes.  M - Thick and chewy bodied. Some moderate alcohol burn going on in it and a moderate level of carbonation.  O - A big and delicious beer. Complexity is outstanding in this beer and it is really quite a challenge to nail down exactly what is going on. (I think I couldn't even do it..)

A- Pours a dark brown with 1 finger light brown head that dissipates into a nice thin layer that lingers wonderfully on the sides. Nice lacing too. Very appealing to the eye.  S- Smells sweet and malty, kind of like caramel and brown sugar. The wood smell definitely comes through also, very interesting. The mildest hint of alcohol is present, but doesn't smell boozy at all (mildly surprising for 12% beer).  T- Woah, that just punches you in the face. Hold on, let me take another sip. *BAM* ouch, still got me. Sweet caramel malt at first...then a wave of boozy brown beer wallops your senses like you got hit in the face with one of the wooden planks it was brewed with. The booze fades leaving a nice hoppy/slightly bitter finish. I guess for 12% it's what you would expect, but that alcohol really hits you.  M- Smooth medium to full body - I can't tell if it's low carb and the hops prickle at your tongue or high carb, but it definitely leaves that tingling sensation.  O- A very innovative and tasty beer. Not something I can drink more than 1 of in a session (can I even finish this one?) but very interesting and something everybody should try at least once.

This beer is off the charts! and by far the best 'new' beer I've had in the past many months. Almost a dessert beer, this smooth and creamy beer doesn't give away it's high alcohol content via flavour. Smooth and creamy with a caramel-malty character.

Sample: 1 bottle 2012  A: Very dark, with dark ruby around edges when held to light, mild internal carbonation, nice light head (dark brown)  S: Nice bouquet, hints of banana and dried fruit, very apparent cedar notes, smoke  T: Boozy, but delicious, strong cedar and smoke, still traces of banana and dates  M: Amazingly smooth at 12% abv, seems to melt in my mouth, easy to drink, nice aftertaste, not overpowering, very nice  O: A great strong beer, very enjoyable to drink, nice strong flavors, and a unique head

I am enjoying this one while I wait for the water to heat up to brew some oatmeal stout. Poured into dogfish head pint glass  A-Dark brown with a chocolate colored head. nice head. Nice chocolate colored layer on the top.  S-Smells of some coffee and chocolate to me. Very nice. Slight nutty scent but not much.  T-Sort of a java/mocha flavor. Some coffee taste in there with a hint of chocolate. A bit of alcohol hits on the way down.  MF-medium to thick. not to heavy feeling. Nice mouth feel. nice aftertaste.  O-this is balanced very well with the the alcohol in it. Very nice mix for a brown. I am not a big fan of the style but this is delicious. Wouldnt mind having this regularly.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a Breckenridge pint glass.  A: Pours deep, dark brown with a gorgeous mocha two finger head that drops down to half an inch and leaves nice lacing.  S: Sweet chocolate notes with a lot of malt backbone. Molasses and slight vanilla are also present.  T: Boozy and woody on the front end, sweet vanilla and molasses in the middle that lead to a pleasant hop-feel bite at the end. A decently complex beer. Glad that the mouth followed the nose.  M: Full bodied and creamy. This is how beer should feel.  O: I'm rarely disappointed with Dogfish Head, and this beer falls nicely into their current lineup of great beers.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a snifter.  A- Pours a dark black with a thin tan head that instantly dissipated down into a ring around the edges of the glass.  S- sweet and malty. Notes of vanilla and oak, bourbon, caramel, burnt sugar, molasses, and wood.  T- Taste's very strongly of vanilla and wood. Very sweet.  M- Very smooth with a low carbonation.  O- An amazing ale. Very unique with it's woody flavor. Really wish this was available here in Wisconsin. Would definitely drink again.

12 oz bottle, bottled date of 11/21/11, so about 3 months old.  appears black, with dark tan 1/2" head. great head retention. aroma is boozey, oak, vanilla, caramel.  taste is malty, slightly roasty. same woody, vanilla, bourbon notes. no alcohol taste. medium thickness, smooth creamy feel, lower carbonation.  overall - great beer, even though it's not really a brown ale, close to a porter or thin stout.

Once I picked up a four pack of this while on the Jersey Shore in the summer. This seemed like a good choice since I am a big fan of DFH. Before my review I can that this is one of the worst choices for summer... however, it is one of the better dark beers around.  I poured the Marron into a goblet. There was a thick brown head that came up immediately. This beautiful head comes down to a very nice ring that is good for leaving some nice lacing on the glass. Oh, and it is so dark that absolutely no light comes through.  The flavor is pretty impressive. You get a ton of heavy stout with a pretty significant woody flavor. It actually hits the umami sensor on the tongue. This is the only one that I know accomplishes this. There is also a pretty strong alcohol presence. It is both challenging and complex. Palo Santo is definitely a good choice for sipping. The flavors are so strong that it will overwhelm most beers that follow.  Overall, this is an amazing heavy beer. Don't choose this before going out because you might just want to stay in.

A: Very Dark Brown. Appears black int he glass with a hint of brown around the edges  S: Maple, Vanilla, Alcohol hints  T: Earthly, Chocolate, Vanilla, middle alcohol, after smokey  M: heavy, creamy, low carbonation  O: Bold Flavor, Strong beer with hints of alcohol coming through. Will drink again.

Bottle from 2008 courtesy of Jason. Thanks!  Dark, dark brown in color with a thin tan head. Smells quite sweet. Lots of brown sugar, molasses, and toffee. The wood is prominent and gives an almost spicy aroma. A hint of vanilla in there which balances some of the roast nicely. Mildly spicy with lots of dark sugar notes--molasses, burnt sugar, and caramel. Light vanilla flavor and a subtle roast flavor. Really well balanced.

12oz bottle poured into hill farmstead 'wine' glass  A - oily black body with a thin brown head thats ringed the glass with 30 seconds.  S - big notes of chocolate, alcohol, wood, seems like theres some anise floating in there as well.  T - some anise hits first with lots of chocolate following. oak some coffee and a herbal/grass hop finish.  M - medium to full bodied with lots of carbonation. its thick but not too thick. some hop puckering but not a lot. alcohol warming on the throat.  O - a superb beer packs a punch well worth checking out.

Nose features bits of raisin, earthy notes, candied sugars, hardly any discernible booze. Pours a near pitch black with a healthy finger of mocha head that dims down to dimples. Nice lacing. Taste is very, very intriguing. Really like nothing that I can remember. Sweet fruit and malt initially. You really get the woody characteristics right in the middle and it makes for a perfect transition into some sweet heat. No complaints with the mouthfeel. Overall, this is absolutely splendid. Really wish I could get this one in MN. Oh well - to my wants!

Pours a deep dark brown, almost black with a thin tan head that dissipates quickly. Looks very stout-like. Aroma is filled with caramel and chocolates, a bit of vanilla and oak-like flavor, some alcohol it there too. Tastes Great. Lots of roast and dark fruits, vanilla, more wood flavors and alcohol burn in the finish. Very creamy in the mouth. Thick and full bodied. Light carbonation. This a damn fine brew, but I’m not sure I’d label it a brown. Got this as an extra, so I will leave my 4 I have cellering alone.

This beer pours a brown color with a small tan head. Lacing sticks to my glass. Smell of wood, caramel, and vanilla. Sweet brown sugar taste throughout the beer. Very smooth and easy drinking, the 12% ABV can sneak up on you. A great beer to sit and sip on throughout the evening.

12 oz botle poured into Chimay chalice.  A - Dark brown, lets no light through. Darkest color head I have ever seen, deep sand brown, 2 finger height, dissipated quickly.  S - Chocolate rum, roasted malts, earth.  T - Big and malty, super roasty. Woody notes, and then the alcohol at the end is a nice effect on this one.  M - Big and full, with an aftertrail that feels real nice. A bit boozy.  O - Definitely coming back for more here.

A - Beautiful black pour with an aggressive head of about three fingers, that fades quickly.  S - Smell is of vanilla, molasses, chicory and Paraguayan Palo Santo wood....just kidding, but the vanilla and molasses notes are serious as a heart attack.  T - Thick, mouthful of flavor. No mistaking this one for a mundane brew. Molasses, roasted malt, soy sauce (yeah), vanilla, hoppy bitterness  M - Full flavor, well-balanced amount of carbonation, thick consistency, but not obnoxiously cloying to the tongue.  O -I get this one at the brew pub in Rehoboth all the time because it's one of my favorites. This beer is so flavorful it gives me wood...chips deep down in my soul.

Received in a grade with Slvrmon82. Reviewed from notes. Pours a very deep brown, almost black color. Body is the beer is very thick as I can't see much through it. Head is tan, stands 3/4in tall after a fairly aggressive pour. Retention isn't great, but that is to be expected. Smell is of sweet caramel malt, vanilla, roasted malts. Taste is relatively comples, from the malts I get a nice smooth sweetness. I also get some dark fruit, vanilla, woody flavors. I can taste just a hint of alcohol, but wouldn't have guessed that this was 12%. Body is thick, with subtle carbonation, this is an enjoyable beer, pretty drinkable considering how big it is. Really a great beer to share with a friend.

Bottled 10/04/11, Enjoyed 02/01/12 A: This thing is jet black. Even when I held it up to the light I couldn't see any lighter color around the edges of the glass. The head is brown but doesn't stay around as long as expected, maybe the alcohol is the culprit. S: Awesome smell. The two main players to me are fruitiness and vanilla. Fruit is of the estery, cherry like variety. I swear I can smell a really sweet banana, like banana cream pie but I might be crazy. The vanilla is no surprise given the wood, but surprisingly, any other wood characteristics are pretty subtle. I don't know what palo santo wood swells like, but I don't think I can really smell any woodiness, with the exception of the vanilla. A roasty, dry, maltiness lurks beneath to really bring the aroma together. T: Fruitiness and sweeter malts open up the taste. The bottle says caramel but I'm not really picking much up. The estery fruitiness is really pleasant, typical DFH great fermentation, and carries the taste on top of the apparent maltiness. The vanilla is also present. The beer slowly dries out as a roasty bitterness and the alcohol take over. It’s a nice transition, the fruitiness never disappears, but joins the roastiness and the alcohol in a lingering finish. The finish is relatively dry, but is somewhat refreshing, surprising given the ABV. M: Really nice mouthfeel here. Fuller side of medium-bodied. The sweetness and bitterness combo do a great job working over the entire palette. O: Typical DFH beer. They stress the uniquie, crazy Palo Santo wood but it really only adds a nice complexity to a well-crafted, balanced beer. The alcohol is a little too present for me, but I still really enjoyed this beer. I feel like I drank this beer a little green, and it will only improve with age.

Tulip  A - deep dark brown/blackish, one and a half finger head and some nice sticky lacing  S - cinnamon, fruity hop notes, nice toasted and simple sweet malts, slight booze, Carmel, dried dark fruits, vanilla and a slight hop  T - deep dark malts, tons of sweet, funky yeast, nice toasted and sweet malts, nice booze, nutty, bananas. Chocolate, slightly hop, earth wood and awesomeness!  M - full bodied, low acidity, ok balance, ok complexity and very long nice finish  D/O - nice huge ale, big stout like malts, fun stuff. Very nice and huge ale! Love this brown/stout  Final thought - 12% abv, nice $3 price and may I please have more

12oz bottle into snifter. Pours a pitch brown color with creamy one finger cedar colored head that dissipates quickly.  Nose: Vanilla, cocoa, dairy, milk chocolate, light hints of smoke. The nose on this is amazing... so much so that I almost don't want to take a sip.  Taste: Raisin, dried plum, slight acidity, alcohol heat, light sweetness.  Low, smooth carbonation with roasted malt and peat aftertaste. The depth of flavor on this is admirable. Overall an awesome brew. Looks great, smells great, tastes great. Would definitely drink again and would enjoy trying some with a little more age!

I had this offering in a nonic pint. Big thanks to Geneseohawk for this one!  Appearance- The milk - chocolate colored frothy and creamy - smooth head has decent retention, but falls to a ring with only the tiniest bit of lace on the glass.  An opaque and nearly black body is also stunning on this "brown" ale.  Smell- A wood chip scent is dominant, that almost turns smokey the more sniffs I take from the glass. Booze is also appreciated, with that woodiness it begins to smell like a whiskey.  A sweet syrupy quality also rises out of the glass. It is a little caramel and vanilla in quality. That sweet and smokey combo also gives the impression of figs.  Taste- A sweet brown sugar and roasted malt come through first, followed in short order by the now bourbon-like booze. A little oakiness shows and mingles with some earthy flavors and more roasted malt in the finish.  This is not nearly as sweet as the nose, but the bourbon aspect and oakiness are well appreciated.  Mouth feel- I really enjoy the medium body and the slickness of this beer. The high alcohol really suits that kind of feel. Too creamy and I think it would be harder to drink.  Overall- While certainly not shy on the booziness, there is much to like. The fun and complex nose, the brown sugar and bourbon qualities of the palate, and the solid, slick feel.  I would gladly have this again.

Man-O-man I've had a metric shit-tonne of these over the last few years, and I still don't know how to describe it. The best I can do is - vanilla - but so much more.  La Brea tar pits in color and a thin brown head, but it oddly looks tempting. "Drink me.", it says. "There's a sabre toothed tiger skeleton at the bottom." Now that's black. None more black.  Oh yeah, the booze. Ethanol in abundance, but the thick, syrupy tongue coating seems to mute the alcohol. The mouthfeel mingles with the vanilla/booze cabal perfectly.  I've helped you none in describing this beer, but I did my best. I am still confused, perplexed and delighted by this beer. I will add that cellaring seems to have little effect on the beer. I've A/B'd 1-year old Palo and 2-week old Palo, and I swear they taste the same.  I declare DELISH!!!

Another Dogfish head beer. Hmm. 12 fl oz brown glass bottle with botled on date 02/02/2011B. What does the B mean? I don't know. Served into a De Molen beer stemflute in low altitude Los Angeles, California. Reviewed live. I don't know what to expect, but when I think of a brown think nuts. Wood aging isn't anywhere near what I'd expect, and I'm hoping it'll blow me away. Served slightly warmer than refrigerator cold.  A: Pours a 1.5 finger head of rich light tan colour, good cream, great thickness, and very impressive retention - especially considering the 12.00% ABV. Wow. Colour is a solid black (NOT brown). I'm impressed so far, and excited to try it.  Sm: A moderately strong aroma of cream, wood, nuts, birch, vanilla, caramel, and a hint of alcohol. I wouldn't call it subtle, nor is it particularly inviting. No yeast comes through.  T: The wood comes through, but only on the finish. The warm alcohol is well-restrained and hidden, hardly coming through at all. I get vanilla, light caramel, very buried roasted barley (why this is buried is beyond me), and nuts - but only on the climax. It isn't subtle, but instead feels muted; I find myself straining to taste each note because the holistic flavour doesn't have all that much to offer. I mean it's good, and it's balanced, but it just doesn't bring the depth or boldness I'd expect from a 12% beer. This may be the least flavorful high ABV beer I've had in the last three months.  Mf: Smooth and wet, suiting the flavours and general tone of the beer. Not too thick nor too thin. Actually surprisingly well done.  Dr: Extremely drinkable for the ABV, but where is the flavour? Hit us with the taste if you believe it's a good one! I like this, but I wouldn't have it again because it's kind of a panzy when it comes to delivering on the promise of the aroma. Shame on you Dogfish Head!  B-

On tap at the DFH Alehouse in Falls Church, VA. Deep brown color. No head or lacing. Smells of oaky dried fruits and malts. Taste is of an oaky chocolatey vanilla...but very mild across the board. This is a sipping beer for sure. The oaky vanilla dominates, but is very subtle at the same time. You really taste the earthy wood. Very nice brown ale...but this may be a call of its own with an Imperial Brown Ale. Nice.

Pulled out of my cellar, bottled 07/24/08. Poured into a snifter.  A- Pours dark with a finger's worth of caramel color head that lingers. Looks like an Imperial Stout. Little carbonation.  S- Lots going on here with the smell. The most prominent smell is wood. Next up is just an overall sweet, caramel-like smell. Some alcohol smell is apparent as well.  T- The wood-aging is very evident in the taste. I also get hints of caramel, vanilla, and chocolate. The alcohol warming sensation is still strong, even after 3.5 years. Very malty finish.  M- Medium-bodied, some carbonation.  I really enjoyed this one, and it's one of my favorites from DFH. As said above, it looks and drinks more like an Imerial Stout, very surprising that it's labeled as a brown ale.

A - Pours a thick, chocolately brown. Very little head, which dissipates quickly.  S - Smells of chocolate, bread, some hops. Definitely malt foward.  T - Tastes different than it smells. The wood character is very prevalent, but does not dominate the flavor. Lots of roasty flavors; coffee and chocolate. The alcohol is very prevalent in the aftertaste. I was surprised by the alcohol flavor until I saw that this was a 12% ABV beer!  M - Thick and velvety. Carbonation is very low.
