Overall, I had one of these when it was fresh and a little bit of age surely does this one justice! The alcohol eased up a bit and the flavors have melded together very nicely. A better beer at 6 months and a great beer in general.

I had this in bottle. aged 6 months. thanks, Cuz for letting me try it!  it pours a deep dark brown with a gorgeous light brown head. it smells rich of vanilla and something dark and fruity. leaves a good amount of lace and legs when swirled. the smell also greatly increases. the taste is sweet and smooth with the vanilla, chocolate and what tastes like liquorice mix then leave you with a nice bitter ending. the mouthfeel is super smooth though somewhat oily. Haven't had this one fresh, but aged 6 months is very very good.

Bottles: 12/28/09 Drank: 5/13/11  12oz bottle into a DFH Sniffer - this is a 1st time brew for me. After many rave reviews from friends and BA's alike, I finally decided to pop one of these open today w/ lunch. It's my birthday and I'm 'working from home'...  A = deep, dark brown pour. like a coffee or dark porter in appearance. thick, creamy tan head (2 fingers) that sticks around. good lacing and carbonation on this one for a 2+ yr old brew.  S = sweet malts and smokey wood flavors. i love the smell of this - faint alcohol  T = strong alcohol on the palette. sweet chocolate and fig flavors. as it warms the flavors become much more complex and flavorful. Smokey wood flavors and sweet caramels lace each sip/drink. I'm loving the taste of this beer!  M = medium to full. good carbonation. not too dry.  O = I loved this! easily up there in the top 2 or 3 from DFH for me. Actually, I'd put this in a 2 way tie with Bitches Brew. Both are complex beers, w/ wonderful flavor...not saying they are the same (or even similar) in any way the same but they do share similar qualities. I'd like another but should keep the mid-day 12% brews at a distance.  Cheers ~ !

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a Unibroue tulip.  A: Dark brown color, one finger of dark tan head with good retention and some dark lace.  S: Spicy dark fruits with roasted malts in the background. Also a bit of dark red wine.  T: Spicy sweet chocolate and more wine notes. Finish has a hint of dry wood. Some roasted coffee under that, fruit notes are elusive but present. As the beer warms, the fruit comes more into play, and the spiciness of the finish becomes more pronounced. Later on, a thin layer of light molasses and toffee. Alcohol is present but integrated, not boozy.  M: Surprisingly light and creamy, very smooth as it glides across the tongue.  O: Wonderful, delicious beer. Taking a brown ale to this height without falling apart or exhibiting flaws is a real accomplishment. Well done!

A - pours a thick viscous deep dark brown about as close to black as you can get, opaque. Is it fair to call this a brown? 2 fingers of light coffee fluffy head that recedes a little then just sits leaving its tracks down the glass.  A - Roasted malts, dark chocolate, vanilla. i get a hint of the wood but not much. God i can feel the heat coming  T - Strong vanilla flavors, of course the BIG roasted malt flavors. More of the woodiness than in the aroma, sweet brown sugar. This is a big beer the alcohol is present and very warming. complex but in a expected way and not messy even with the heat. Oak aftertaste that lingers a while with hints of dark chocolate. I didn't get a strong coffee or sweet toffee that others may get, not sure.  M - on the "brown" scale this brew is heavy, on the stout scale it's medium to heavy, carbonation is medium and sort of takes away from its creamy possibilities. the alcohol along with the carbonation create a palate numbing feel. upon temperature increase the numbing goes away and this brew becomes much more creamy.  O - i have been enjoying this brew for a while now, and it continues to grow on me every time. I love it and it has earned a permanent residence in my beer fridge. i do wish the carbonation was a bit less but other than that, I love lamp. As it warms it improves dramatically. Drinkability hard to determine

Just did not like this beer at all. Poured a thick, dark, sludgy black color with an off-white head that quickly dissipated. Smells like...wood and alcohol. You can't really get a sense of the malts or hops in my opinion, and I was not impressed by this beer, especially for the style. Tasted like I was licking a piece of freshly cut wood. Not cool. Mouthfeel was thick and unpleasant. DFH has much, much better offerings!

RR 'tion glass.  Pours a stout-like coffee brown with a thin cap of foam which dissipates pretty quickly. Lacing is minimal. Nose is not at all what I was expecting: a strong candied banana and marshmallow (?), which recedes to the secondary as it warms, transitioning closer to the usual coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, plus some fruitiness. Taste is similar, with now some caramel and some astringent oakey dryness. Other than this, the oak is not at all evident. A nice medium-full body with a fitting high carbonation, with some but not a ton of heat. Overall, I'm a little ambivalent: this was interesting and unexpected, but I'm not sure I would reach for another.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle from 10/13/10. Last bottle from the 8 that I bought, and cellered since purchase.  A- Pours deep dark chocolatey brown... thick tan head that doesn't want to leave. Lacing drips down the sides leaving a sweet and sticky lacing.  S- Vanilla, sweet toffee and licorice twists. Buttered popcorn? Lovely hints of charred wood, hot cocoa, toasted mixed nuts (hazelnuts, pecans, and Brazil nuts mostly), figs and dried plums, and banana. The nose tells me this should be a stout... deep, robust, dark and mysterious. I remember this smelling great when I first bought it... but this is rediculous!!!  T- Charred, toasty wood... vanilla, licorice dried fruit, ripe banana and roasted nuts just as the nose dictates!!! Nice alcohol finish, but it doesn't burn... it just explodes with layer after layer of flavor!!! Mouthfeel of an ale... with the bold taste of a stout!  M- Sweet, sticky, woody, alcoholic... yet fruity! Certainly not a stout, but damn if it doesn't wanna be! Absolutely delicious!!!  O- Brilliant!!! (insert standing ovation!) This is one of DFH's finest, and being that it's a year round brew... I can't wait for it to show up on shelves near me again soon!!!

12 oz, bottled on 2/22/11 into a snifter.  A: Pours a rather dark mahogany with a small egg white head that dissipates slowly. Darker than I was expecting.  S: Roasty malts, some sweet licorice, tobacco leaf, molasses, slight hint of dark candied fruits, dried figs. Some coffee as it warms, and the fruits become more and more prominent and berry-like.  T: Lots of dark fruits, but still pretty bitter from the wood. Strong wood presence, tobacco leaf-like again. Maple syrup. Fairly spicy. Very subtle smokiness throughout. Very earthy, extremely pleasant aftertaste. Wet soil.  M: Somewhat sharp, which I tend to get from barrel/wood aged beers. Dry. Well hidden alcohol, nice low carbonation.  O: I thoroughly enjoyed this beer - there are certainly some very strong flavors that I could imagine being perceived in many ways, but it worked for me (though did become slightly overwhelming by the end). I love all the earthy notes that come from the wood and for all of the flavors it was extremely well balanced.

Have had this one so many times, but after having a 6 month old bottle last night, I decided to take notes this time. 12 oz. bottle dated 12/6/2010 into the weird glasses they have at Smokin' Joe's...  A - Pours a dark, rick, mahogany brown color. Even a vigorous pour left very little head. The head that did form was a medium tan color about .5 fingers thick.  S - Wood, dark roasted malts, some dark fruits, and brown sugar all up front. Get hints of molasses, some caramel and a little hint of vanilla. The wood really makes its presence known here.  T - Earthy wood flavor mixed with sweet caramel, vanilla, dark roasted malts and some dark fruits. Chocolate and coffee peek out after those flavors as well as some smokiness, molasses and brown sugar. Really a complex flavor and very well done.  M - Medium to heavy bodied with a very nice compmentary carbonation. Creamy and smooth. Very nice feel on the tongue  O - I have loved this beer since it came out and am so glad that it is in the regular line-up. Such a great concept for a beer and one that actually comes all the way out in the beer itself.

12oz Bottle  Appearance - Dark black/brown colour with an average size frothy brown coloured head. It’s too dark for me to see the carbonation levels and there is some fantastic lacing. The head lasted for around 4 minutes before it was gone.  Smell - Malts, breads/grains, chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, wood  Taste & Mouth - There is a below average amount of carbonation and the most noticeable flavours are malts, chocolate, and coffee. Also, I was surprised as to how much of the wood flavour I could pick up on. It really stood out – in a good way. There were also some notes of dark fruits and at first I could really taste the alcohol. The beer finishes with a chocolaty and malty aftertaste with a lingering wood flavour.  Overall – Just a superbly well crafted and well balanced beer. It falls into the category of a “must try” beer in my opinion.

Appearance - extremly dark like a fresh shot of esspesso that is topped off by a mildly tan head.  Smell - Very sweet fig/date like in aroma, with a touch of spicy cinnamon notes. Then at the end you are hit with a nice earthy mild hop sensation.  Tates - Extremely bold with a nice roasted malt flavor, a hint of smoke and wood taste but not over powering, finishes off with a nice coffee, with a slight chocolate covered cherry after taste.  Mouthfeel - Heavy bodied, leaves the mouth feeling dry after taking a sip, nice bubbly carbination sensation as it hits your mouth.  Drinkability - Great comfort beer, nice warming feeling goes with this beer, would be great on a cold night (Have to get some for the winter) Goes awesome with a scoop of vanilla bean ice cream.

There's something evil about this beer, in that you don't know quite what you're about to get until you pour it into your glass and you see the devil. It was thick brown/black, like 10W30 oil, with a head that once you got it out was a cap. The smell was powerful good, something from a wonderful beer dream...forget the fizzy lager smell you associate with beer and take a giant whiff of this potent mamma. Roasted malt and alcohol were present, along with what seemed like dark fruits. The flavor was also roasty with a warming alcohol, and finished with a long lingering burnt sugar. Very thick in the mouth and down the gullet, not something you'd want to (or be able to) have a 6'er of anytime. Overall I'd say aside from the thick feel, this beer is something to save when you have no heavy machinery to operate anytime soon. A very good experience.

Poured into a tulip. This one pours a dark brown with about an inch of light tan head. Sticky lace. This one looks dark; looks more like a porter than a brown.  Somewhat smokey wood aroma comes through right awaay. A little bit bitter in the aroma with a little bit of toasty cocoa. It's all there but it seems very weak in the nose. Smokey caramel flavors come through with a little bit of cocoa. Very charred flavor here that seems to give a little soured flavor to the finish.  This one is a very thick and heavy with soft carbonation. Not bad here, I think there are other browns I would pick over it but a unique beer worth trying.

First had: ? (possibly on tap at Pinocchio's, Media, PA)  Poured a dark, opaque brown with very little head. Sweet malts in the nose, with a bit of hoppiness coming through. More malts in the taste, with some nuttiness and caramel, with a tinge of dark fruits evident in the background. Medium mouthfeel, and fairly drinkable. I'm not a huge fan of brown ale, and this one wasn't too memorable.

A- Pours dark brown/black with little head that doesn't last long.  S- Aroma is very roasty and spicy.  T- It tastes very sweet with a lot of spices and roasted malt flavors. The alcohol is right up front and has a nice warming effect.  M- It was thick and coated the mouth.  O- A solid beer with a lot of complex spicy and roasty flavors. Aging it on the wood gave it some really nice characteristics.

A: The darkest brown ale I've ever seen. Decent looking head but not much of it.  S: Vinous roasted malt.  T: Alcohol is huge, seems to be the most dominant characteristic. Otherwise rich and roasty with notes of dark fruit. A little too brash.  I like what they were trying to do, they just went a bit overboard. Then again, that might be precisely what they were trying to do. It's a decent sipper anyway.

This was a powerful beer, giving me an instant headache from all the smoke and spice - but in a good way, like some holiday porters do, y'know? It had sweetness to it, but also a spiced bitterness that worked to really cover up the 12% factor - I really couldn't tell it was that high of an ABV. I had it on tap a few weeks later at Howie & Sons, and it tasted pretty much the same as it did in the bottle. The color is beautiful with little head and it is fairly viscous, but somehow that didn't bother me because it had enough spice to brighten it up.

This does not taste like a brown ale per se - if anything it should be called a black ale. It pours thick and dark with very little head. It reminds me more of a porter than a brown ale. It has heavy chocolate and fig overtones with a slight hop finish. I have never tasted anything like it. It is not too sweet and not all too dry. There is a strong alcohol presence but not in the least bit over powering (unlike the strong Bastard American ales, of which I am not a big fan). This is a great beer and one that is definitely worth a try.

It pours very dark and thick into the glass. The smell is a strong liquorice and leaves a mocha foam that dissipates quickly. The first taste has some sweetness and dark fruit, but it mellows out and finished slightly dry with a nice roastiness. The alcohol is hidden by lots of flavor, but this is a big beer. Interesting and well balanced.

I picked up a bottle of Palo Santo Marron for $3.79 at The Lager Mill. I have been starting to like Dogfish Head lately and thought it was time to try one of their big guns. I have never had a Brown Ale that was this strong so we'll see how it goes. Bottled on December 6, 2010. Poured from a 12oz brown bottle into my mini snifter.  A- The label looks OK and I like the wooden theme going on with this bottle. It poured a super deep dark brown color that was on the edge of being black that had the slightest bit of ruby edges when held to the light. It had a fingers worth of tan colored head that died down to a really thin ring.  S- The first thing that stuck out to me about the aroma was the large presence of dark fruits, it's reminiscent of a strong doppelbock. There was some nice roasty aromas along with smoke and wood. It smells boozy but for 12% thats to be expected. I would have liked it to have more smoke and wood aromas to balance out the dark fruits.  T- Wow there is a lot of things going on with this brew, the flavor is really complex. It starts out with some nice sweet lightly roasted malts that impart a nice molasses like flavor along with some grainy earthyness. The dark fruits are toned down, which I was hoping for. The smokey wood is right where I like it and works nicely with the light amount of dark fruits. There is some slight bitterness on the finish and some warming alcohol, which was masked very well.  M- Full bodied with a semi dry finish and it had an average amount of carbonation and I thought it could have used just a little more.  Overall I thought this was a very good and unique brew, really different from your typical American Brown Ale, I never see one this strong. From my experience it seems like Dogfish Head has a thing for making unique and extreme Brown Ales, you usually don't see much creativity with this style. To me it seems like Shorts and Dogfish Head are leading the way in making unique browns, I like it. The taste of this beer was pretty good and complex, the Palo Santo wood imparted some nice flavors that I liked and I thought they worked very well with this beer. For being 12% this beer is dangerously drinkable, they did a great job at toning down the booze and making this seem much lighter then it really is. I would buy a four pack of this too keep in the fridge. If you like browns but want something bigger and unique, give this a try, you might be surprised. This was another great beer from Dogfish Head, you guys keep on impressing me.

For some reason I was expecting a more dark amber color than an almost black. Don't know why. This was a pleasant surprise. The deep deep brown indicated that this was going to be something more than I expected.  The smell was typical for heavy beer of 12% ABV. Lots of alcohol, but there was also that smokey palo santo wood smell that I love. Wish it was more the wood, but the taste more than made up for it.  The wooden and smokey front of the beer did not, as I was afraid of, turn into a sweet, alcohol burn in the back. The taste was hops and malt, blending together beautifully with the taste of palo santo wood. One of the best tasting beers I've ever had. I know, a bold claim, but it ranks with Alaskan Smoked Porter and my first taste of craft beer (Fat Tire) in terms of how excited I am about what I'm drinking in the moment.  Smooth and slightly carbonated. A little bit of a bite at the back, but not much.  Overall, I'd say this is my favorite beer out of Dogfish Head. I love their 90 minute, but this is just so unique and different.

This beer has serious wood flavor, not to mention a very high alcohol level. I am an avid DH Indian Brown Ale drinker so I had to try this, but prefer the original. Would definetly order again though since I don't find often at bars. Plus with twice the alcohol it could save some cash.

A - Opaque, dark, dark brown. It doesn't look quite black, but no light shines through. A small amount of dense, creamy, tan head that drops some but leaves tons of lacing (is it called lacing if it's a solid layer?) on the glass.  S - Lots of caramel mixed into roasty malts and some coffee, with a bit of something else which I assume is that Palo Santo wood, perhaps?  T - Whoa, that's complex. I need another sip to get my bearings.  mm... that's better. Very sweet, dark maltiness: dark fruit, caramel, coffee roastiness, altogether quite nice. The whole thing is hard to describe, though, because of an unusual sort of acidity that confounds the taste buds at first sip and tickles them throughout, making this rather heavy, sweet beer feel light as it dances across your tongue. At the finish, I get a better picture of that slightly indescribable taste which I haven't met in any other beer -- it must be the Palo Santo wood. Nutty, woody, acidic, weird, tasty.  M - Thick and creamy, but the touch of acidity seems to prevent it from being cloying. The alcohol is noticeable, but blends in. Quite a good balance.  Overall, this is great. One of my favorite from Dogfish Head, and a wonderful, unique beer all-around.

12 oz. bottle bottled on 12/06/10 - Had 4/21/11..  - Dark jet brown brew.. minimal dark root beer brown head.. quickly down to just a small ring and some scattered traces of foam. Super dark mahogany red/brown..  - Sweet, woody, salty.. smoked.. brown sugar.. molasses.. certainly an earthy woody presence... almost cedar-like..  - Great sweet molasses malts, earthy woody flavor.. light fig, esters... smokey wood.. certainly a great beer. So far the best I have had from Dogfish Head.. my favorite of them thus far. Wish more of their beers were like this.  - Medium bodied.. not too chewy at all.. sticky sweet.  - Overall I am impressed. This is certainly another to buy again. I openly admit I am not the biggest fan of this brewery... but this one changes my mind.. a little ;) Go get it!

Dark dark brown, big cocoa brown head, just too dark to be a brown ale and I LOVE it.  Sweet caramel, vanilla, oak, and candy just an amazing mix.  This isn’t a stout, it isn’t a brown ale so I’m a bit lost. It is however simply amazing. I’ve loved this beer since it first came out. I loved it fresh, loved it aged, loved it on tap. Finally, taking the time to review it and well it’s hard to review. Sweet candy flavors, woody flavors, honey, yet strong impressive hops to keep things from being too sweet.  Thick, creamy, well carbonated, and just perfect for what ever this is.  I think Baton Burton is dogfish’s best beer, but this is a very close second. These guys made me a beer lover, and this is proof I was right to follow their ways.

Out of the bottle and into a Stone RIS glass  A- Average for a brown ale. Dark brown with ruby edges. A nice small head with good lacing.  S- Vanilla, roastiness, and a tiny bit of wood. I head this beer was an amazing smell like walking into Home Depot. lol. So, a little disappointing on the smell, but it is nice.  T- The taste is borderline porter or stout....which are generally my favorite styles. I'm loving the taste of this brew. Major roast and vanilla and dark fruit dominance. Hint of wood on the tongue to take you another direction. And a great bitter dry roast finish. Also, a satisfying warm alcohol presence, but not hot. Seems pretty complex to my palate.  M- Medium to heavy body. Creamy. Perfectly carbonated. Thin finish mouthfeel on the finish though. Interesting.  O- Great beer. Seems a bit more like a porter or stout to me. But, still a great beer. At 12% though...

Pours almost black, but you can see a bit of dark ruby at the edges. Forms a little bit of a brown head which quickly faded to some nice lacing.  Somewhat sweet smell, with notes of coffee and chocolate, and a little woody in there as well.  Nicely complex beer, I'd rate this among the most complex I've tried. There's coffee and chocolate in there, as well as caramel. I can also detect some fruit, maybe plum. Nice finish, not bitter as expected, but I think I'm detecting the wood notes.  Nicely solid, this one lets you know it's a serious beer.  This one reminds me a lot of a bourbon barrel aged beer, but less bitter. It has a sweetness I wouldn't have expected from how dark this beer is. It does have a big of an alcohol burn to it. and the high ABV makes this one a sipper, but a really nice beer. Glad I took a chance on it.

Pours a very dark coffee brown, barely any light coming through, even at the edges. Limited dark tan head that lasts and lasts. Looks like a stout. Streams of bubbles rising along the edges of the glass.  Wow, smell that wood. Vanilla comes through loud and clear, but is well-supported by abundant caramel sweetness from the malts. A bit of bubblegum-like fruity aroma. There's a lot there, but it's all in great balance. A hint of booze, but not much.  The dominant flavors are a rich roasted malt sweetness and that woody vanilla. The malts come through much darker and more chocolatey than they did in the smell, where I mostly got caramel. These two flavors (roasted malt and wood) kinda bounce back and forth, with a bit of hop bitterness coming in late to try to fight its way past them. These three maintain an impressive balance. Amazing that 12% alcohol isn't more evident in the taste. There is no booziness to this at all, just some solid warmth in the finish. As it warms up a bit, the alcohol is more apparent, but still surprisingly limited.  Mouthfeel is heavy and thick, but not syrupy, with medium-low carbonation (just enough to moderate the thickness). Kinda fluffy, actually.  This is a really really delicious beer. Rich dark malts, wood, a bit of fruit. It's shockingly un-boozy for the ABV. And just like that, my glass is empty. As with some of my other favorite "brown ales", it pushes the boundary between this style and porters/stouts. Shortly after Dogfish Head officially pulled out of Wisconsin, I passed up a 4-pack of this on a trip over there. I'm really regretting that now.

I wasn't sure what to expect from this beer. A few friends had this one prior to me obtaining one and said they were not very impressed. I am an avid fan of DFH beers so I had to make my own decision on this beer when I saw it in the cooler while getting a mix-o-six.  Appearance - Poured dark with a medium/fair amount of head  Smell - Wood and alcohol is the impression that hit me the hardest  Taste - Bitter. Can't really explain it more than that.  Mouthfeel - Reminded me of cough syrup. I like the tast of cough syrup, but did not like this beer.  Overall - Not very pleasing. The pour looked good and smelled ok, but I did not enjoy the taste at all. I had a hard time finishing this one, and poured out the last inch or so of my glass down the drain. I usually like the DFH beers, but this one left me a bad taste in my mouth (pun intended!)

Appearance: Black, opague no light shines through when held up to the light. Thick tan head lingers but eventually dissipates leaving some lacing on the sides.  Smell: cherries is what immediately comes to mind, followed by dark fruits some slight alcohol notes as well  Taste: Brown sugar and some alcohol warmth. The fruit notes from the aroma are there but subdued. Some slight smokiness from the wood that lingers as the beer is swallowed.  Mouthfeel: It's got a full rounded mouth feel. Not light, but definitely not syrupy thick either. The carbonation is moderate and definitely helps keep the mouthfeel substantially rounded.  Drinkabillity: Dangerous. I wouldn't be pounding these back all night, but at 12% it's dangerously drinkable. It's not quite the palate wrecker that some beers this caliber and strength are though so you could theoretically transition to lighter fare if you'd care to.

Lucky find on at my local beer store that sells a pint. Thisone, 10 oz pils glass being higher abv.  Dark black apperance, no light gettn threw thisone. Tan/ brown head, nice thick lace.  Full bodied, complex well balanced brew. Malts of toasted goodness, roasted brown sugars and toffee, caramel all while keeping the alcohol at bay. Not boozy  A great sipper or desert brew. Though Id like this round after round, that could be trouble.

Appearance: Thick and dark; light doesn't even pass through this beer. Topped with a thin cap of tan head.  Aroma: Dark roasted malt with a lot of estery alcohol and brown sugar swirled in and some funky, earthy notes mixed in there too.  Taste: Thick and syrupy sweet, but quickly followed by a very astringent roasted flavor that cuts the sweetness without totally masking it. Some hop bitterness rides the tale end of that leading into a bitter, soapy finish that is luckily pretty fast.  The Rest: Body is very full. Another very unusual one from DFH. I'd put this in the same category as ApriHop and Midas. All very interesting beers, but not ones I really feel the need to try again. Although, if I was offered one of these three, I think I would go with the Palo Santo.

Revisited just last night  Bottle from Triboro Ice Co. and poured into Spiegelau tulip.  Young man I do say, gatdam! There are countless reviews about how incredible this beer is, but hell here is another.  To call this a brown ale, not so sure but to call it an out of this world rare wood aged beer is an understatement to boot.  This complex and spot on ale hits the spot everytime. 12% doesn't even leave a trace. So do yourself a favor and go pick some up today!

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass  A: Pours nearly black and completely opaque. There is a foamy tan head with good retention and light lacing.  S: The smell is smoky and strong. I caught a huge whiff just opening the bottle. There are notes of vanilla, coffee and caramel. The flavor from the Palo Santo wood really comes through; very earthy and natural.  T: The first sensation upon tasting is similar to any brown ale. There is a caramel sweetness but this quickly gives way to an explosive range of flavors. Caramel and mocha are strong flavors. I can also make out a faint brandy/cherry taste. The wood flavor is noticeable and lends a spicy, earth tone to the drink. It’s hard to miss the taste of alcohol, but it complements the overall flavor well. The aftertaste is long and bitter.  M: Comparable to many stouts, it is thick and smooth with little carbonation. The high alcohol content is as noticeable here as in the taste, but this is hardly a problem.  O: A complex and potent brown ale.

A- Dark, Dark Brown. Almost black, but not quite. Completely opaque with basically no light penetration. Ok head retention for a beer with this weight. Not a lot of lacing.  S- Deep, woody, earthy, and somewhat alcoholic. Muted smell (I did have a slight case of nasal congestion, which could have changed my senses a bit). The best way to describe it was a leathery, woody smell. Very natural.  T- Standard brown ale "sweetness". Soon after the sip, the depth of the wood used in the brewing becomes evident. Slight fruitiness with a burnt aftertaste. Almost a porter-like quality of flavor depth.  M- Heavy, thick, and demanding. Definitely a sipping beer. Took me the better part of an hour to get the whole thing down, which was actually very pleasant.  O- Awesome beer. A bit heavy for most, but personally I would love to have 1 of these rather than 2 or 3 of another beer. Not for the light-palated.

4-pack purchased for $12.99. Bottled in September. Poured into snifter.  Appearance – Pours black with no light penetrating the edges. Good head that shows some retention, which is surprising considering the weight of this beer.  Smell – Explosions of dark fruit, licorice, caramel , and vanilla atop a backdrop of soft wood. Similar to the character that oak-aging would give a beer, but still different.  Taste – Intense and rich malt sweetness upfront. The taste is defined by a bold oak-like character, obviously from the unique Palo Santo wood used to craft this brew. This wood flavor seems to soften a bit as this beer ages. Dark fruits, vanilla, and licorice accent the bold sweetness and the wood gives this beer a pleasant dry finish. Alcohol is well integrated and adds a punch of head to the finish.  Mouth Feel – Full-bodied and supremely smooth.  Drinkability – A smooth sipper. Mysteriously complex and expertly crafted.

On Tap  Churchill's Pub & Grille San Marcos, CA  A rich and dark chocolate brown with a very thin head. Sheets of lacing running down the glass.  Rich aroma of sweet malt, roasted malt, and some caramel. A bit of chocolate and woodiness as well. No alcohol present in the nose, which is remarkable for a beer of this ABV.  A rich flavor of freshly baked bread, some chocolate, and roasted malts. A complex and interesting version of a terrific American brown ale. Again, no alcohol present at all, which is a wonderful surprise.  Full, creamy, and rich mouthfeel.  A truly terrific brown ale. I can't comment on how much the aging from the wood barrels has improved or changed this beer, but it's certainly good as is!

Sampled from a 12 oz. brown glass bottle, very cold from the fridge in a standard pint glass.  A: Pours a rich dense brown beer color. Head was only slight and retention was minimal with only faint lacing. Typical of higher alcohol beers.  S: Smell was sweet, with vanilla and brown sugar notes on the nose. Smelled like an apricot sugar cookie.  T: Very pleasant. Nice hops balance to the sugar malts. Reminiscent of an American strong ale. Didn't get a lot of smokiness from the wood processing advertised on the bottle, but what I did get was a rich cherry flavor. Alcohol content wasn't noticeable until the last drop, then the warming kicked in.  M: Very pleasing beer to drink. Hops provided plenty of dried fruity flavor depth without much bitterness at all. Two of these and you're schnockered, so be respectful.  O: I'd consider this one to be the little brother of Worldwide Stout. It's a little more enjoyable than the stout to the average joe, as it's not as alcoholic and sweet, so it'll match better to a wider variety of occasions and meals.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into my Great Divide Brussels glass.  Beer pours a deep black with a thin wisp of brown head that dissipated quickly but produced some good lacing. I held the glass up to the light to see if any light would escape. None did. Looks more like a stout than a brown ale.  Smell starts with burnt sugar, caramel, and a touch of roasted malts. It opens up with some smoky wood notes and hops bitterness. A nice smelling beer.  Taste is intensely complex. Starts out with roasted malt sweetness and a touch of alcohol warmth and ends with with some hops bitterness and sharp wood notes. Each layer of flavor builds on the one preceding it. A wonderfully tasting beer.  Mouthfeel is thick and stouty, a touch sticky and quite viscous.  Drinkability is great for 12% abv. You only pick up a touch of booziness. Palo Santo Marron is definitely an end of the evening sipper and a good one at that.

A: Viscous, burnt umber. Thin beige head. Impenetrable.  S: Smoky wood, vanilla and caramel. Malts. Hops?  T: Vanilla, caramel. Dark chocolate, creamy and bready. So good. Bitter, but get sweeter at the end of each sip. Delicious.  M: Creamy and smooth. So silky and wonderful.  O: Didn't even realize it was 12% until I read AgentMunky's review. And I agree with him. Dangerously drinkable. Highly recommended.

A- pitch black with a light creamy coffee chocolate head.  S- Wow i smelled it the moment i opened it. Strong toasted malts, almost like a nice stout.  T- This is a very strong beer, and not my spacific type. But its well done and shows quality and i respect that.  M- Feels like a stout to me.  D- Well done beer by dogfish. Not the most drinkable beer tho.

A: Pitch black with a creamy tan head. It appears completely opaque. The lacing sticks to the side with a step-like effect. It is about average, because it doesn't have any unique changes in color in the beer and the head isn't the strongest. I score it above average because of the lacing.  S: It has a rum-like smell with a sweet spiciness. It has a light cola-like smell. There is a light woody smell but it doesn't have any pungency or earthiness. It smells very similar to a sweet stout.  T: Pow! It has a very strong flavor right as soon as it hits the tongue. It's very smooth. The flavor has vanilla, rum, roasted grain, and is insanely rich. It has an oakiness but is lighter. It's very flavorful and has a spicy flavor that balances out the bitterness. I can taste the alcohol some but it really isn't overpowering.  M: The mouthful is excellent. The beer is so smooth and rich. It is malty without being too sticky.  O: Overall I would say that this is a very nice beer. I enjoyed the spicy notes in the beer which gave it more character. It's 12% and it doesn't overpower the flavor which is awesome. I can't give it 5.0 but it was really close.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into my Dogfish Head snifter. Minimal lacing and excellent head. Pours a deep dark maroon/brown. Aroma is slightly medicinal, of some licorice, cherries, chocolate, wood, and vanilla. Tastes of chocolate, cherries, vanilla, slightly medicinal and metallic, and woody (Palo Santo?). Excellent lingering aftertaste. This is one of DFH's best.

Solid brown in color. Rich and dark looking. A nice brown cap of suds that reduces down. Nice bit of lacing.  Sweet and rich malt smell with undertones of wood and alcohol.  Huge sweet malty taste with warm alcohol and toasted wood. Caramelized sugar, toffee and a touch of peat malt. Quite complex and warming.  Full bodied and smooth. The carbonation is maybe a touch low, but it is soft what remains. Sticky finish.  A very nice beer that would go well with dessert or sitting by a fire on a crisp evening.

Poured into a pint glass. This is a brown ale? It looks more like a stout. It's brown as it can be without being black. It produced a one finger, lasting head. The smell was typical brown ale plus some added alcohol, and a little extra fruitiness. The taste-sweet, alcohol, woody, low hops, thick mouth-feel. Not a beer I drink regularly, but it's decent enough to try again.

As a Stout lover I was intrigued by this strong Brown Ale. The color is black, even when held into the light, with a brown creamy head about three fingers high. It dissipates fast. The smell is very unique. You can smell the Palo Santo wood , caramel , coffee, honey and chocolate and hint of cherry. Tasting this beer, the fruity flavor off cherry and dark chocolate, caramel and honey will meet you, quickly being held up by a distinct wood flavor and malty qualities. At the end coffee and bitter hops balance the whole composition. The beer certainly contains alcohol and will let you know it right away. Yet it is very drinkably and is therefore of the dangerous kind. I love this beer and certainly will recommend it as a secret specialty, because a specialty it is. I really start to like the experimentations of Dogfish. Great job.

Drinking this beer was an awesome experience but one I would never want to necessarily experience again. I bought a 4 pack with a friend which was fairly expensive.  Upon pouring it I was extremely impressed with the dark color, creamy brown head, and intriguing smell.  The taste was strange. It wasn't a conventional beer by any stretch of the word. I tasted a almost licorice type of flavor with strong cedar and vanilla aftertastes. It tasted almost like some sort of magic Paraguayan elixir rather than a beer.  The alcohol content was high! It burned on the way down, and had me slurring my speech within two beers.  Like watching some sort of strange independent film, this beer was certainly an interesting experience, but not one that I would necessarily sit down and drink again.  But don't worry Sam, we get it. You are a pioneer in your field, seeking new and innovative beer flavors. I respect that, and appreciate your contributions!

A: deep chocolate brown, shimmer of black, 1 finger oatmeal head  S: big smokey, boozy, caramel, hint of vanilla, wood  T: sweet wood, mild smoky boozy finish  M: med/heavy body, slick/oily feel, smooth, chewy  O: POW! This delicious boozy Brown beast is soooo good. Dogfish Head has wowed me again. Big sipper and I'm thrilled to see someone take one of my favorite styles, brown ale, and just explore.  YOU MUST TRY THIS, BUT GO SLOW!!

A: A Near pitch black color, with a small tan head that dissipates quickly.  S: Strong deep spicy aroma with hints of dark fruits, vanilla, and caramel.  T: Tastes of sweet chocolate cake with some cedar notes in between the alcohol blaze.  M: The body is full and creamy with lighter carbonation and a long roasted and vanilla finish.  Overall this is a solid beer. A definite sipper due to the richness and high alcohol content at 12%.

Poured from an old bottle, into a schooner. This has been sitting down in a fridge for 2 years! Bottling date is 04/07/09. It seems like it's stood the test of time successfully.  A - deep black, small tan head disappears after a minute with no lacing. Pitch back with no light transmission whatsoever.  S - lots of vanilla on the nose with some caramel malts.  T - licorice, molasses, hint of smoke, along with the wood/vanilla from the nose. A foundation of caramel malty sweetness provide a nice background. I had a bottle from the same set 1 year ago and it was definitely rawer around the edges with a lot of booziness; much smoother now.  M - still well carbonated with medium body. Gives the entire mouth a nice slick coating. Moderate, but not excessive alcohol warming.  D - could maybe do a second one of these, but that would be the end of the evening!  Stunning drink after sitting down for a long, long time. It's definitely held up after resting for a couple years!

A: It's pretty much black with a 1 finger, deep brown head that leaves just a film on the top.  S: It smells of caramel and sugar cookie. There's also some chocolate notes. The alcohol isn't overpowering at all.  T: OK, the alcohol is overpowering. I don't get the toasted malt that I was expecting, just a bitter/metallic flavor. I do sense the sugar  M: There isn't a stickiness to the finish, however as soon as I sip, I want to swallow. The mild carbonation doesn't help this.  O: I'm pretty dissapointed by DFH's effort on this one. This isn't a multi-dimensional brew and leaves quite a bit to be desired.

I can't lie. I'm not man enough to handle this. The boozy ether flavor is way too strong. It tastes like a stout with a shot of scotch in it. The smell is great, looks great (ultra dark), no head, good mouthfeel. The taste of bitters plus malty booze is overpowering. I bought a 6 pack, I don't know when I can finish this.

Imagine my surprise when I opened up this bottle and poured out a stream of inkly blackness. When I held it up to the light it was a decided Mahogany, but still waaaay darker than any Brown Ale that I've had.  The smell was roast and sweet. Almost fruity.  The taste was a bit on the sweet side for my palate. Dark fruits and molasses dominated it for me. As a representation of the style it was decidedly lacking. As a stand alone beer it was better, which is why I didn't kill it with my rating.  Mouthfeel was cloying sweetness and thick. Almost like a Quad.  Overall, I think I was distracted by the fact that this beer was allegedly a brown ale. I didn't find it to be similar to any brown I have had, but it was still pretty good.

One of the first craft beers I have tried. I figured I owed this one a review.  Bottled on 09/10/2010  Pours a deep brown, near black with a big soapy tan head. Smells of dark pitted fruits, molasses, bananas and cloves. Slight woody/vanilla notes as well. Big caramel malt sweetness, brown bread, figs, chocolate and vanilla/wood. Alcohol well perceived, but doesn't distract from the brew. Finishes very sweet and sticky. Full bodied mouthfeel with moderate-to-low carbonation. I haven't had this beer in a long time, and I must say it is much better than I remembered. Very solid brew.

From bottle to Odell tulip, bottled on 11/11/10.  Pours dark, black in fact some ruby/purple highlights, with a two finger mocha head that is frothy with heavy lacing. A brief, hypnotizing cascade effect but really dark for a brown ale.  Powerful and complex aroma, roasted malts, not much smoke or coffee but chocolate, syrup, molasses, cherries, tart grapes and a touch of vanilla. I'm guessing those sweet dessert aromas come from the wood. Breathy alcohol, smells vaguely like a red wine.  Dark fruit figs and plum, rhubarb and earthy spices with a bitter chocolate maltiness. Very little to no hop character, not overly boozy but enough to pull the syrupy sweetness out a little more. Tart finish, slightly sweet and syrup-like, vanilla and some dryness on the back end, to represent the wood character but not enough to overcome the predominant malt.  Rather viscous not overly heavy though, lacking in carbonation but assists with the smooth drink. Alcohol hits with every exposure to air, biting. Needs to mellow down a bit more.  Not really a beer that really fits into a category but it's meant to be off centered right. Rather complex mix of flavors, like a dark earthy dessert. A definite sipper which I feel hurts the drinkability a bit since you get that alcohol kick more often. Bold and uncompromising, a strong ale with good complexity, not the kind of thing you'd want to session but a unique offering.

On tap -> small snifter at Dogfish Head Ale House in Falls Church, MD. My buddy and I had dinner and drinks here before the Mike Gordon Band show at the State Theater. I don't see this one on tap very often up in Baltimore so I had to get it. It's been a few years since I'd last had this brew.  A - Pitch black, fine bubble edged head, little carb, large grouped lacing  S - Sweet, dark roasted, mild minty notes  T - Roasted coffee, cola, rooty, woody and slightly resinous pine notes. Mild versions of all of the initial flavors through the middle finishing tart sour with a mild molasses sweetness.  M - Medium bodied, noticable alcohol warmth  O - This is a very good and unique beer. It's got the color, some notes and mouth feel of a strong stout but with some unique earthy sweet notes. I'd get a few bottles to let sit for a while. I'd also order again on tap, maybe once a year.

355ml brown bottle poured into a Delirium Tremens snifter.  A. A deep brown coloured beer accompanied by a dark tanned, smooth head.  S.Plenty of bitter chocolate and freshly roasted coffee in the nose.  T. Figs, dates, chicory, woody and some port in there too.  M. Full bodied and oily.  D. Deliciously dark beer. Let's you know that it is a BIG boy!! A real pleasure to sample, so glad I have a few more of these to go at.

Served in a Founders tulip from a brown 12 oz. bottle with bottling date of 09-13-10.  As others have said, this is maybe the darkest brown ale out there, a near black beer, with some brown on the edges when held to light. The head is pretty small, maybe 1 finger of tan color, due to the high alcohol content. I get very little lacing.  The smells are very complex. The wood aroma from being aged in wooden barrels is there, along with dark malt notes. I can smell the alcohol even at 6 months of age on this one. Also aromas of raisins and dark fruits, chocolate, vanilla and a smokiness character. Amazing  The taste is exactly like the aroma, big and complex, with a fair amount of alcohol warmth in this strong ale. The malts give a brown bread taste, along with molasses and vanilla, plus dark, ripened fruits.  The mouthfeel is rich and chewy with a full body. The aftertaste is hard to pin down - it has a malty sweetness to it but also a dry alcohol part as well.  This is a wonderful beer. A definite slow-sipper, nightcap kind of beer, due to the richness and high alcohol content.

The beer pours a very dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is very strong and very spicy. I get a lot of woody notes, which I presume is from the Palo Santo wood. I also get some dark fruit notes in the aroma. The flavor is very similar. I get a lot of oaked and wood notes, as well as some caramel and roasted malt, vanilla, spices and dark fruit. The alcohol is definitely present, but it is not overpowering. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very well done beer.

Tasted to me more like an imperial stout than a brown ale. Very hot alcohol taste but not overpowering. I really enjoyed this beer and will have to buy a lot of it up with Dogfish Head not supplying to Wisconsin anymore. Everytime I have had this beer, I wake up in the morning with a really dry mouth. It is probably the high amount of alcohol but it is well worth it.  Further notes-I taste the vanilla for sure. The wood is there as well. I still think the alcohol is hot but this beer is pretty smooth compared to others with that high of an abv.  Further notes take 2-I had a bottle of 2010 and 2008 tonight (3/1/13) for my birthday. Both were very smooth without any hot alcohol taste. I really want a few fresh bottles to compare with these that have some age on them because the alcohol seems to completely have mellowed out. If I had to pick, 2008 was a little better than the 2010 as it had a little bit of sweetness that added a nice element. I have five bottles left of the 2010 and I plan on letting them sit for awhile.

appearance: Beautiful dark brown. Creamy tan head with lots o lacing. smell: Oh, that's the stuff. Woody vanilla, banana, a hint of spice. taste: more goodness. Smooth, spicy, a hint of sweet. mouthfeel: full and creamy. overall: No way i would guess the ABV from the taste. A wonderful concoction. One of my favs. Thank you DFH.

Serving Type - Bottle  Appearance - Dark brown/tan, creamy 1 inch head. Lots of lacing  Smell - Malts, barley, cinnamon and sugars. Dark fruits. Alcohol and hops also present. Alot of armoma  Taste - This monster starts off with fruits, sweet hops, malts, tons of sugar and barley. Plenty of warmth from the booze. Man what a overload of flavors. Plenty of rasin and plum. You are crushed with all the flavors , only at the end you get the wood, oaked flavor. Brown ale? How so? Maybe in color, reminds me much more or a strong ale oak aged. Wow, this is sweet.  Mouthfeel - Really harsh on mouth. So many flavors, but in the end the alcohol is the lasting flavor. Leaves a dry finish on tounge, and a odd fruit flavor in mouth.  Overall - Right on par with other dogfish head beers, too many flavors, too sweet and intense. It almost works but its too much to enjoy. I like the dark fruits in it, but too much alcohol and sugars. I would love to try this again at around 8% and less sweetness. Its not bad, id drink again but nothing to seek out.

A: Pretty much black in color. Not much of a head, just a tiny mocha colored ring along the top.  S: A ton going on here: Coffee, golden raisin, some overripe mango and a little smokiness.  T: Very hard to believe that it's so high in alcohol. A bit syrupy, but this is one delicious beer. It shows some nice hints of the aging in a bit of an earthy/smoky flavor. The finish has a bit of espresso and there's a lot of sweetness upfront in the form of molasses/raisin. Tasty.

Been eyeing this one up for a while now and finally pulled the trigger. Glad I did.  A: So dark brown that I can't see any light coming through - it's brown and murky. Nice tan coffee colored head - 1 inch head that lingers for a while  S: Woody, nutty, earthy, sugar, malt, nice profile  T: Wow, some smoke, wood, malt, booze, pepper, and some dark fruit  M: Medium-high carbonation. Borders on being overcarbonated imo  O: Great sipper - can't get through it quickly but it's good offering from Dogfish Head.

12oz bottle poured into a 3rd. rev Boulevard Smokestack Series tulip. Batch 2 is hand written on the label. Thanks to a great trading partner in MA for this extra!  A: Pours very dark brown and settles completely black with absolutely no penetration of light. For a brown ale, this is as dark as they come (and for many stouts, for that matter). Topped with a small light mocha head that almost doesn't recede at all. A foamy, stick film remains the entire glass. When rolling the glass, the foam coats the side completely, and long legs slowly fall, leaving an impressive display of lacing behind.  S: Holy aroma Dogfish Head! This smells fantastic! Immediately I am hit with bourbon, dark fruit (black cherries and fig), toffee, and wood (I assume Palo Santo, although I wouldn't be able to pinpoint it otherwise). A bit of dark chocolate and roasted malts as well, but they are subtle.  T: Interestingly, the chocolate that was so subtle in the smell is much more dominant in the flavor. It's rich chocolate, almost like letting a bittersweet morsel melt in your mouth. Behind the chocolate are hints of bourbon, toffee, dark fruit, coffee, and roasted malts. Each sip seems to highlight different characteristics, but overall, they are all there working together to produce a very rich, fairly well balance, delicious taste. It finishes with a chocolate and coffee flavor, with just a bit of booze, leaving a very nice warming effect. (As it warms, it becomes pretty hot ... not completely unpleasant, but the alcohol isn't hidden as well as I'd like it to be).  M: The mouthfeel is medium-full. Not sticky at all, but slightly heavy and sits on the tongue. Carbonation is fairly low, but enough to create a smooth creaminess. Slightly drying, mainly from the coffee and the roasted malts, but also from just a bit of hops.  D: Although delicious, not very drinkable. Between the complexity, medium viscosity, and the alcohol content, this is a sipper. It's one that you will really enjoy sipping on, though. I wish I had a few more of these to enjoy on a cool evening.

I was really quite impressed with this, enough to hope others try using this Palo Santo wood too. Poured a slow to emerge 2" head. Looks dark as a black ale. Taste is like an exotic Imperial Stout with vanilla, caramel, coffee, plus what I'd describe as slightly over-ripe canteloupe. Quite rich, and a long finish. I could gladly substitute this for the majority of Imperial Stouts on the market.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle.  A - Dark coffee in color, slight head, mild lacing on the sides of the glass.  S - roasty, figgy, malty  T - lots going on here, get a roasted, malty carmel with some figs and raisins, finish is almost chocolate like.  M - Full bodied, medium carbonation.  D - High ABV is hidden well, good brew to sip, would only want one a session as is very rich in taste and at 12% isn't a beverage I'd want to drink a lot of at one sitting. Another interesting creation from the folks at Dogfish Head.

Poured on tap at Church Key DC 10 oz. into a small snifter.  A dark walnut body is presented, with a very soapy loose head that is sort of a cocoa light brown. Leaves minimal lacing on the glass.  Bouquet is at first a faint wood and roast, but then gives way to salty jerky meats. In the back of my sinus (after a few sips) there are hints of dark chocolate. No hint of a high abv beer to come either. Very nice.  Taste is slightly fizzy at first but also a minor silk feel. This is a tad boozy in taste and sensations, but there is a tannic/wood in the front and middle palate. Some faint anisette on the finish and a tongue numbing sensation. Surprisingly not much roast character to this at all.  Overall this is still quite good and really masks the high abv somewhat too.

12oz bottle, bottled on 8/17/10. Poured into a DFH goblet.  A - Pours a dark black with a thick and luscious head of mocha-colored foam that never fully dissipates, leaving behind sticky lacing as it recedes. Beautiful! S - Huge aromas or dark roasted malt, almost-burnt caramel, vanilla, licorice, and brown sugar. Smells so sweet and rich. T - Very close to the nose, the flavors of dark malt, caramel, vanilla and brown sugar carry through nicely, along with a bit of dark dried fruits like figs or raisins. There is a slight alcohol burn as it works it's way down, the 12% ABV is pretty apparent. M - Pretty sticky and syrupy, definitely full-bodied with low carbonation. D - Not a bad sipper, but this isn't something I can drink much of over a given period. Still, it's nice to keep a sixer around just in case the mood should hit. Finely crafted brew from DFH!

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a stemmed wine glass.  A: Brown ale? How about black ale. I got almost no brown color out of this at all, almost a jet black color with a very slight off white head. No glass lacing.  S: Again, brown ale? I got huge roasted notes on the nose with some chocolate and sugar sweetness. A bit of woody notes are detected too with some licorice.  T: Follow the nose. If I didn't know any better I would bet this was a stout. Huge dark roasted flavor with notes of chocolate, licorice, wood and some smoke. The sugar sweetness is more of brown sugar with some caramel sweetness and maybe some sweeter chocolate. Finish remains sweet and roasty with not much hops and a large alcohol flavor. Roasted flavors linger.  M: Alcoholic, sweet, sticky almost cloying.  D: Oooh, not great. One bottle is way plenty.  Overall another different take on a beer, just like DFH likes to do. This is very different that they get props for that, but it just seems like they tried to hard on this. An ok beer, but I won't seek it out much again. Enjoy in small quantities.

Pours a black (though almost seems a very dark red) with a full finger of tan head, which settles to a thin but full layer quickly.  Smell strongly contains chocolate and sweet malt. Very pleasant.  Taste is great. Sweet malt and dark chocolate are present, as in the nose, but also hints of dark fruit. Alcohol is present, but in a very pleasant way. Finishes slightly bitter. All of this is accompanied by a fairly unique flavour which I imagine is the result of the palo santo wood itself.  As for mouthfeel, the beer is fairly heavy bodied, very smooth, and carbonation is pleasantly mild.  For a 12% beer, this is very very drinkable. However, make no mistake, the booze does start to become noticeable. I wouldn't go through this too quickly.... but it is tasty enough that I have to be careful to take it slowly.

Pours a deep brown, burnt caramel color with a a dk. cream colored head. When it dissipates, it's hard to tell this beer apart from flat cola in a glass. The smell is great, woody, smoky, pipe smoke. The taste is kind of similar, with a hint of roasted dark fruits (cherries, figs). I also love the sweetness of this beer. It has that "sticky" quality that's great.

Pours a completely opaque deep brown (read: black) with a decent creamy, dark chocolate head. Excellent head retention and good, well-defined lacing all the way down. The aroma is very indicative of what's to come: dark, heavy malts are enriched by a solid earthy/woody scent. The 12% ABV shows through immediately, and hops figure in pretty minimally. Taking a sip, an initial caramel sweetness fades quickly into a powerful chocolate/malt body made all the more robust by the heavy alcohol presence. The mouthfeel is very syrupy, bordering on offensive, with a medium- to low-carbonation. Fortunately, all of this means that you really only need to take a small sip to really get the full experience of this beer.  I guess "epic" isn't a bad word to use to describe this beer, so long as it isn't confused with "excellent." That said, I really do love it, and I'm tempted to buy some from time to time just to have it lying around. Still, it's a little too strong to really be enjoyed to the fullest (in my opinion) and I can't see how aging it even longer would change the flavor/make it better. After the first few sips, the taste gets a little monolithic, but it's still appealing. Kudos to DFH for giving it a shot.

Love the rich deep mahogany color of this brew. A brown top with long legs to match. Awesome. But that's where the goodness ends. A beer that is overpowered and buttered with Palo Santo wood is one that attacks the palette. Not a fan of the hints of sweetness here either. Mouthfeel was average, but feeling over carbonated for this suite of flavors. Overall a disappointment for me. The 12 alcohol on top of all this just makes this whole brew seem like a marketing joke. Sorry, normally enjoy dfhead. Not this time.

Had this at Beer Bistro in Toronto. Pours a very dark brown colour with creamy tan head. Really nice head retention, lots of lacing down the glass. Smells very woody, I suppose like palo santo wood (though I have no idea what that smells like). There is also a chocolate and fruity aroma. Flavour has more bitterness than I expected, though the wood seems to dominate the aftertaste. Nice thick mouthfeel. I didn't know this was 12% alcohol until I came here to enter my review, so it hides it well.

Reviewed from notes:  Appearance: Black with a 1 finger mocha head  smell: sweet, booze, wood, malts  taste: sweet malts, coffee,  mouthfeel: mild carbonation, full body, sticky  Drinkability: this is a very complex brown ale or should I call it a stout. Full of flavors which makes this beer very enjoyable. So rich almost rather split this bottle with another body.  Cheers,  the CPJ

Pours into a pint glass dark brown with no transparency. Small but stubborn creamy light brown head that holds good lacing.  Aroma has a healthy malt selection. Chocolate, dark fruit, toffee, and brown sugar. Somewhat doughy yeasts with a definite hint that this thing is 12% ABV. Slightly woody scent when I look for it, but not quite what I had anticipated; however, I have no idea what Palo Santo is supposed to smell like, so maybe I'm confusing it with the malts.  The taste is definitely also full of malts. Nutty and chocolatey, with a strong dose of alcohol and slightly sour yeasts. The woody flavor is a little more prevalent in my mouth than it was in my nose. Sweet but also a bitter dark chocolate/coffee flavor. Nice balance on the malts.  Full-bodied and with decent carbonation as well as a warming sensation from the alcohol. Overall, this is an interesting brown and somewhat enjoyable, but the alcohol flavor gets a bit overwhelming after about half-way through the pint.

A dark brown brew with a fair light brown cover and modest lacing. The aroma suggests a light citrus hop over malty licorice. Nice. The flavorm comes on with much the same in addition to some very definitive raisin. It's pretty intense with malt and an almost minty licorice idea with a vanilla alcohol edge. It's near full bodied, somewhat cloying in its intense combination of sweetness and tasteful bitterness. Carbonation is mild and drinkability is marginal due to the thick character and alcohol presence. There's a slight peaty, almost seaweed-like base in the malt side of this quality brew. A real tasty treat but not something for the sessioning.

Have enjoyed this beer so many times, it's about time I give it a formal review. Can't get it in Columbia, so whenever I travel to where DFH is available I'm sure to pick up at least one four-pack.  Appearance - Poured a deep onyx. Fine dark tan, almost mocha colored head formed slowly as I poured. Nice 1.5-finger head rounded out my Old Rasputin pint glass. Yes, I should have used my DFH snifter, but that would have been pretentious...no? As the head receded, lacing coated the sides of my glass as a flannel blanket would keep your toes warm during a cold winter evening.  Smell - So, this is what Palo Santo wood smells like. Always wondered.... The nose is lively, almost fruity with a melon aroma (about the best I could classify what I'm smelling). Exotic would be another, woody would be too obvious. Some undertones of malt and a sweet component as well. Very inviting.  Taste - Starts with a deep malt presentation as you would expect from a base brown ale. The wood-aging lends a "warming" (best I can describe) contribution that makes the taste richer and fuller. The middle brings some hops to the party but it's not detracting nor acts as a cleansing agent. It's dry, it's roasted, it's dense but not overly complex. You know what you are getting here. Some fruity notes to give some balance. 12% ABV? Not by my reckoning. You get a hint, but not a big boozy presentation. Well done.  Mouthfeel - Smooth would best describe this mouthfeel. Is this an understatement? Sure, but I'm about the beer, not the words. This coats your tongue and gives meaning to the the word "lush". The carbonation is lighter than expected, meaning this is "all beer all the time" giving the body to this offering.  Drinkability - To take a brown ale, age it in wood barrels and have something like this come out is true artistry. This tastes like a bourbon-barrel-aged offering, but it isn't. Drink it close to room temp and you will enjoy it as the flavors further opens up. The presentation, the flavors, the sipping quality of this beer makes me come back to it on both chilly evenings and non-chilly evenings alike. One of my "top 3 beers" from DFH. Well done.

A: Deep black. Dark tan/caramel head that lingers. Pretty good lacing.  S: Vanilla, coffee, maybe some licorice?  T: BAM! Delicious! Deepest, darkest, "brown" ale I've ever had. Coffee and Vanilla are still present. You can taste the ABV.  M: Smooth but still pretty heavy. Good finish, pretty long though, still getting the alcohol even after awhile.  D: Easy drinking but no more than one. Turn down the heat, start a fire, throw on your favorite sweater and kick back with this. A really great beer.

A - Densest black I can imagine in a beer. I got at least a cm of head meaning even at 12% it still is carbonated.  S - I get mostly booze but some slight leather and caramel tones. Maybe chocolate.  T - Wow smoother than expected! Creamy body with a bit of charcoal, coffee, and a bit of cocoa. I am surprised this beer has no burn!  M - Heavy, I found myself gulping though but this beer is dangerously drinkable.  D - I got this back in April of last year dated "July 2010" so after six months this beer is just perfect. Was really avoiding it because of the ABV but it drinks the best I ever seen for the style and volume. Recommended!

So, pretty intense beer. Just finished one with dinner and I'm still enjoying it's aftermath. Pours smoothly with a dark, uniformly dirty coloring. Smells like booze - the alcohol comes through in the smell as much as, if not more than, it does in the taste. Ultra malty beer with maybe a touch of caramel. The label mentions something about vanilla, but I think that gets quickly picked up by the more molasses-y tastes. Sweet leather, that might be a good way to describe it. Maybe not. The paolo santo wood notes come through though, quite strong. Overall I recommend it, but I think the tastes might be more muddled than usual for DFH.

This beer pours an opaque black with a good amount of late-forming creamy tan head that lingers around for a while and leaves some pretty heavy lacing.  On the nose I can pick up on some hops, fig and other dark fruits, plus some sweet vanilla and coffee that comes in at the end. Very complex, overall fairly sweet smelling, not too boozy smelling, I only pick up a tiny bit of alcohol at the end.  Flavor wise this is really complex just like the smell, I feel like the alcohol is really well masked in this. There is a bitter dominance in this brew, but there are some delicate sweet flavors that come and go in the middle. The most prevalent thing to me is a roasted coffee flavor, along with some fig and some sweet sugary hints.  This beer has a really interesting mouthfeel, its slick and oily, and also has a moderate chewyness to it, but finishes on the thin side. It leaves an interesting wet feeling in your mouth aftwards then warms you up from the high abv.  I found this beer very drinkable and easy to sip on without hesitation. Not something I would enjoy more than 1 of at a time though.

Got a few bottles of this as extras in a trade with tsblack05. Thanks a lot Tim!  Appearance: Palo Santo Marron pours out a very dark brown; about as dark brown as you can get without moving into the totally black end of the color spectrum. About a finger of light mocha colored head forms. Retention is okay, and lacing is very good.  Smell: Whew, a ton of complexity in this beer. Coffee, light smoke, fig, raisin, wood, and a bunch of vanilla. Great on the nose.  Taste: I must say, I'm a gigantic fan of this beer. A touch of smoke, coffee, caramel, slight dark fruits, woody quality, and a ton of vanilla all combine for a great flavor.  Mouthfeel/Drinkablility: This beer is slightly over medium bodied with incredibly fine carbonation. Super smooth and creamy; I don't think a brown ale gets any better in this category. This is a huge beer for the style at 12% ABV. That being said, I'm a total sucker for it. It combines most of my favorite beer qualities into a somewhat random style, and the ending result is phenomenal.

Appearance: Jet black with about of finger of head that receades quickly into the abyss.  Smell: Initially there a sweet scent of candied alcohol follow by slight waves of roasted almonds.  Taste: Mirrors the scent it starts sweet with a mild kick of alcohol at the back of the throat and ends with a mellow taste of smoked almonds.  Mouthfeel: High viscosity, rich and creamy, reminds a bit of a milkshake.  Drinkability: Fantastic session beer, best enjoyed in good conversation with good people.

A - Very dark brown, almost black, body with ruby edges and base. Tan head that dissipates quickly and gives way to very light lacing.  S - Quick scent of alcohol in the nose followed by deep sweet dark malts. There is a roasted (near burnt) sweetness to it. Not coffee exactly but rumors of coffee. The whole thing, while not fruity, is suggestive of candied fruits; acidic sumatran grounds.  T - Again, alcohol (and its relaxing vapors) up front. Brown sugar or perhaps burnt nun's candy. The dark malts are too roasted to be caramel but the sweetness has a smoothness to it, just under the sharpness of acidic roasts. There are moments of chocolate in here but so indirect that it might be flavor matrixing on my part. Any hops/bitterness is minimal and overshadowed by the acidity of the malts anyway. The finish has a classic wood/nutty brown ale flavor.  M - A robust medium, exceptionally smooth for the ABV %.  D - Highly drinkable for such a powerful flavor and alcohol content.

This is barrel aging done right! It was much darker than I expected and kinda oily on the pour. First sip was love as I felt like I had something truly unique. Wanted to smoke a cigar with this brew. The aroma was dominated by vanilla and wood. Initial taste represented a nutty brown ale relatively faithfully but then it finished with an intense alcohol/wood flavor reminiscent of cedar.  Really like this one!

Poured into a lager glass - my first beer from Dogfish Head.  A: This beer is heavy, thick and dark - a medium-sized head which faded fairly quickly. The carbonation was minimal and the bubbles struggled their way to the top.  S: I think you can smell how big this beer is. Plainly woody with some nuttiness to it, not overly complex.  T: As I first sipped this I thought it was a simple brown, but it is more complicated as it finishes. Definitely some caramel and a slight bit of leather.  M: Smooth and heavy, some velvet/syrup to it. It lingered in my mouth for a while.  This combined great with my shepherd's pie dinner - both were very substantial.

Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights that turns into a solid black once it fills the glass. Nutty brown colored head with a creamy texture leaving behind a semi-sticky lace.  Aroma is heavy on the malt characters with some bready and chocolate or brown sugar sweetness mixed in with a strong dose of vanilla. A mild alcohol presence suggests this one is a bit boozy.  Lots of malt flavors going on here, reminiscent of many doppelbocks. Chocolately and caramel sweetness with some tart fruit flavors too. Not much of a roasted character for such a dark ale which I'm kind of missing because it's almost too sweet. Some woody accents but I'm not sure what the Palo Santo does that is any different from the more typical oak. Finshes with a lingering alcohol presence that makes this one a little too hot.  Thick, chewy, and creamy mouthfeel really compliments the flavor well and it gets better as it warms.  Overall the cloying sweetness of this makes this a suitable desert beer for some but certainly not something you could have more than one of in a night. I'll let my other bottle sit in the cellar for a long time and then revisit, four months old seems a bit too hot for my liking.  Edit to add: Having a second bottle from the same batch a week later. This one sat at room temp for a few hours before I opened it up and I'm enjoying it quite a bit more as the sweetness does not seem as cloying.

Vintage: 2010  Serving Type: 12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  A: Pours a deep dark brown with burgundy around the edges. Head is minimal as well as the lacing.  S: Slight boozy aroma, brown sugar, barely and a woodsy aroma waffs up to my nose,  T: A little heat, but age has weakened it. Vanilla, wood and sweet caramel/brown sugar.  M: Medium body brew, almost like a stout but not as creamy. Really enjoying this as I sip this.  D: Great sipper! No need to rush this one. Well balance and very good representation of the "ABA" brews. Aging 3 more from 2010. Time will nake this even more complex.

Poured very dark to almost pitch black with little to no head and no lacing... Smell of dark chocolate, roasted caramel, charred wood nuance aromas with a hint of coffee... Taste of sweet roasted and almost singed caramel yet warming to the tongue... Mouthfeel of mild carbonation on the tongue, thick and creamy lingering sensation at the end. This brew has some depth... Definitely a sipper. Enjoy every minute as the 12.0% ABV warms the soul...

A: Very dark color, lets no light through. Very small, dark brown head with good lacing; disappears quickly.  S: Malty aroma; notes of liquorice, vanilla, and coffee, with a slight alcohol smell at the back of the nose. very reminiscent of a good stout  T: Rich, malty flavor with hints of vanilla, caramel, coffee, and a roasty bitterness that lingers on the back of the tongue. Small hint of alcohol at the end  M: Medium-bodied with a small amount of carbonation. I wish it was a little thicker, but the carbonation is perfectly balanced. It feels buttery as it coats the mouth, but with a little bite of alcohol  O: Very heavy and flavor-intense beer, great for sipping after dinner. I dont think I could drink more than one 12oz bottle at a time. I'd also like to add that this beer feels and tastes more like an imperial stout than a brown ale, and if you enjoy a good stout then you will love this beer. Overall its a very good brew, but not worth $15 for a 4-pack.

Very dark brown, almost black and opaque. Smallish dark head that dissapates to not much quickly, not much in the way of lacing. Aromas of bourbon and booziness are prevelant, smells like the inside of a barrel maybe? I don't know but the tastes like it was aged in a bourbon barrel and after the initial alcohol-y pow you get from it, there is a delicious barleywine with booze covered dried fruits. Definitely an alcohol driven beer at 12 percent. Thats true for most good barleywines of course though. Creamy mouthfeel backed by mild carbonation and an alcohol twinge. If you like barleywines, this is a good sipper and one that you can enjoy as it warms up.

12oz bottle poured into a Maudite snifter...  A: Pours a syrupy dark, glassy brown with a minimal, coffee head; not much retention nor lacing; looks like a BIG beer.  S: A lot of sweet malt, molasses, figs, a touch of vanilla, and a very faint aroma of what reminds of crusty banana peel; not the huge aroma I was expecting, though; considering the abv, not much hotness on the nose.  T: Wow, rich maltiness... caramel sweetness; toasted dark bread; sugary molasses; hard to believe this is 12%... crazy; although subdued by the big malt bill, hops more than hold their own, as there is a nice touch of bitterness on the finish.  M: In a word... huge. Almost too huge. Syrupy, yet well carbonated. Mouthwatering. Fullest mouthfeel of any beer I've had.  D: A wonderful sipper, but the sweetness is a bit much for me, personally. A very nice, big beer, though.

Poured from the bottle into a piraat tulip. It looks like runny molasses. Very little head, as could be expected from a 12% abv beer. Looked very inviting. Darker than I expected.  Smelled like toasted wood. Not really a familiar smell.... maybe because it was a Paraguayan wood. Carmel.... molasses.... rummy fruit.  Very nice flavor. Wood.... roasted coffee. Caramel. Alcohol evident, especially in the aftertaste.  Mouthfeel was creamy... strange. A blend of creamy and silky.  I only gave it a 4 for drinkability, only because you really couldn't have more than 1 or 2 of these at a time. It is in no way a reflection of the awesomeness that is this beer!  As I type my final thoughts, I can still taste the wood in this beer. Incredible! Almost like licking a board... in a good way that I never knew was possible!

Dogfish Head is hard to get around here, but got some when I was in Chicago.  It pours a black thick liquid with the medium to dark head.  Nose was rather boozy and caramel with malt.  Taste was pretty much right. Kind of a stout but sweet and really malty too. Some spice mixed in.  Mouth feel with thick and not overly carbonated. Drinkability was pretty high for a high ABV and sweet, thick beer.

12oz bottle (bottled 11/11/10) poured into a snifter  A: Pours black/dark brown with red/brown hues around the edges when held too light. Very little head, about 1/4 inch, that quickly disappears.  S: Alcohol soaked dark fruits, molasses, wood tannins, smoke, roasted malts. The heavy alcohol scent reminds me of rum.  T: Fairly hot from the get go. I get the roasted malts and alcohol soaked dark fruits similar to a stout, but without the chocolate. There's a lot of wood tannins, not quite oak, and some smokiness as well. Decent amount of sweetness is something akin to molasses and toffee. There's a little bit of vanilla, almost a hint at bourbon in the background. I'm pretty impressed not only at the complexity, but the balance. Finish is toffee, vanilla, and wood. While the alcohol is a bit hot, it's not as overbearing as a lot of high ABV beers.  M: Medium to low carbonation (I've been doing a god bit of swirling), fairly full body with plenty of viscosity. Seems very smooth and goes down easier than 12%ABV should.  D: As mentioned above, I found this a lot easier to drink than similar high gravity beers. I especially like how pleasant and 'soft' the finish/aftertaste is.

Poured into a Duvel Tulip.  A - Dark brown, poured almost no head that turned to film right quick.  S - What I would expect a Carribean Toffee Rum to smell like (if it existed). I actually want to smell this more than drink it, it's so good!  T - A hint of bourbony sweetness. Alot of wood, and malts. Not up to par with the smell, but still very appealing.  M - Good consistency, not too thick. Nice boozy coating.  D - One is enough, which is fine. This should be savored not chugged.  Overall a fantastic beer. Dogfish Head scored a winner!

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a tulip pint.  A: Very dark brown with little head; good legs though.  S: Smells of toffee, booziness and oak. Lots of complexity and its one of the beers you keep going back to smell.  T: Taste is an abundance of dark malts, roastiness, coffee and woodiness from the barrels.  D: Its pretty hot, but the flavours are complex and the mouthfeel is creamy.  Overall: A very original and tasty brew! I like this one, but can't quite put my finger on what it is that pops out. Overall, this is a unique and damn tasty beer!

palo santo, bottled 11/11/10  a 4 cola colored, near opaque, short head doesn't leave much at all in the way of a ring or lace. but this will mostly be forgiven due to the 12 and wood, i guess%  s 4-4.5 tobacco, figs, raisins, alcohol, and an overall molasses rum (almost like Cruzan black strap plus a touch of myers's for the tobacco) essence.  t 4 yes, it does follow the smell, with emphasis on the raisins and alcohol, with tobacco in the finish after the etoh evaporates. fair amount of alcohol flavor in this one. the flavors (apart from alc) are not as integrated or apparent as i hoped. wonder what it will be like in a year or two.  m 3.5 not very big in the body dept., alc burn in the finish.  d 4 amazing the quantity of this stuff they're putting out these days. i hope it hasn't hurt the quality--and if it hasn't, that is amazing and laudible.  Dec 2012 update (after 25 months of aging): the primary characteristics are a big coffee roastiness and a vinous quality. the mouthfeel seems none the worse for the wear, a little lusher actually. the alcohol does not seem as prominent (but that could be due to palate change from sipping a lot of spirits in the meantime), but the lack of complexity is disappointing. the beer is good, but certainly not great. currently drinking around a 3.8 - 3.9, and the dominating roast is discouraging me from planning on buying more next time i'm in dfh country.

Pours a dark brown almost black color with a thin khaki color head which gives way to some decent lacing.
