S-honestly to me, it smelled like bourbon, with out the alcohol note. also smelled almost "burnt". it actually a very inviting combination, in fact, i sniffed it for awhile before even taking a taste, and through out the experience, i continued to smell it constantly, it put a smile on my face every time.  T-The taste is very woody, the alcohol is noticed but welcomed in this one. there is a mocha/abbey aftertaste to it. best brown ale i've come across.  M-medium carbonation  D-alcohol hits quickly but the taste stays during the entire experience. definitely not a session brown ale.  I found myself drinking this one slowly, not because of the high ABV, but because i simply did not want the beer to end!!

Had a vertical of a 2008 and 2009 side-by-side. Pours a very deep brown color with a few crimson highlights on the edges. Dark brown foam is creamy and dense, holds well. Not a whole lot of lacing though, and the 08 fades a bit faster.  Both smell nice; heavenly wood aromas with lots of brown sugar. 08 shows a bit more dark fruit, while the 09 more black licorice and alcohol. I think I actually like the 2009 version better, has a more 'green' wood aroma.  Malts range from chocolate to dark bready grains to burnt caramel. Lingering licorice flavors and the wood is very unique and noticeable. Some raisin fruitiness comes out as it warms. I like the 08 better in the taste...it has a mellower wood influence and the alcohol is very smooth. Incredible drinkability for a 12%'er. I can see this one getting even better with a couple more years on it. Oxidation is quite low for a 2-year old beer, nice. I'll buy it again, even with the steep price tag - that is for damn sure.

poured into my duvel tulip  A: pours brown almost black, with a very thin tan to light brown head. small amount of lacing. S: sweet and nutty, a light hint of alcohol and wood T: also sweet and nutty, with sweet roasted malt and a slight hint of coffee. alcohol is almost unnoticeable. M: thick and chewy, sticks around for a while, bubbles are low. D: this is a large sipper, i could see this catching up to me if i had a couple.

Bottled 5/21/10 (3 months ago)  Poured into tulip glass.  40 F probably way to cold. Let warm to 48 before finishing.  A: Dark burnt umber body, creamy head about 2 inches, settles into wisps of foam a minute later S: Dark roasted nuts, roasted cardamon, burnt molasses and creme brulee. T: Raw licorice root, tar,pebbles, dates, figs, molasses, charred mahogany, jelly beans, Black Sea salt all in a malty soup. Basically messy liquid sex. M: Tingly carbo, nice heat. Super rich, churning creamy mouthfeel. Tongue does not rest here. D: About my 5th bottle so far, never gets old. Would be interesting to see if it changes after bottle aging.  How can they get this so right and fail so epically on the Theobroma? Sort of like Ford coming out with the GT500 but also producing the Xr4ti. Different design/marketing teams? If this is their winner then they are allowed to fail (once) on something else.

Had it on tap at Barley's in Greenville, SC. I was skeptical at first as I am not a huge fan of DFH.  Pours a pitch black with a decent light brown head.  Smells of raisins and dark fruits with a hint smoked wood/booze.  Tasted much like it smells but better. Lots of dark fruits like cherry and plum, a little spice (not sure what) with a finish of the smoked wood.  Creamy thick mouthfeel with low but good carbonation.  My wife was given a sample of this at Barley's. She liked it but it was a bit much for her. So I finished the sample. I had to order one up as soon as I finished my Racer X. I then went a bought a 6 of it to have one every now and then. Very good change up for a complex, big 12% beer. Flavor is big and bold. Very drinkable for 12% brown (black) ale.

Pours rich dark reddish brown, syrupy thick. Rich foam and lace. Nose is of roasted malt and berries.  First taste is thick, like drinking a beer smoothie, rich and alcoholic mouthcoating. with hints of plums. Develops as it warms in the glass to have an almost sherry quality. Finishes with lingering sweetness. High in alcohol, so not good to quaff multiples.

A: Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a dark tan, small head with a little lacing down the glass. Mixed it up with an Otter Creek stein that I've never used before.  S: Very strong wood smell with some alcohol. A hint of dark chocolate and roasted malts.  T: A pretty strong taste of alcohol up front with some roasted malt, caramel and slight vanilla hints. The wood is also very prominent throughout the taste.  M: Smooth and full bodied, not much carbonation here but it works.  D: A big beer with lots of booze in the flavor, a very good beer with some serious bite, at 12% be careful because it is delicious but could be deadly (in a good way though).

Purchased in Wilmington, DE. Bottling date is 7/14/10, so only a month old. Poured in DFH Signature glass.  A: VERY dark with tan head. No light can be seen through this brew. Poured with very little head, but what was there disappeared quickly. Good lacing on the glass.  S: Hard to mess the deep woody smell. Definitely hints of caramel, vanilla, and some fruits.  T: This is a strong brew. Powerful stuff. Vanilla, chocolate/caramel, etc. I like the flavor a lot. Definitely good for being sipped and enjoyed SLOWLY. So much going on in there.  M: We have some body here. It coats your mouth smoothly while leaving a nice aftertaste. Surprisingly smooth for such a deep brew.  D: This is probably a ONE a night type beer. With the 12% alcohol, you might have to move on to something a little less filling after this one.  All and all, another solid beer from Dogfish Head. Always impressed with what they continue to churn out down there in Milton.

Chilled bottle into a glass.  A: Dark, opaque brown that passes absolutely no light when held up. A dark tan head forms easily but recedes quickly, leaving only a light trace of film on the top and some lacing down the sides. Impressive for a 12%er.  S: Dark rum smell. Impossible to miss the wood. Elements of chocolate, brown sugar, tobacco, and caramel.  T: Vanilla and some spice right up front with a powerful alcohol kick. Brown sugar and chocolate malts next, followed by hints of smoke and noticeable wood. Nuts and a noticeable taste of dark fruit, like raisins -- I find this is a Dogfish Head signature, actually. The rum/port combination is quite powerful. Very tasty.  M: Medium bodied; not too syrupy despite its sweetness. Medium carbonation.  D: Good to have this once in a while. This bottle is about 9 months old. I haven't had a fresh PSM in some time, so I don't know what the age has done to it. But I like the way it is drinking right now.  Also, I consider this more of an American Strong Ale than an American Brown Ale. Rating this one against other ASAs.

12oz. bottle dated 11/11/09 poured into a tulip glass  It pours a rich silky looking deep brown with just the smallest of ruby highlights. A small mocha colored head arises and then dies within 15 seconds leaving just a ring of bubbles.  The nose is deep very rich and thick. I'm getting some spicy wood, licorice and vanilla. It reminds me a lot of Bells Batch 9000 with a strong licorice notes. A hint of expected alcohol at the end.  I know the back-story for this beer and sad;y have never smelled or even seen Palo Santo wood so i cannot pinpoint what this wood exactly adds to the beer but i can describe how I'm perceiving how different this wood tastes. The taste starts off with raw wood taste with some very subtle spiciness like black pepper (much different than like a saison pepperyness). The end begins to get pretty vegetative and similar to wet grass which I'm not digging too much. Intervened in what I'm perceiving as wood is a very sweet alcoholic rich beer. The sweetness is right at the border of cloying to me. Once again my mind races to make this beer similar to batch 9000 in richness and sweetness.  This beer just coats my mouth in sticky thick beer. The flavor lasts and lasts in my mouth. Carbonation is on the low side which works well for this beer. For a beer this size it's still only average drinkability. I had some trouble finishing the whole bottle because of the sweetness.

Bottle. Bottled on 6/21/10. Pours a DARK brown alomost black color into my tulip glass. This has got to be the darkest brown ale I have ever seen. Very slight dark tan head. Big roast notes coming from this one. Big whiffs do burn the nostrils a bit with the booze. Much smoother in the taste than I would have thought after the aroma. Notes of coffee and dark chocolate come to mind. Alomost an iron taste to it as well, not sure where that is coming from. Woody and earthy too. The alocohol is surpisingly not that noticeable in the taste. This could be an IRS judging by the looks, so dark with a slight head. The wood flavor becomes more apparent as this warms a bit and tastes like a mix of oak and very subdued cedar. Very much a sipper type of beer. Medium/Heavy mouthfeel.

From bottle dated 2010.  A: Pours dark brown, almost no light makes it through. Minimal head initially and maintains nice lacing throughout.  S: "Roasted wood." Love this smell, reminds me of walking outside in the forest! Some dark fruit sweetness evident, but I keep coming back to the wood.  T: BIG wood taste. Spices jump around, surprising me at times. Quite sweet as well - dark fruits and raisins mainly. I also get a sour kick, but this could be a sensory association with the wood.  M: Thick and creamy... wow I like this! Not what I expected, but definitely compliments the flavor profile.  D: I can't see having more than one of these, if that. This one will take me a while to get through... one sip at a time!  I had this one on my "To-Drink" list for awhile, and I am glad to have tried it at last! Definitely one to sip by a fire on a cold winter's night. Will drink again!

Like Barthelme's guy climbing the glass mountain, this thing is on it's way to the top for me. Ascension. What we have here is an effort for transcendence.  Stare into the dark amber nectar and think "Father, forgive me, I did not know it was you," but don't worry because that burning sensation is not his flaming sword. It is the alcohol that burns so sweet, separation before coagulation, see solve et coagula.  Welcome it is what I mean, but don't rush. You can't rush these things, it's one plungered hand at a time up that mountain.  The taste of red wine, of the communion wine, is only made more illuminating because it is a beer you hold in those plungered hands. And though you have a long way to go, and many mounted men chasing you, worry not for this fine liquid will last long into your journey, and leave you with the desire to continue your quest.

Pours a pitch black with a one finger light brown head which fades fast. Tiny bit of lacing.  Smells of dark fruits, raisins, with a woody smell similar to red wine. Hint of vanilla. Definetely big and boozy.  Tastes of dark fruits like cherry and plum, wood, thick caramel sweetness. Finishes spicy with the slight alcohol. Some roastiness.  Super thick mouthfeel. Low carb makes it creamy and milkshake like. Warming in the chest.  Well it's big and boozy, what else needs to be said? Drinkability is about as high as a 12% brown ale can get.

Pours dark brown in color with one finger of off white head that leaves decent lacing.  The scent was of roasty malts, light alcohol and some hops.  The taste was of burnt coffee, some chocolate, very nutty, notes of wood, molasses, raisin, and lots of alcohol.  Full bodied, thick, viscous and chewy, smooth feel with low carbonation.  This was a fantastic brown ale, great complex flavor, not necessarily easy to drink more that one or two, but it is greatly enjoyable.

I initially tried Palo Santo Marron at a tasting hosted by Sam Calagione. He introduced it as "one of the best beers I have ever made." If that isn't intriguing to a beer lover, and especially a fan of Dogfish Head, what is? I was blown away with the quality of my one inch beer ration, and also mournful that this brew would not be available for the forseeable future. Now, much to my delight, it is here at last.  This review is from the original bottling date Feb 11, 2008. Taken from my cellar.  A: Very dark brown and rich, almost black, like an imperial stout  S: High abv% slightly evident in the nose, though much less so than a fresh bottle. rich brown ale and wood aromas  T: Delicious. Although the alcohol is present in the aroma, it is well disguised in the taste. I think the time spent in the cellar has mellowed this beer out. The Palo Santo wood creates a pleasant lingering aftertaste.  M: Smooth and easy, perhaps too easy!  D: A great beer to share with someone, although, since it does go down quite easy, considering it is 12%, you could enjoy one all to yourself, as well.

A: jet black. little of white/tan head that disappears quickly and leaves jsut a touch of lacing.  S: alcohol fumes. pretty much over powers everthing else. little bit of burnt malt.  T: woody alcohol. Like liking burnt wood. THe alcohol is overpowering everything here.  M: Spicy alcohol flavors, average carb. Alcohol burns long after flavor fades.  D: I bought a 4 pack for $12. This will be my last. Not bad, but not good.

A: very nice head, dark color, almost stout-colored S: unbelievably strong, abundant aroma, primarily of the Palo Santo wood T: I cannot describe this beer. It is unlike anything I have ever had before. I am stunned. Dogfish conquers. M: very silky, well carbonated D: You would be sick if you had more than one on a given day. No, week. Really, half a bottle will do you just fine.  This is one of the most outstanding beers I have ever had.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.  The color is a complete black with a thin brownish head that has disappeared and no lacing.  The smell is sweeter than expected. A slight peppery flavor is out front with some coffee flavor and in the back is nice dark malt flavor.  The taste is really biscuity at first with a doughy flavor that is pillowed by dark malt flavor. Nice toffee, caramel and a tough of coffee surround and then take over to converge at the end.  The feel is really enjoyable and is pretty smooth. It slides down the pallet and has a nice drinkable feel.

Woah I had no idea this was a 12% beer when I bought it.  A- Pretty syrupy while pouring. Thught I'd have trouble bringing upsome head but it looks fine. Black with red and brown highlights. I was expecting a more transparent, lighter brown. Beige-grey head.  S- Good bit of chocolate malt and dark fruit alcohol. A little metallic but nothing that really bothers me. Alcohol gets stronger and stronger as it warms. A bit like milk.  T- Not exactly blown away but it is very good. I don't get too much of a ''special'' wood taste. I guess the wood kind of fits in the alcohol (a bit like a whisky) but it definitely doesn't stand out. A wood and licorice bitterness ends it all. Alcohol after-taste.  M- Almost like a milkshake. Very full with low carbonation. Very little dryness.  D- It's a good, very thick beer. You can easily share a small bottle with a friend. I wouldn't drink two.  Won't buy this again but have been wanting to try it for a while so... not disappointed.

Dark and thick as it's poured into a DFH snifter. A very minimal head.  The aroma is complex and includes: vanilla, oak, alcohol, and several other sweet aromas.  The taste is as bold as the aroma. The Palo Santo wood it's aged in is definitely evident, because instead of the traditional oaky flavor there is a slightly different taste, which is definitely wood related. There is certainly also a note of smokiness. It is sweet and slightly syrupy. It is labeled a brown ale, and as such, it reminds me of a more complex, more alcoholic version of the DFH Indian Brown.  It's too strong to be very drinkable, but it's a very intense, complex, and eminently enjoyable drink.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a tulip glass.  Appearance: It has an almost opaque dark brown body with lighter chestnut highlights near the edges of the glass. The pour is deep, dark and thick, making a small light brown head to sit on top. This head fades out quickly however and leaves a thin ring of tan foam lace. A quick swirl gives it a wispy thin film covering and slick lace.  Smell: The aroma has toasted bready malt, roasted grain, sweet brown sugar and molasses. This gives it a sweet overall character but there is also some fresh cut pine, resin, hops, dark wood and leathery notes. Its alcohol is noticeable as well.  Taste/Palate: There is a lot of complexity here in this big full bodied beer. There are sweet notes of brown sugar, vanilla, molasses, raisons, and prunes. This is balanced with some floral/woody notes, pine resin, leafy hops and dark hard wood. It also has notes of toasted bread, roasted grain and warm alcohol that give it a bit of bite. This all comes on a heavy, slightly viscous texture with smooth carbonation.  Notes: It's big and complex with a bit of bite, which should mellow nicely with age. This is a big winner in my book.

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass.  A The appearance is that of dark brown almost black and opaque with a creamy head. There is heavy lacing noticeable around the sides of the glass.  S The distinct smell of wood and roasted caramel malts. A slight toffee like aroma is also present.  T The taste is awesome. Dark cherry, vanilla, woody, caramel, nutty, plum, and fig. Also noted a chocolate taste.  M A little oily and buttery. This beer has a slight bitterness on the back of the tongue. A full bodied beer with a very long finish.  D Very drinkable if sitting with it for about a half hour. This is not a pounding beer.  Overall this is a great beer. Very complex and becomes very aromatic as the beer warms up with the wood really coming to the forefront.

Appearance-Pours a slick, very, very, very dark almost black brown into the glass, about of finger of mocha colored head rises and lingers longer than I would expect for the ABV and leaves a sizable ring of lacing along the edges as it recedes. The consistency of the pour has that sick motor-oil consistency one typically associates with Imperial Stouts, though this is billed as a brown ale by DFH.  Aroma-Darkly roasted malts reminiscent of a brown ale only much, much more intense. A caramely-woodsy aroma, which I assume comes from the Palo Santo wood, mingles with milk chocolate and dark fruits to concoct one of the most intriguing and intoxicating aromas I've yet to come across. No alcohol detected on the nose.  Taste-Robustly bittersweet flavors of oaken caramel, vanilla, plums, raisins, dark chocolate and just the slightest tinge of a burn of alcoholic heat to remind you of the ABV of this bad boy. The woodiness *really* comes through on the finish and smooths everything out nicely, it's a very unique kind of woodiness too, definitely not piny but not exactly oaken either, which I imagine is the result of the unique wood they used for this brew.  Mouthfeel-Thick, but not quite as viscous and chewy as an RIS; I can see why they billed this as a Brown ale, maybe a new style category is in order for this brew; Imperial Brown ale perhaps?  Drinkability-Not sure how to rate it on this scale, it's not really a beer to knock back and pound, it's intended to be savored and drank slowly. For what they were going for, I think the drinkability is pretty solid.

Bottled 12/28/09, drunk on 8/7/10. Very good, aged well with no apparent storage impact.  A - Pours very dark brown with a thick pour stream  S - Aroma is roasted malts, wood some chocolate with a slight dried fruit smell  T - Wood, some raisin with vanilla overtones and roasted malt  M - Thick and rich, hard to believe it is 12% abv, nice carbonation, just enough to know it is there but not too much to overpower the richness.  D - Very Drinkable. Strong so be careful you can overdo very quickly if you don't watch out. Nice to have to just sip and enjoy the moment. Definitely not a session beer, but easily a special moment beer.

Poured in to Duvel tulip Bottled on date of 12/28/09  A - Dark black colour with a generous amount of thick, bubbly brown head.  S - Rich sweet caramel and toffee malt nose with some oak notes. No apparent bitterness.  T - A robust sweet malt palate of rich caramel and molasses with a nice oak taste present. Very strong flavour and the ABV is somewhat apparent, although not overwhelming. There is a nice nutty flavour in the background  M - Medium body, lightly carbonated, somewhat chewy.  D - A very good and unique beer. Easy to drink for 12% ABV.

Longtime reader, first review. Bottled on 12/28/09. Purchased on a Hudson, WI beer run. Poured into my Surly Darkness tulip glass.  A - Pours a very dark brown nearly black. Some reddish highlights. Syrupy. Slight tan head that dissipated quickly except around the edges.  S - Alcohol, followed by vanilla and caramel.  T - Lots going on thanks to the wood. The vanilla is there as well as raisin. Light smoke and toasted malt.  M - Creamy, syrupy low carbonation. Similar to a stout. Smooth. Almost chewy.  D - A great sipping Imperial Brown. It is smooth but at the same time the alcohol is not hidden. A great first beer of the night or a great one for a single beer evening. I would definitely drink again.

I have been very happy with most dogfish brews in the past, in this is no exception. I have just consumed my third of a four pack, and WOW is this a great brown ale. I am more of an IPA fan, but this beer is a must have.  A: very dark, unexpected, yet clear and very smoothe looking. Pours heavy, almost syrupy.  S: First impression is a smoky and carmelly, but you can smell the booziness in this one (12%). Has subltle chocolate and coffee hints as well.  T: Exceptional for a brown ale. Very strong and very boozy on the tongue. But is perfectly balanced with carmel flavor. Leaves and incredible smoky, boozy, yet sweet taste the tongue that translates into a very sweet caramel aftertaste.  M: very thick and rich. I described it to my wife as almost desert in a cup! Not a ton of carbonation, but is not necessary due to the bitter/boozy/smoky flavors.  D: Surprisingly drinkable for a syrupy brown ale with a thick, rich flavor. I am currently on 3, and could go for the fourth, if not for work tomorrow. Very strong at 12%, so 2-3 would set you off fine, aka, handcuff yourself to the couch if you drink more than 3!!!!

APPEARANCE Pours a very dark hazelnut brown with shades of a dark redwood. Toffee colored head dissipates quickly with some light lacing. SCENT Smells roasty with hints of wood, coffee, and vanilla. TASTE Deep and complex, this beer has got a lot to offer. Highlights of vanilla and hints of a dark coffee. The taste is lighter than it looks. MOUTHFEEL Smooth, does not disappoint. DRINKABILITY Considering the 12% ABV this beer goes down with resolve. At $18 a 4-pack it is on the expensive side but well worth it if you're looking for a dark, complex brown ale.

A - Nice dark beer. Looks much thicker than it is.  S - I pick up a slight coffee scent,somewhat bitter and sweet at the same time, also notes of vanilla.  T - I was expecting more of a smokey flavor with this beer as is is aged on Palo Santo wood, but honestly, it isn't at all. Tastes of coffee, but with a bitter finish. Hints of caramel and vanilla as well.  M - I found this to feel very smooth and creamy.  D - This is an easy beer to drink, BUT, I wouldn't drink more than one.  Overall, I found this to be a satisfying beer. I will definitely buy it again, but in limited quantities as I wouldn't drink more than 1 at a time.

brown/black pour with some mahogany highlights. a small tan head settles to almost nothing but a film. lacing is ok.  aroma is nutty, woody and roasty with malts and the barrel aging coming through strongly. hops are overpowered and cannot be found.  taste is very nutty, malty, woody, earthy, and roasty. caramel, toffee, vanilla, molasses, and some dark fruits are able to be tasted. reminds me of an old ale, brown ale, barrel-aged stout and a smoked stout mixed.  medium-full bodied with tons of sweetness left on the tongue with almost no carbonation to speak of.  drinks pretty well for a beer of this strength, but not as smooth as I remember from my past experiences with this beer. the smoky, roasty bitterness adds a harshness that suppresses the alcohol content, but still hampers the drinkability.  I loved this beer the first couple of times I had it, but this time, its just ok. I will revisit again in a year or so, I'm sure.

Notes from 6/30/10  Pours a murky dark brown, near black. Not much head nor lacing.  Sweet dark fruits are evident in the smell. Bourbon and dark malts add almost a wine like character. The smell is very complex.  The taste is very smoky and roasty. Raisins and plums dance alongside an oaky wood aftertaste evidence of barrel aging. There is no shortage of brown sugary molasses.  Definitely heavy in the mouth and I was not ready for this rich of a beer. There is a somewhat sour aftertaste which mixes with a lot of sugar giving me sticky saliva.  This is very drinkable for its ABV, but the sugary feel will keep me from having more than 1.

Bottled 7/24/08 poured into a pint glass.  A - Pours out a rich dark brown almost black. Looks like a porter or a stout. Very little head that leaves a carmel colored ring around the glass.  S - Smells of roasted malt, wood, and chocolate. Lets not forget the alcohol, its apparent upon opening the bottle.  T - Rich, roasted malts, brown sugar, some molasses. And also vanilla notes brought out by the palo santo wood. Also some spice that I cant make out. Slightly astringent.  M - Fairly robust IMO for the style. Almost like a porter/stout. Creamy, syrupy and my bottle had little carbonation.  D - I could only handle one of these per sitting. High abv. I thought was apparent making this a sipper for sure. But an interesting beer none the less, always worth a try.

Poured into a nonic glass.  Pours a near black with reddish brown on the edges. Has a dark tan, near brown head. Has a fluffy head that settles to a wispy lace top, with some lacing. Great looking giving the really high alcohol.  Brew smells of sweet dark chocolate, nuts, caramel, vanilla, alcohol and a earthy wood smell. Very complex and smells delicious. Great smell.  This brew is smooth; sweet, nutty and earthy. Has a wood nutty flavor. Dark fruits, cherry, vanilla, chocolate, caramel. Has a warming alcohol flavor and feel. Drinks slightly carbonated as well, great smoothness. Finishes dry and sweet. I had this on tap at DFH restaurant and it was better, as expected. None the less, this is a world class tasting brew.  This brew is absolutely fantastic, has all the big flavors and taste with mouthfeel you could want. The only reason it would be hard to session would be because the high alcohol. World class.

Poured into a mug.  Pours a near pitch black brew with just the faintest hint of brown along the bottom edge of the mug. The deeply tanned, light brown head is two fingers thick and creamy.  This brew smells of deep roasted, sweet caramel and vanilla. There is also a definte woodiness in the nose, and a descent whiff of alcohol presence at the finish.  Big, complex flavors in this one. Roasted caramel, vanilla, dark earthy fruit, some espresso notes, hints of chocolate and a very unique finish that is dry, but also has what I would guess is the Palo Santo wood aging, which lingers long. Meal in a glass. Awesome stuff. Excellent balance of bitters and sweetness.  Heavy, chewey brew in the mouth that is incredibly smooth and creamy.  I recently had this at DFH Restaurant in Rehoboth Beach, DE and I believe it is a bit better on tap, but to be honest - this is one heck of a brown ale. You can definitely feel the abv here, but there is just so much going on in terms of flavor that if you have not tried this, it is well worth a try. As a souvenir, I bought a 4 pack of this at the restaraunt. Sadly, there are only 3 left at this point and I do not see these too often.

A- Very dark brown / almost black pour, dark amber highlights when held up to light. Half inch light brown head that quickly dissipates to a thing ring.  S- Toasted malts, vanilla, the wood really stands out in the nose. Earthy, dark chocolate and brown sugar.  T- Roasted coffee, vanilla, toasted malts, dark fruits.  M- Creamier and heavier than I would have originally guessed. Especially being marked as a brown ale. To me its a hybrid; creamy like a stout but thin like a porter. The alcohol is barely noticeable and the carbonation gives it a good punch.  D- If it wasn't 12% the 4pk wouldn't last me the night. This really is a remarkable beer. I was sad when my glass was empty.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into my arrogant bastard pint glass, a thin dark brown head, color of cured wood tops the brew. The body is extremely dark, not pitch black but definitely so thick you can't possibly see through it.  The smell imparts very strong "in your face" estery alcohol with a backgrounded malty sweet nutty brown ale feel. I get some dark maple and molasses in there.  The flavors are great in this brew, up front strong alcohol flavor, gives a wood aged bourbon feel in the taste while keeping a brown malt sweet flavor to back it. I actually get a bit of cherry flavor milling about in there and a roasted sugared chesnut type flavor. There is a very distinct finishing aftertaste to this brew that I cannot account for with anything except the wood fermenters they make it in.  I love the mouthfeel on this brew, it's thickness and darkness with minimal carbonation combines with a hot alcohol barrel aged type feeling. The aftertaste and the hotness of it are a great finishing touch on it.  Definitely a sipper, chugging this thing would be quite dangerous haha. But the type of tastes that are backgrounded in this one make it drinkable enough to say hey, I could possibly chug it.

12lf oz bottle poured into my snifter  The appearance is opaque black with no light passing through. The pour produced a one inch medium brown head with slightly less than average head retention. No noticeable lacing was left behind.  Aroma consist of various kinds of chocolate with the likes of dark chocolate and milk chocolate. Vanilla follows with oak and bourbon. Caramel and roasted malts with coffee is also detected in the aroma.  Upfront sweet taste with milk chocolate and vanilla. Following midway is oak. bourbon, caramel , and dark chocolate. Finishing is a slight coffee flavor with roasted malts and tobacco.  Full bodied with high carbonation and a sweet aftertaste lingers.  If I did not know better I could pass this as an Imperial Stout from the way it taste. For a brown ale this is really good and something I would like to try again.

Appearance: It pours heavy and opaque brown/black. An even thin creamy head appeared, and lasted most of the glass. This is one dense drink.  Smell: A strong smelling beer; big dark chocolate and earthy wood that one assumes is Palo Santo Marron. Sweet esters and heat.  Taste: Huge flavor bomb! Roasty, dark earth flavors, with molasses and burnt sugars. Very sweet and complex, with many flavors of wood and earth. Reminded me of a few Scottish ales I have tried.  Mouthfeel: Thick, heavy, viscous and coating of the palate. You know you are drinking an extreme beer.  Drinkability: Low; this is a big beer that packs a punch; I am used to high gravity brews, and this one throws some weight into you. A good one to share with someone.  Notes: I bought this bottle 2 months before I drank it. I was saving it to try on Father's Day. Not only am I a father-to-be so it is my first of many Father's Days to come, but also my father is a wood artist, who makes pens and other fine pieces; so I wanted to split a bottle with him. A great beer for a great day!

Bottling date of 05/09.  A - The blackest brown ale I've ever encountered. A brown hue cups the bottom of the snifter, but that's it. It sports a dark brown collar that recedes most of the way after a couple minutes.  S - Dark chocolate jumps out immediately along with strong wood notes from the Palo Santo. If I didn't know better I would have pegged it to be aged in whiskey barrels. There's a really nice vanilla note as well, along with a mild earthiness that's probably coming from the barrel instead of hops at this point.  T - The wood packs a big punch. I know I've read that people prefer the beer fresh because the wood is more prominent, and while I haven't had it fresh I would imagine I'd prefer at this stage. It seems as though there would be a lot of rough edges when it's fresh. The wood flavor is almost biting, if that makes sense, in how flavorful it is. Dark chocolate is prominent upfront, followed by some fruitiness the earthiness I mentioned. At this point the sharpness of the alcohol steps in before fading into vanilla. There's also some slight roastiness in the finish, which makes me think this beer isn't properly labeled as a brown ale. Then again, I don't know what to call it.  MF - It hits mark pretty well. Silky smooth, but with enough carbonation to keep it from feeling too big. Leaves the mouth coated and sticky, but on a level that feels appropriate.  D - I would imagine it's better than this would be fresh, but I think it could still go quite a ways with a bit more time. Still, the beer feels like it has actual direction, something that a lot of DFH beers seem to be lacking. The wood adds to the drinkability as well since it cuts back some of the sweetness.

12oz into a tulip. Pours a very dark brown/black with purple fringed minor head that dissipated quickly, minor carbonation. Mysterious  Very strong aroma of dark fruits, old barrel, smoke, vanilla and alcohol. The scent is as powerful as any! Intoxicating, I can't wait to savor.  The taste is . . . . strong. I don't know if I like this but I keep taking baby sips. Any amount more and it causes me to shudder. This is frick'n terrible. I keep sipp'n, I want to like this. I'm gonna try and fight through this, perhaps I'll see the light, feel the love. Has similarities to a Russian Imperial Stout which generally agree with me but this is a brown traitor. Oh no, now it's warming, doubling down on my taste buds. Maybe I should eat some habanero infused baby diapers so my mouth welcomes this lesser of two evils. If I end up in beer hell, I'll be served this swill.  above is what I wrote on 72310 what I'm tasting now is different in that I don't hint at a shudder my review has changed from an F to a C- cheers jd

The first time I had the Palo Santo Marron was after I toured the DFH Brewery in Milton, DE. They offer free beers tastings after the tour and when I tried the Palo Santo, I was blown away! I bought a 4-pack before I left.  Enjoyed in a DFH Signature Glass  A - The beer is a very dark color, to the point that no light shines through even if you hold it up to a light. Alright, lets call it almost black.  S - The smell is what I describe as very sweet, with a combination of vanilla and caramel with a pretty good alcohol smell as well.  T - The taste is excellent, with a combination of sweetness and woodiness that I assume comes from the palo santo wood that this beer is aged in. The alcohol is disguised but it's lurking there in the background. This beer gets even tastier as it warms up a bit.  M - A slightly thick mouthfeel. Lightly carbonated.  D & O - At 12 ABV this is a beer that goes great as a night cap but not one you'll be chugging at the next BBQ. Open a few and let your buddies have a chance to savor an exceptional beer from the folks at DFH.  Cheers!  Update: This was the first beer I reviewed on BA. This beer still ranks as one of my top-5 beers I have ever had even after having a lot of different styles and varieties through the years.

Served in a sniffer. I had to pour this one pretty vigorously for it to give up a tiny head. Which then of course, quickly faded to a ring and only left a tiny bit of lacing. The beer itself looks dark brown and syrupy when pouring, and pitch black in the glass.  The aroma is roasted malts, coffee, a bit of sweetness, alcohol, and something I can't identify. Which i assume is the wood showing through. Pretty interesting. The flavor extends from the nose nicely, it rounded and well balanced bitter and sweet. Alcohol presence is strong, and with 12% ABV that makes sense. Wood and chocolate flavors are there adding some complexity.  The carbonation is much more apparent than I expected given how it poured. This is nice, since it lifts the otherwise heavy mouthfeel. I wouldn't drink more than one of these in a sitting, but I am thoroughly enjoying this one. I think it would do well with some age on it.

A: The beer is jet black and poured with a finger high tan head that quickly died down into a thin layer of bubbles. A moderate amount of carbonation is visible. S: The aroma is very intense, especially as the beer begins to warm up, and smells from the barrel aging stand out in particular. There are some hints of alcohol. T: Like the smell, the flavors from the barrel aging really dominate the taste, which is complex and also has hints of bittersweet chocolate, raisins, roasted coffee and rum. M: It feels medium-bodied on the palate and is both smooth and viscous. Not much carbonation is perceptible. There is warming from the alcohol in the finish, which also has some dryness. D: This beer definitely needs to be sipped because it has an intense flavor and the alcohol will quickly catch up to you (the alcohol is noticeable but fairly well masked from the taste).

I'm sorry, but I could NOT drink this beer. I had been looking forward to it so much, too. All I could taste was wood and alcohol, which overpowered the finer flavors. An assault on the tongue. It's just not my type of thing. I don't think the higher ABV helped this beer.

This was reviewed at Loris Diner in San Francisco on July 19, 2010. Paired with Loris Diner's "Snack Mix"  Wiseman Justin Reporting:  Appearance: Opaque as hell. Head retention is poor. Good ring around top; small island of bubbles in the middle. Nice darker colored mocha head.  Smell: Molasses, Pistachios? Carbonation. Some Bourban.  Taste: Carbonation dominates. Bourban is the backup. Reminds me of Old Stock Ale. Very strong wood (from the bourbon aging) some chocolate and roasted nuts. It's too bleh, and less tasty then I remember it from the bottle.  Mouthfeel: I smelled carbonation and I could taste the carbonation. Guess what I could Feel? It burns too.  Drinkability: It's got 13% ABV and isn't all that tasty. It's highly carbonated nad taste a lot like bourbon. It's not working for me.. I'm not sure what's going on here. It's not terrible by any regards I just remember liking tihs beer more and am dissapointed by the on-tap showing.  Pairing Score; B+ The bowl of goodies was much better than the beer and it helped refocus my palate.

Appearance - Brown head with a very dark unfiltered body. Barely any light get through, some mahogany at the edges  Aroma - Alcohol, raisons and other dark fruits, bit of wood and smoke, sweet roasted malts, some molasses as well.  Taste - I get a bit of alcohol burn up front, followed by the dark fruits and some smokiness. Mid way through the sweet malts take over with some roasted malt and molasses notes. The finish has chocolate, some vanilla and caramel as mentioned on the bottle with enough bitterness from the hops to keep it from being too sweet. No alcohol burn on the mostly dry finish that leaves a bit of a chocolate caramel coffee flavor.  An unbelievably complex yet drinkable brown ale, Palo Santo Marron takes the standard brown ale in a completely new and different direction. It makes a fantastic desert beer or night cap.

12oz. bottle into tulip.  The body is black, with a thick milk chocolate colored head.  The aroma is of light roasty malt, with notes of the Palo Santo wood, vanilla and caramel.  The flavor follows the aroma fairly well, with roasted malts backed by a combination of nuttiness, vanilla and caramel. There is a light booziness that strengthens up as it warms.  The mouthfeel is full bodied and has good carbonation as well. This is very drinkable, and has become one of my favorite go-to beers. I also love that this is offered year-round.

12oz bottle in a tulip.  pours a deep mahogany, sits a borderline black tone while yielding a smallish, maybe 1/2" tan head. moderate retention and lacing.  bold, aromatic nose smacks of malty, woody, smoky delciousness; there's chocolate, roasted malt, some vanilla. almost more like an imperial stout than a brown. great aroma.  taste confirms the delicious: smoky and woody notes swirl around sweet roasted malt, hints of coffee, chocolate, molasses, and vanilla; and at 12% abv, there's definitely a kick of warming alcohol. this a big, unique, and very tasty brew, full of flavor and complexity. smooth, medium-full bodied mouthfeel with adequate carbonation. drinkability is good for a beer this potent, you have to remind yourself to sip. really enjoying this one.

A. Pours a dark brown with a slightly reddish hue, it has a nice 3/4 inch milk chocolate head that settles in minutes. While it is darker than most Browns, the mystery that waits is killing me.  S. Smoky and sweet with peat, oak and plums. As it warms up hints of molasses, caramel and vanilla are revealed.  T. It tastes more like an old ale than a Brown. A definite woody taste stands high above hints of brown sugar and dark fruits- perhaps figs. A slight ethanol kick reminds you that this beer is 12%.  M. Thicker and more chewy than most Browns without being particularly heavy. There is a tartness in the finish that hangs on the tongue. I'm not sure if the lack of carbonation is entirely because of the high alcohol but it is noticeable.  D. Different than any other beer I've ever had, I will definitely have another. Not a daily drinker for me, but a good one still.

A - Murky, deep ruby brown with a minimal brown head that has little retention, but some spotty lacing down the glass.  S - Vanilla, wood, and a touch of alcohol as it warms.  T - Follows the nose with vanilla, then has a nice roasted malt character with some coffee, and the wood aging on the back.  M - Medium to full body, perfectly low carbonation level makes it creamy across the palate with a clean dry finish.  D - Wow, 12%? Never would have guessed, because it is hidden so well. So smooth and creamy going down, perfectly balanced, complex tastes make this a stellar brew.

12 oz bottle into a snifter.  A: Pours almost like an imperial stout. Very light on the carbonation, had a little head which dissipated quickly. Not much in the way of lacing on the glass.  S: A very deep, smoked, earthy stout-like smell.  T: Dark, smoky and woody. A little hop bitterness as well. It looks like a stout but definitely a strong, dark brown ale. Very good.  M: Exactly the right amount of carbonation. This one leaves a thick film in the mouth that reminds you of how big it is.  D: It's good, but I wouldn't drink more than one of these. You may also consider sharing a single bottle with someone else.

Oh Holy Grail of dark beers! American Brown Ale?!?! Come on, give me a break, it's got to be in some other dark category-- porter, stout?  A= dark dark thick rich black-brown, modest head when served to me in a brandy snifter at Dogfish Head, Gaithersburg MD.  S= I could spend hours just sniffing this. HUGE smoky bold nose bringing reminiscences of an old country inn burning rare hardwood in a fireplace. The Palo Santo wood from Peru really does fulfil its fame! All sorts of other notes going on here, plentiful hops florals, some dark fruits, but smoke and more gorgeous smoke.!  T= the Scent was shades of things to come. More smoke, as promised. Bold, rich, dry, over the top strong flavors, wood, I was overwhelmed and will need to hopefully return for another snifter and pay more careful attention to details. Suffice it to say that I wish I lived next-door.  M= rich, smoky, strong and bold, very fulfilling.  D= amazingly this went with everything that I was eating, mostly a mixed seafood plate with homemade potato chips. Would be spectacular with a dark chocolate dessert but unfortunately I would fear that this beer would diminish the enjoyment of the dessert!

This one was bottled in July of 2008. Poured into a pint glass.  A - Pours a dark, dark brown that pretty much goes opaque black once it collects in the glass. A slightly aggressive pour yields a good finger of dark brown head that settles down to a nice retentive ring around the glass. This baby looks like a stout. A light wisp of bubbles continues to hang around on top.  S - Sweet cocoa and dark ripe fruit. Raisins. The wood aging appears as well. Hint of alcohol.  T - Sweet malty goodness. Dark sweet chocolate and strong notes of roasted espresso. Hints of the raisins and dark fruits. Smooth vanilla. Hint of smokiness. The mellow wood flavors really shine through on the finish and aftertaste. Hint of alcohol in there, but it's well hidden. Very complex, and very good.  M - Excellent. Smooth, chewy, and creamy.  D - Very good for a 12% brew. You have to fight the urge not to sip this one as you should.  Notes: Not sure I'd classify this one as a brown ale, as it really seems to head more into the stout territory for me, but this is one tasty beer and I don't really care what category it's in. This would be a great sipper on a cool evening.

Nice, dark brown ale, almost seems like a stout to me, plus there is a little sweetness mixed in here, I did not check the bottle to see whats in it, but it comes off almost sugary.  High abv can be detected minimally, nothing detrimental. Coffee flavor, goes down pretty smooth, one of the better brown ales I have ever had, can't remember a better one (maybe dogfish Indian Brown if any).  Not a session beer, one of these and I was good to go. Nice beer though.

12 oz bottle dated 4/20/10 poured into a snifter  A- Dark, almost black, but has a hint of brown and a small dark tan head.  S- The Palo Santo wood is the biggest smell, with hints of brown sugar and dark chocolate.  T- Wood really comes through with a semi-sweet roasted malt/chocolate taste.  M- Smooth and a good weight.  D- Enjoyable and easy to drink, alcohol could be hind better. If you like beer aged in wood barrels this is a must have.

Poured from a 12oz brown bottle into a St. Bernardus goblet. Bottled on date of 12/28/09. Palo Santo Maroon appears a very dark brown color with some redness around the edges when held up to the light. The head appears less than a finger strong with a creamy dark brown color that retains quite well for such a high abv. Lacing appears and sticks in spots about the glass. Nose has a strong dark sugary aroma much like a mix of molasses and brown sugar. Some nutty date-like scents come into play as well along with some noticeable alcohol. As the beer warms, the nose indicates some previously hidden scents of caramel and vanilla. The taste of this brew has some bold malt character coming across much like the aroma indicated but not as sweet as the nose suggested. Flavors full of dark sugary notes riddled with alcohol and a contrasting bitterness of dark grain slightly chocolatey. The finish of this brew leaves a lingering taste of woodsy flavors much unlike the usual contribution of oak. It is peculiar with a flavor I never experienced before but very much enjoyable. For such as high abv brew this is a chewy full bodied brew but very smooth in the feel and quite drinkable considering. At times the alcohol comes across a bit astringent but understandable so. Wow I bet some age would make this taste even more wonderful.

Every time I have this beer I marvel anew at how damn tasty it is. As thick and chewy as it is, it's about as drinkable as they come; I have to restrain myself from guzzling it. A truly exceptional brew - far out of style - from a brewer justly celebrated for breaking style guidelines.

A- Very dark for the brown ale it claims to be. Light lacing and light brown head that disappears quickly.  S- at 12% you can definitely smell the alcohol along with an earthy sweet smell  T- a strong roasted taste is what strikes me first followed by a sweet taste followed by a mild burn (again 12%)  M- very thick with nice carbonation  D- great relaxation beer. Even at 12% its extremely drinkable. Definitely recommend it if you can find it.

12-ish oz. poured into a snifter  A - Jet black with no head and a minuscule amount of lacing  S - Burnt sugar, white raisins  T - Wood, molasses, and brown sugar are evident right away. This exponentially sweetens as the seconds pass, and dark raisins and prunes make an appearance as it warms. This may appear that I'm reviewing an extremely flavorful old ale; in actuality, I'm describing an overly sweet, distinctively strong ale.  M - Medium-heavy with a quality amount of carbonation.  D - Obviously 12% and too sweet.  I was really looking forward to this, and I'm a bit disappointed. It's not a bad beer, but it's nothing I feel compelled to have again soon. Maybe in a couple of years.

Bottle 5/21/10 into wine glass  A: Dark brown/black with a huge head. Great lacing once head disipates. A thick brew!  S: Aromas of roasted coffee and dark chocolate. Hints of raisin and brown sugar. No overpowering alcohol.  T: Sweeter then I was hoping for. Lots of coffee and roasted malts. Molasses on the mid-palate. A little alcohol burn but not too intense. Some burnt toast at the end.  M: Thick, real thick. Needed a water back for this one. Lingers on the palate. You don't feel cheated.  D: Huge beer meant to be shared with others!

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a dogfish head pint glass.  A- Dark brown/burgundy, non-transparent, finger of head(dark eggshell brown in color) that quickly dissipated. Mild lacing.  S- Earthy, sweet, vanilla, caramel, maybe faint chocolate.  T/M- Thick, rich, velvety, smooth, a little boozy when cold. Malty, sweet, excellent aftertaste.  D- Really rich, this is like a dessert beer for me. I don't know that I could have more than one or two of these in a sitting. This would go well with any kind of chocolate dessert or even cheesecake. I recommend trying this beer when you get a chance. Keep up the good work dogfish.

appearance is a very dark brown, almost black. very little if any head as the beer settles.  smell is malt, wood and earthy, with an alcohol bite, very interesting and new smells here.  a good brown ale base with flavorful malt gives way to the unique wood aged flavor that i am really digging. (someone start growing it here and selling barrels for my homebrew please) exceptional and unique flavor.  mouthfeel is surprisingly good. the pour made this beer look syrupy and undercarbonated, but i was surprised by a good amount of carbonation and a smooth feel.  flavor is excellent but the hints of alcohol detract from drinkability.

I hear so much about this beer but rarely try it. Apparently I had a growler of this recently, but don't really remember. I agree with my original review that it's by no means an american brown. However, you could say it's an american brown on steroids. Very intense in the flavors you want from a brown. Good dark malt without being too roasty. Amazing aroma that is, again, not too dark but very malty. Overall, this is a great late evening beer or winter warmer.

On tap at bluedog in chalfont.  A- comes to me with a good finger of creamy tan head that settles quickly to a faint skin and a small ring. Very dark brown almost black in color. Nice legs.  S- big time woody punch, palo santo wood I guess, that rolls into a dark chocolate sweetness. Some dark bread, pumpernickle maybe, definitely a big graniness.  T- I've got wood! Big time wood. Roasty and slightly burnt. Dark roasted malts and dark bread. Mild sweetness that goes a long well with the layers of complex wood and roast. Maybe some smoked peat and a deep eathiness. But all in all the woods where its at.  M- almost full bodied and a nice mid level carb that helps the feel. Very dry with lots of tannins.  D- I like this a lot but all in all its a palate crusher and 12 abv is no joke. Either way I think I'm having another.

Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and little head with a smattering of lace left on the side of the glass. Smells of dark,ripe fruit(prune,raisin) and dark rye toast. Very sweet but not cloyingly so,lots of dark, malty goodness here as well. Big ABV.,but is not overwhelming. You can absolutley drink more than one,just pace yourself. Have been on a DFH kick latley, and this beer is another great example of their take on this style.

Beer was bottled less than two months ago on 4-20-10.  pours a syrupy and black, super thick beverage. With small brown head. Low carbonation which is often associated with the high alcohol beers. That might improve over time as the yeast ferment the few left over fermentable sugars.  Really nice dark roasty flavors. The taste of this beer is really unique and delicious. And I will say this; the alcohol content of this beer is very well hidden. (@ 12% A.B.V.) I could definitely put a few of these back before realizing how alcoholic it was. The burn is actually pleasant.  It does seem to have low head retention, unless it is my glass or something.  I think I will save the rest of these for this winter, or the next winter. !!!young, inexpensive, high alcohol by volume beers could almost alway use a bit of aging. This beer was very fresh. I hope they let me do a second review after aging the beer for a year or two.

Split a bottle with my buddy. Glad I did, too, since this is some super-strong stuff.  "American Brown Ale" may be the official BA style designation here, but it's much closer to a Barleywine or Old Ale in many respects.  Its greatest quality is the temperament left from the barrel-aging in the Palo Santo wood, which imparts a depth of flavor unrivaled in the DFH oeuvre. (Is that vanilla I discern?)  The overall effect is something very much akin to a fine sherry, and it should be consumed in a similar fashion -- slowly, deliberately, and luxuriously.

Review #100  Pours the darkest brown with a half finger dark tan head that dissipates quickly. The smell is very unique and mostly of the palo santo wood and booze. The taste is wonderful, like drinking a log. There is a sweetness to the wood that is quite pleasant. There is a boozy finish even after a year of aging, but not overwhelming. Mouthfeel suffers a bit from the flavor intensity, and after about 8oz I'm done. Best DFH beer I've had.

Pours a thick oil-black with a medium head. Olfactories pick up hints of fruity esters and a sweet vanilla punch. The taste is consistent with this before a brisk burn of alcohol takes over. Fans of bourbon barrel stouts will be interested in this uncharacteristic brown ale, aged in Paraguayan Palo Santo wood vessels. Certainly a unique and delicious brew.

12 Ounce brown bottle poured into a pint glass  Appearance: Very dark brown/black with a brown head that diminishes really quickly.  Smell: Raisin with a slightly nutty smell. For the amount of alcohol in this, the smell is not really even there.  Taste: Sweet with a taste very similar to the smell. Because of how dark this is I expected a toasted taste but there is nothing like that in this beer. Good and still surprising it has as much alcohol as it does.

A - black, dark tan head quickly recedes to a ring  S - rich nuttiness, big carmel, vanilla, raisin, very inviting  T - lots of carmelized raisin, dry earthy woodiness, sweet, but not at all cloying, aftertaste is light roast coffee  M - velvety, luxurious, medium body, light carbonation, alcohol is very drying, and has a fair bit of warmth, which really helps cut the sweetness  D - definitely one of DFH finer offerings, a fine sipper for sure  Bottled Feb 09, so about 15 months old.  I first tried this beer in fall 2008, and loved it. Picked up a 4-pack last summer, and then never got around to trying one until today. Though I quite liked my first taste, I was in no hurry, as I knew this beer would hold up well. It could still stand to lose a bit more alcohol heat, but regardless, this is a top notch drink. I have been underwhelmed by many offerings from DFH, but this is possibly their best.

This unique ale pours very dark brown--nearly black with a moderate tan head. The aroma is rather complex--moderate-high bittersweet, caramel malt with hints of earthy peat and a bit oaky. The flavor is intensely malt--bittersweet, caramel with a smooth acid earthy undertones and a bit of vanilla. The hop bitterness is moderate and provides balance. The body is exceptionally smooth and very high ABV is hidden in just subtle warmth in the throat and belly. The body is full and carbonation moderate. Overall a very flavorful, complex brew--exceptionally smooth. Interesting wood--I could never pick it out of something different than say oak, but certainly makes a tasty beer.

Bottle (Bottled on 5/27/09) Thick and vinous and hardly carbonated. The mouthfeel is somewhere between a nice cabernet and a good single malt. Chocolate malt and a volitle alcohol warmth dominate the aroma and it leaves an interesting tabacco flavor on the back of the throat as the warmth from the alcohol subsides. Its not the first beer I'd reach for or would i call it a social beer but I commend the effort.

First off, the only reason that gets a 4 on drinkability is that this is not a beer for everyone, saw a guy the other day on post that slammed this beer. It's expensive and not for everyone, but that's kind of DFH in shorthand. Anywhoo... The malt and wood are on the nose even. DFH has this effect with a lot of their beers. Like the 120 min. Could smell that on the other side of the room by just opening the cap. The lack of hops is accentuated by the smell of cherries and ...what's that...oh wood! Surprise! There is a thin tan head atop this Adonis of a ..brown ale? Chocolate wood and fruit on the mouth and a lingering sense of wanting more. The 12% alc. isn't even noticed. Another sly beer from the kings of high alc%. Must buy if ya got $17.

Appearance: impressive, dark dark mahogany, almost solid brown, tan head.  Smell: coffee, roasty malts, chocolate  Taste: bold, intense, and complex. Chocolate, coffe, malt, woodiness from the barrels. I got a tobacco-like cigar taste, some vanilla, and some booziness. Here was a lot going on.  Mouthfeel: substantial, full  Drinkability: I could drink this beer a lot, but not in small quantities due to the high abv. Trully an artisan ale.

On tap at Barley's Greenville 5/17/2010.  Super dark ruby-brown in color. Tan head. Roasty, woody aroma (cedar-like, which I presume to be the Palo Santo wood profile) along with dark chocolate & vanilla. Without knowing the style beforehand, the aroma might lead me to believe I had an imperial stout in my hand. Flavor is huge dark chocolate with a smoky, barrel-aged likeness. Vanilla as well. Full bodied with a smooth booziness. Drinkability low, but this is a seriously tasty beer. Curious how it would taste with a bit of age on it.

Poured to a one inch head. Head was dark brown or chocolate in color. Beer itself was black in color. There was no light getting through this brew. Head hung around for a little while. A little lacing but not much. You could smell chocolate as soon as the bottle was opened. Also could smell the alcohol. Almost smelled like whiskey. Tasted of heavy chocolate, alcohol, whiskey, caramel, slight vanilla flavor, malt. Also had that alcohol burn. Felt thick in the mouth. Carbonation was about right. To heavy for me. Also to boozy. I dont think you could enjoy a few. I had a nice buzz after one.

Palo Santo Marron pours a dark brown with an ultra-thin umber head that reduces down to a ring around the edge of the glass very quickly. Aromas of molasses, fruity(really?) sweetness, and a little wood. Chocolate malty sweetness upfront and a bit of cherry on the palate. Finish is of sweet alcohol blanced out by a drying wood. There is a slightly fuzzy mouthfeel but there is no mouth coating like I expected. A syrupy stickiness is present at the lips but not much anywhere else. A slightly drying wood feel moments after swallowing is also present and there is no alcohol burn.  This is a very fun beer to drink. Sweet yet dry, a lot of flavor and an interesting mouthfeel make this a great sipping beer although it's balanced enough you don't have to sip. Wood flavors are nicely subdued so you don't feel like your sucking on beer flavored wood chips.I really felt like another one immediately but at 12% I don't know if that's a good idea... yes I do.

Pours black with mahogany head. Carbonation is a little uneven. The smell is actually not too great, there's a metallic quality to the smell. The taste is rather nice, however. The beer has a chocolatey edge to it and something else I can't quite pin down, perhaps something to do with the Palo Santo Marron wood that they mention. Mouthfeel is sticky, and the beer is pretty smooth and drinkable.

Served from tap into standard pint. Poured a dark dark brown (almost black) with a one-finger off-white head. Maintained decent lacing throughout. The aroma contained a nutty hint with malt notes as well. The flavor of this one was malty, nutty, and sweet. This brew was medium on the palate with low carbonation. Overall this was a nice stout with a nice welcomed sweet flavoring. Very nice stout and was not aware of the ABV until checking here on the site.

Poured into a tulip. Pours quite dark for a brown ale, light doesn't really penetrate. Tan head is almost nonexistent, decent lacing on the glass, however. Smells of red wine--cabernet?--with some chocolate and nuts.  Smoky notes over bittersweet chocolate up front. Some red fruit, and a red wine quality to it. Somewhat like Dogfish Indian Brown ale channeling a smoked porter. Lighter carbonation. Moderate body, somewhat watery mouthfeel. Slight warming alcohol presence, and a somewhat dry finish.  Another experiment from Dogfish that's ended well. Glad I tried this, though I prefer their regular brown ale.

Bottle pours a very dark black, almost stout like. The taste is heavy on the wood and dark chocolate. A little vanilla and dark fruits lingers in there as well. Overall, the 12% is well hidden and it goes down quite smooth. Kinda wishing I picked up a second bottle of this.

A - Deep brown body lets some light through during the pour but little after it all makes it into the glass. Small head on aggressive pour.  S - Smooth chocolate aroma with vanilla and wood. Hops smell mild if anything. Rich aroma but not hot as I would have predicted. Getting coffee as it warms as well as a little bit of fruit and heat is starting to creep in.  T - Tastes like a stout, as in there is a load of chocolate and coffee as well as wood and vanilla. Really smooth, not a ton of residual sugar. Quite tolerable, I expected this to have a big stick FG. Ends hard with coffee.  M/D - Despite being a big beer it's easy to drink. A sipper for sure because of the ABV and because you have to savor the flavor but you could easily drink a few if you wanted to get into trouble. My only issue is I'm not getting he wood thing that hard, which is fine, it's done tastefully but if you gave this to me blind I wouldn't know. For the price I feel it's a bit hype despite the backstory to it being awesome. Always respect DFH.

Pours black with virtually no head. No light comes through it.  Smell has some dark fruit, bourbon, and sugar. Smells a tiny bit boozy. The vanilla described on the label also comes through in the smell.  Taste is complex. Starts off with some sweeter dark fruit, with a hint of tartness that is quickly swept away by smooth creamy vanilla and caramel. The booze is very well hidden, more so than I had expected.  Mouthfeel is highly carbonated and thick. Coats the mouth and tongue and leaves it slightly sticky.  Drinkability is low. Taste wise this is easy to drink, but at 12% ABV... one is enough.

A: Deep, thick brown with a tan head that sizzled down quite rapidly. You can definitely tell this is on the strong side from the appearance. Easily the darkest brown ale I've seen. Nearly no light is coming through this one. The head is quite a lovely reddish brown color.  S: Chocolate and caramel malts are strong right off the bat. Dry cocoa and a deep roasted aroma. Behind this follows some plum and dark cherry aromas. Some alcohol noticeable, but not hot. Glad I let this one warm a bit, because the aroma seems to be very deep in profile.  T: Lovely woody flavor, the Palo Santo definitely has lent a very nice quality to this beer. Not the usual oaky type flavor, but a smoother and sweeter wood flavor. Nice sweet malts and a good hop bitterness as well. Some raisins and cherries lend a sweetness as well. A bit boozy with some deep and dark fruits. Great flavor profile.  M: Very thick and viscous for a brown ale, and I know...it isn't really widely classified as one. Very nice mouthfeel as this beer seems to leave a slickness on the teeth.  D: Finding this one highly drinkable, thought the alcohol presence would make it hot, but it is definitely hidden well. Well crafted, yet dangerously drinkable beer.

Poured into a tumbler it produces a small coffee colored head that leaves ample lacing. The appearance is deep dark brown with clear ruby highlights. The aroma is complex, sweet, with hints of toasted malt, caramel, and black currant. The taste is richly sweet with all the flavors suggested by the aroma along with woody astringency. The feel is full bodied with a somewhat bitter finish. The alcohol blends in well.  This is an extremely good ale

Stoked o try this one for a while. I love just about all the brews that Sam and the fine folks @ DFH turn out. So here she goes...  Comes out an very dark brown color, basically black with a mocha head.  Smells like a liquid candy bar. Melted chocolate, rich caramel toffee, vanilla. ALso present are whiffs of sweet bread, coffee liquer and maple syrup.  A symphonic array of flavors are present in this 'holy shit' taste dept. THe flavor morphs in your mouth. It starts out sweet and rich with notes of dark fruit and milky chocolate, but wait...midway through things get interesting as the taste turns into woody and vanilla bean affair. The close is long and dry with a lingering coffee flavor.  Full bodied sipper with an ultra smooth velvety texture. this is borderline perfection.  This is truly a fine crafted brew. THe alcohol is pretty well hidden which gives it a bit more 'quaffability' points. Flavor and scent are the epitome of complex. Dangerously drinkable, even at 12 percent.  Good job boy and girls of DFH!

Poured a dark cola brown into a tulip with just a trace of mocha head. Pleasant aroma of sweet caramel, vanilla, roasty oak, and Kahlua.  Smooth mouthfeel with just enough carbonation to keep things from getting too syrupy. Taste begins with vanilla and toffee and leads into a bit of smoky oak, leather, espresso, and dark chocolate on the mildly bitter finish.  You get a sense of the high ABV throughout, but it doesn't adversely affect the flavor...just makes this one all the more pleasurable to sip and savor. Bought a couple to age and can't wait to see how they develop.  Update: consumed a 06/2008 bottle in 07/2011. Three years in the bottle really smoothed out the flavors and further concealed the alcohol. Just a slight hint of cardboard oxidation but nothing severe.

DFH Palo Santo Marron  Impenetrable black, slim brown ring of foam.  Sweet, dark cocoa hits the nose first. chocolate cake meets dark fruit, raisins, port wine, a little molasses. Woody. Intriquing.  Drinking: more chocolate, more dark malt. Sweet caramel tones, vanilla, with an oaky edge. Sweetness remains strong. Hangs long on the palate, really sticks it in there. Caramel tones abound, get a little sticky, even. Ends dry, and leaves you wanting more.The next sip repeats it all. The sweet, the smooth, the dry and rounded.  Really remarkable.

Poured into my trusty New Belgium globelet.  A - Pours thick and near-black, with a one-finger khaki head that quickly recedes into a smoky ring that stays for most of the duration. Wait, this isn't an impy stout? It looks like a fantastic stout, but I'll have to mark it down slightly for being a brown ale that isn't, well, brown.  S - Rich aromas of wood (mahogany and oak), cocoa beans, and bitter coffee. Some figs and prunes as well. Again, a brown ale? But wait, I'm definitely catching tree nuts and conifer aromas as well, and some caramelized brown sugar. Okay, a brown ale then, and it smells wonderful.  T - Wood and dark chocolate right up front, the coffee is there also. Nutty, roasted malts arrive quickly, and warm the palate. Discernable hop bitterness balances nicely. Outstanding.  M - Unreal smoothness and a thick, syrupy body. Yet again, much more reminiscent of an imperial stout, but I can't mark it down for not following style this time. This smoky, creamy textured charmer is one of the best feeling beers I've sampled.  D - This is a big beer at 12%, but it hides its alcohol heat better than anything this side of Dark Lord. A compulsive gulper, and I enjoyed each drop.  This could very easily be called a stout, or at least a porter, and no one would blink. There's enough nuttiness and hops to give away its brown ale roots, but the aging on the magical South American wood transforms this into something very very special. Worth seeking out if you're into big dark brews at all.

A dark muddy brown color pour with a small soapy tan head , short lasting , leaving loads of lacing all the way down the glass , lively carbonation . Aroma is malty and sweet , caramel , wood ,toasted nuts , brown sugar , spicy hops and a hint of alcohol . Flavor is big and malty , lots of caramel,toffee and earthy roasty nutts , just enough of the wood coming through , light smoke , vanilla and alcohol notes with a nice warming effect . Full body with a creamy smooth mouthfeel , slightly boozy finish . An all around great brew very drinkable and enjoyable , nice work DFH .

brewed feb 2008. Consumed may 2010.  A buddy of mine and I have been socking away palo santo's here and their since they became available in California (about feb. 2008). Since the acquisition of this beer, my palate has matured and refined itself to not only really appreciate its flavor, body and nuances, but to also appreciate this beer in all stages of its development. This last bottle was exceptional. It was chocolaty and creamy and spot on par with the hair of the dog Adam that we drank afterward.  Hell of a beer. Four Stars. "****"

12 oz. Bottle.... and I thought I was drinking a typical brown ale...  A: Dark brown, maybe even black, no head and no lacing (sound familiar, it's called an imperial stout).  S:Smells like World Wide Stout almost, tons of licorice and alcohol. I like it, but this really isn't anything like a brown ale to me. Also some smoky dark malt flavor hidden in there.  D/M: A little bit harsh but also creamy.  This is to brown ales as Lou Ferigno is to actors; you kind of like him but don't actually think of him as a real actor, more of a bodybuilder.

pours a dark chocolate color with a mocha frothy head.  the nose is very complex and I can't I.D. all of the smells. do detect the malts with caramel, molasses & brown sugar  taste is rich... malts, cocoa, roasted coffee, & sugared nuts. alcohol hits initially then fades away... very nice  very thick and rich, medium body. little carbonation but still works with the flavor profile  enjoyed this beer and very interesting take on a brown ale. the flavor profile is unique... plus I really enjoy the boozy taste.

A - Very dark brown, almost black, with ruby brown hues on the edges. Large, thick, frothy, and creamy light sandy beige head with very good retention and a good sized layer of creamy sticky lacing left.  S - This is definitely interesting to smell as it as a number of aromas, some I don't know really what they are. There is a good amount of dark malt smell with caramel and molasses in there and hints of smokiness. There is also some overriding tart/acidic aroma that I don't know what it is or how to significantly explain it.  T - Starts with a bit of dark malt with just hints of dark bread and even fainter hint of chocolate. That quickly gives way to a subtle dark fruit tartness. This then quickly opens up into a smokey, charred wood flavor. Underlying this is some burnt brown sugar and molasses. The finish has a strong peaty/charred wood tasting bitterness along with a fair amount of alcohol, and just the faintest underlying of dark fruit. The peat/charred wood really lingers on the tongue for quite some time. Reminds me a bit of a whisky really.  M - A touch more than medium body with slightly under moderate carbonation. Pretty smooth.  D - The alcohol and wood/peat can get to be a bit heavy after awhile. Definitely a sipper. Probably a good beer to have on occasion, but I don't think I'd make a habit of drinking it regularly.  Notes: Bottled on 05/27/09. Definitely an interesting beer that has a strong wood presence. Really this beer was a bit of an enigma for me whether it was trying to determine the aroma or trying to determine if I like it or not. At times I was really enjoying it, and at times I wasn't so sure. It's a beer that I'd really have to be in the mood for to have again. The wood/peat and alcohol were a little strong for me, but at times they worked. Those being so prominent reminded me of a whisky at times. Definitely worth a try to see how you feel about it.

Excited to try this beer, my 6th Dogfish Head. Last one I was able to procure on a trip to Colorado. So let's dive in...  A: Appears to have the viscosity of milk as poured. One finger head, deliciously dark caramel color. Beer looks like a stout in the glass. Very dark brown, almost black.  S: Wow. Blown away. So complex. Has a very intense caramel, woody, roasted malt smell. Intense smell lasts throughout the whole glass, but changes. Licorice sweetness becomes noticeable.  T: Perfect example of a beer that has a taste that almost exactly matches the aroma. Malty, roasted, sweet, woody. AMAZING! Truly phenomenal beer.  M: Very thick, feels smooth and minimally carbonated.  D: One 12oz bottle is perfect to be split between two people unless you don't mind sipping on this for a very long time. Very powerful beer and meant to be sipped.

fine beverage. enjoyed every drop.  very dark, almost black. purplish brown and very opaque. smells is great, roasted earth, some brown sugar smell with a slight tinge of fruit.  taste brings this one into my fav. from dogfish. i really enjoyed the earth roasted flavors with a brown sugar sweetness, the wood barrel flavor is mild and a nice balance of complexity with simple flavors.  nice a full beer with a great mouthfeel.  dinkablility is good.

A-Pours black with notes of brown leather and a small creamy tan head that has pretty ok retention ends up just being a colar on the rim of the beer and little to no lacing.  S-The smell is very complex with notes of caramel, chocolate, dark fruits and Palo Santo wood. Very nice indeed. Also there is a bit of fusal alcohol.  T-The flavor is much of the same as it has caramel and chocolate with an added demention of vanilla and spices and a very mocka-like wood character. With a touch of warming alcohol.  M-It's thick and silky with a woody aftertaste and warm slight sting on the finish from the alcohol.  D-I think the hotness of the alcohol really could've been hidden better. If it was, then I think it could've gotten an A+.

pours a solid black color with spare tan head and spare lacing. Chocolate wood flavor which was also apparent in the smell. heavy syrup like feel with caramel and vanilla hints. very sweet and just a very tiny bit bitter. full body with a creamy oily texture. alcohol was well hidden. to me this beer was completely average, i was not the least bit impressed, and had been left feeling slightly used and abused.

Palo Santo Marron | 330 ml. | 12.0% ABV  Appearance: Pours an opaque, silky black with a stout and creamy brown sugar head.  Aroma: Brown sugar, roasted chocolate malt and Palo Santo wood.  Taste: Initially sweet and drenched in a woody alcohol. Vanilla pulls out towards the middle along with chocolate malt. No hops in sight. It finishes dry with overtones of burnt wood and warming alcohol.  Mouthfeel: Very thick and silky. It's full-bodied with very little carbonation.  Harmony: Drink with food. The alcohol isn't overpowering, but it builds up quickly and leaves a burn on the aftertaste.  Price = $3.49 at Joe Canal's

A: Pours a nearly-opaque black (my pocket light revealed the slightest hint of red, but it's darker than a schwarzbier) with a 1.5-finger tan head. Coats the glass nicely when swirled. Brown ale, not so much. American stout, yes.  S: Roasted chocolate malt with cherries and a hint of alcohol.  T: Chocolate-vanilla bourbon beer! Initially very sweet, then vanilla and roasted malt flavors kick in, followed by wood. The aftertaste is nearly as complex as the main flavors. It's dry at first, followed by a very sharp woody flavor, then a warm ethanol dryness.  M: Smooth full body (think chocolate milk). The warmth is present, but not overwhelming.  D: This is an amazing beer. It could go well with spicy appetizers, or with rich desserts. Sip and savor.

A - opaque in the glass, a bit of light managed to shine through on the pour and it matched the reddish color on the label. Decent head, dissipates quickly. Lots 'o lacing.  S - Molasses and what I am assuming is Palo Santo wood.  T&M - Well balanced. Sweet flavors up front, like the bottle says caramel and vanilla, maybe some molasses. Thick and syrupy. finishes dry with smokey, wood, and , a touch of pepper and alcohol, but it is masked well.  D - considering the ABV, very drinkable.  When I bought this, I told the guy at the shop I'd never had it before and was looking forward to trying it. He told me "it's like chewing on cedar chips" . I've never chewed cedar chips, but now I may have to try that too.

Pours a black beer with a small brown head that leaves some lacing.  Smells of roasted malts, caramel, a bit woody with some fruit.  Taste is quite sweet, roasted malts, caramel malt, anis and dark fruits with warming alcohol. Very nice!  A full body, a viscous mouth feel with medium carbonation.

Bottled on date of 12/28/09, pours awful black for a brown ale. Truly epic in appearance. Red tinged around the edges, though it is a struggle to see any hues other than pitch blackness. Virtually no head to speak of, though there are a bit of tiny brown bubbles that cling to the edges of the glass. Minute lacing present also. Smell is big wood and the major alcohol punches you in the nose. Surely smells like a big ass beer. Also tastes heavily of the wood. The alcohol warmth of this is crazy. Almost has a bourbon characteristic to it. A very unique tasting brew, unlike anything I've ever encountered. Feel is light and smooth for such a monster beverage, burning sensation on the way down, though it is a good burn. I have to rate the drinkability of this a bit low, due to the heavy booze content. One of these is fine for me, may have to move on to something not so "epic". Great candidate for aging, as this is what I'll do with the rest of the pack.
